description:
MaMa Ji's is one of the best restaurants in the area. A little pricey but, most restaurants in the Castro are. 

We got the Clay Pot with Chicken and Mushrooms and Fish Fragrant Beef and both were amazing. Nice to see a restaurant actually use the clay pot to cook. 

They have a dim sum menu during the day and will for sure be trying that out.
author: Howie M.

description:
I went with fairly low expectations based on what I saw from Yelp, and I'd say the experience met expectations.

Ordered the cucumber salad, turnip cake, dumplings (XLB), fish with chilis, and a chicken/eggplant dish. The turnip cake was pretty good, the fish itself was good but way too spicy. And the chicken/eggplant dish was decent, what you would expect from a Panda Express.

And maybe this place is good for the Castro. I'm trying not to be too harsh because maybe it's unfair to compare the food here to other Chinese places in the general Bay Area.
author: Cal C.

description:
Solid 3.5 restaurant. My boyfriend and I met a friend here for dinner per our friends suggestion, and it was good! Because it was later in the evening, the restaurant was not too busy and we received pretty good service throughout our meal. The ambiance isn't too great and I did not look too closely, but I got the feeling that everything was dirty? I don't know? It just didn't feel clean in there.

THE FOOD: overall, pretty good! We ordered shanghai dumplings, potstickers and the cucumber salad as appetizers. Before I say this remember that I am a dumpling snob: the dumplings were not that great. They were extremely soppy/soggy at the bottom. Don't get me wrong, they had great flavor, but they weren't my favorite. The cucumber salad was great, as were the dumplings. We then ordered the combo fried rice, fried chicken and green beans, beef and green beans and sweet and sour pork. Everything tasted good and the portion sizes were pretty good. I personally thought the dried chicken and green beans were the best, but everyone thought their respective dish was the best and I'd say that's a good sign. All of the plates had good flavor! 

Overall, I think the food was good and I would come back, but maybe I wouldn't order the Shanghai dumplings again. I would be open to trying some of the other dumplings on their menu - maybe they are better!
author: Bri T.

description:
We went here for the first time today (Sunday around noon). There were only two of us, so we got the last open table. It was pretty busy, but the staff was attentive and gracious. 

We ordered only from the dim sum menu. It was pretty good, although we agreed the pot stickers needed more flavor. I think the prices are a little higher than average for dim sum. We waited quite a while for the last item (pork & shrimp shu mai), but the others came out at a steady pace. 

There is only one bathroom. Single bathrooms always suck because you are always going to be waiting to use it, especially in a place that gets busy like this. 

We'll probably be back to check out the rest of the menu. Four stars.
author: Lani S.

description:
They charge more than $12, about double the standard cost locally, for the most flavorless chow mein, which they initially confused for dry fried rice. 

I ordered the dishes via Caviar, thinking surely I'd enjoy amazing quality for the price tag. Obviously never again.
author: Paulina F.

description:
If you LOVE dim sum then this is the place for you! 

Excellent selection. It was difficult to decide between all of the amazing dishes offered. 

We went as a group of four for brunch on a Sunday. It was packed but we got lucky and we didn't have to wait. 

We ordered approximately 14 dishes all together. Not sure we needed that much but we dang sure ate all of it! No dumpling left behind! 

Service was ok. We ordered a specific sparkling wine and they brought us a different one. It tasted totally different and we had a difficult time explaining to them that we wanted to see the bottle (and send it back). They also have a lovely hard cider that went well with the tea and dumplings. 

Would return for the food alone.
author: Clyde V.

description:
Amazing! Highly recommend the hot and sour soup, Shanghai dumplings as well as the dry fried chicken. We also had the beef chow fun which was tasty but I'd try something else instead of that next time. 

Highly recommend!
author: Allison S.

description: I love this restaurant the service and food does no comparison to any other restaurant! The hot numbing is incredible as well as the salt rock shrimp! To top it all off the owner mama Ji's absolutely refreshing and sincere with nothing but good food service and experience to validate her joy for her business!
author: John A.

description: A good neighborhood spot for Chinese food with lots of veggie options. Be prepared for it to be loud though, the space is pretty small.
author: Clara M.

description: Amazing dim sum! The space is small and family-run, so you may have to wait on a weekend--but totally worth the wait!
author: Don W.

description:
I've wanted to visit Mama Ji's for a long time now and I'm pleased to say I was finally able to check it out yesterday :)

Mama Ji's offers great Szechuan cuisine. If you're not already familiar with Szechuan cuisine, one defining characteristic of the food is its can get SPICY. Even something like the hot and sour soup here is above average in terms of heat.

I didn't get a chance to try out any of the dim sum but as far as favorite dishes go, I absolutely loved the chicken wings and can't recommend them enough. Mama Ji's wing's probably make it into my top 5 in the city. Other than the wings, another dish I'd recommend (surprisingly actually) is the fried rice. I normally don't order fried rice at Chinese restaurant because it seems like such a average filler dish but the fried rice here was done really well. Good fried rice is where every grain of rice has been coated with a tiny bit of oil and has had the chance to toast in the wok its cooking in. Mama Ji's nailed it in this regard.

I'd definitely come back if I'm in the area looking for good Chinese food!
author: Austin W.

description: Really fun and good place. A little bit of something special for every one: authentic spicy Sichuanese dishes, dim sum for lunch, appetizers and some dim sums all day long, Belgian beer. It's diverse place with a diverse menu and loved by the neighborhood. Highly recommend! Parking is hard (expected in this neighborhood).
author: Dilys S.

description:
I have been to MaMa Ji's twice now and have enjoyed my meal and experience both times. Their menu is EXTENSIVE so come hungry and try a bit of everything! 

I believe my favorite so far has been the soup dumplings, the egg rolls, and the pork buns! Pro tip: grab some of their tea! It comes in an adorable container and is delightful.
author: Caitlin A.

description: We just ate an over priced (50.00 for two entres and one appetizer- no drinks) meal which left us queasy.  We usually love Chinese food, but the tofu fish dish was a slimey , mushy mess that we ended up paying for with a trip to the toilet soon afterwards.
author: Alan W.

description: living off the food coma nostalgia I've had since dining here 2 years ago. You might have to wait, but you have to wait everywhere in San Francisco. Szechuan pork and a few different dim sum for the win.
author: Nomis A.

description:
Finally a Chinese place that means it when it says it is spicy.    Mama Ji,s is where I go every weekend for top notch dim sum.   I love the shrimp with pea spouts and Shanghai dumpling.   The country French shrimp will make you break out in a sweat.    All the dishes have excellent flavor and if not hot enough there is a house made chili sauce to add a little more heat.     

The also feature a decent wine list and selection of draft beers 

This is my go to place
author: John B.

description:
I really enjoy MaMa Ji's. I've walked and driven past it several times and never thought to stop. It always looked super crowded with the line out the door. Well, about a month ago, when it was a quiet night, I went there with a coworker and now I am definitely a fan. I have been back about half a dozen times.

The staff is friendly, the food arrives incredibly quick, and it is some of the best szechuan food I have ever had. Everything is incredibly fresh and the flavors are amazing. 

The place is small and when crowded, can be a bit loud. Parking is definitely not easy around the restaurant. 

The only other drawback is that it is pretty pricey. So I can't go every week (as much as I would like to!) but maybe once every few weeks.

If you haven't tried it yet, find a quiet night and check it out! Amazing stuff!
author: Chris D.

description:
Everyone was so kind and wanted to make everything perfect! The food came out really fast which was great because we were very hungry. My dad was a little overwhelmed with how spicy the wings were! Perfect if your a super spicy person. If you come here definitely try the sauces especially the sweet and sour sauces.
The Best part was the selection of what to get was so easy because their menu includes spicy things, sour things,sweet things, plain things and so much more!
I really recommend this place.
author: Sophia S.

description: Bland. Bland. Bland. Ordered the chow mein with beef and it was the most flavorless chow mein I have ever had. Literally no seasoning at all and if they used oyster or soy sauce, zero trace on the taste buds. The Chongqing chicken was also on the flavorless side with a lot of tongue numbing heat. It would have been fine if there had been another dimension of flavor aka salt to the mix, but this was a horrible experience. Will not dine again.
author: Connie N.

description:
Review for their take out:

Food was very mediocre. Ordered the soup dumplings, Szechuan beef, chicken chow mein, and fried rice. Only the soup dumplings were good. Everything else was average and bland. Felt like we were eating Panda Express. Maybe their dim sum is better than main dishes but caviar didn't have most of the items on the menu available.
author: Laura D.

description:
I think I understand now, after 4 or 5 visits over a fairly long period, why Mana Ji's has a downward trend in stars. 

Call me crazy, but the portion sizes have reduced. The Ants Climbing Trees dish was definitely smaller with a seemingly slight drop in quality of the meat from tonight compared to a few years ago.

Dishes appeared at the table like random falling leaves with the appetizers arriving well after the last entree was dropped.

The taste and quality was okay but in my estimation should be about 30% cheaper. Not that the bill was expensive. It just wasn't commensurate with the quality. 

We had both the dry beef and the dry chicken with beans. The chicken was good but the cut of beef left something to be desired. Again, passable but not stellar.

Finally, they only take a maximum of 2 cards and when our party of 6, reduced from 4 cards to 2, the waiter returned having charged it all to one card. Exasperating.
author: Bulldog W.

description: Totally legit Cantonese food in the Castro.  The people are super nice too.  Oh and they even have dim sum.  I'm coming back for sure.
author: James C.

description:
Okay I get it. Weekday lunch is the best time to come here. Xiao long bao was sublime & a fair price. These dumplings had the perfect amount of soup inside. The Noodle with bean paste I'm told is the bomb, too. It comes with fresh sliced cucumber & your choice of proteins.

4 stars instead of 5 because the beer selection is not great. No Asian beers at all, & I don't think heavy microbrews, ales or wheat beers compliment this food. At least offer Tsing Tao.

The service was much better this time, too. Mama Ji's nephew seems to be getting the hang of it (even though he was about 20 mins late for his shift.)

I will def come back for lunch.
author: Scott F.

description: Lunch today so expensive and no service and I order  shrimp pepper it's very old  not fresh at all because I know so and  I eat out every day and over cook it's was $6.50 for that? I was sitting out and wait for someone to come by check with me but no one does and I don't care about $22 but it's was not very good for lunch for $22  and that shrimp bepper it's was old and over cooked.. I very disappointed  I would not going back this place to paid $22 for lunch not happy with food and no service. I been there before many times to eat  and food always and I was happy after but today is very bad .
author: Tony T.

description:
This place was a huge disappointment.  Growing up on dim sum I guess my expectations are too high.  

Shrimp Rice noodle roll which is my favorite dish because of the sweet soy sauce was ok.  The sauce was basically regular soy sauce not sweet at all.  The Hargow was decent with chewy wrapper.  Other dumplings were very underwhelming.  Will most likely not be eating here again.
author: Jay H.

description: The food here is very well prepared! Every time I come here I always want to order more, but am usually stuffed. Great for sharing with friends! I often try not to tell people about this little gem. But find myself obligated to share.
author: Cory T.

description: Great ambiance, simple elegant decor. Yummy food! Vegetarian pot sticker and spicy noodles were flavorful and fresh. My husband's pork buns and lotus leaf sticky rice was nice also. They open at 10:30 in Sunday not 9:30
author: Nils H.

description: Very rude people, especially the lady answering the phones. My take out order wasn't even started when I showed up. They told me to go away for 10 minutes and come back. That's unacceptable.
author: Mike R.

description:
Three of us came here for dinner. We were at the door at 5:30 p.m. when it opened because no reservations are taken.
We started with Shanghai dumplings which were delicious.
For our main course, we had fish fragrant pork, kung pao chicken and Chinese broccoli with garlic.
Two of us thought the pork was too hot while all of us liked the kung pao chicken.
But our favorite was broccoli with garlic. I was far more tasty than American broccoli.
So be careful what you order - some dishes are very hot. And order the broccoli - there is enough for three or four people.
author: Philip C.

description: We went here with Dim Sum in mind.  This is not your traditional dim sum place so the selection was not huge and a little twist on everything from traditional but the quality and freshness was great.  We really enjoyed everything.  The prices were reasonable as well.
author: Amanda L.

description: Had the most amazing lunch here in SF. Loved the dumplings, fish, and green beans. Mama Ji comes over to your table and makes the dining experience feel very homely. Loved the authentic food and 100% recommend.
author: Aaina P.

description:
I ordered dim sum & some wok dishes from MaMa Ji's through Caviar several times and have to say, the food was pretty mediocre. 

The dim sum:
--shrimp dumpling (3/5): the dumpling skin was pretty sick and the shrimp inside tasted okay
--shumai (2.5/5): I don't like their shumai at all. The pork was really dry, old and flavorless. When I asked for some dipping sauce, MaMa Ji's just put some standard soy sauce packets within. 
--steamed BBQ buns (3.5/5): the buns were okay but the ratio between the BBQ pork and the buns were off--wait too little BBQ pork
--spareribs w/ black bean sauce (2.5/5): the spareribs did not taste fresh at all from the two times I ordered and it also lacked flavor. 

Wok dish:
--fish fragrant eggplant (3/5): first of all, the dish was overly oily even when I requested for less oil. Besides, the flavor of the overall dish was out of balanced--a bit too sour & sweet. Won't recommend it at all.
--Mapo Tofu (3.5/5): it was okay but the dish was too oily. It felt like they just dumped half jar of spicy oil on top. 

I personally have never been into the restaurant. Just from the delivery food experiences, I won't go to the restaurant in person. There are so many much better Chinese restaurants in the city.
author: Clare L.

description:
What a great place for weekend dim sum. It's not going to bustle and hustle the way you might like - no room for carts here - but they are friendly, fast, and delicious. The highlights for me are the steamed pork buns, cilantro shrimp dumplings, and the spicy cold noodles. I always order the Shanghai soup dumplings even though the ones here tend to fall apart too quickly; I have low standards for personal appearance and I'll eat them as messily as I must. If I come late enough for dinner I'll always get pea leaves with garlic, then I'll have trouble deciding between clay pot chicken, ma po tofu, and the hot-and-numbing fish. 

Sign in on the clipboard outside if there's a line, but show up a little early or a little late on the weekend and you're likely to get a seat right away. If you come for dinner on a hot day, try to grab a table out front. 18th St can get a bit loud, but it's still a nice place to sit with a bowl of hot and sour soup while the evening cools you off.

Fair warning to beer drinkers: if you insist on Tsingtao or Asahi to compliment your dumplings, you're out of luck, as they only serve Belgian brews here. Their selection is fantastic, though, and you should probably try one even if you wanted a basic lager instead.
author: Alex L.

description: Where do you find good Dim Sum in San Francisco? Go to Yelp and take a gamble on one of the many places located in the city. We chose MaMa Ji's because (1) it was located in the tourist spot known as the Castro District and (2)-the reviews were generally excellent on Yelp. We were not disappointed! We arrived on a Friday evening over Labor Day weekend and were seated immediately. The restaurant is quite small but charming and we were seated at the window which I loved. We ordered dumplings, sweet and sour soup, noodles, and quite a bit more. It was all delicious, fresh, and filling. The price was reasonable and the service was excellent. When we were ready to leave around 8pm we saw how crowded it had become and just how popular this restaurant really is. Take-out is also an option. We took an Uber and I'm glad we did because I didn't see any parking. Recommended!!
author: Vincent Artemio E.

description:
I've been wanting to check out this spot for a long time! I read an article once that had  interviews with various chefs in SF and they asked the chefs what their favorite meal was in the city. One chef said that the steamed fish with chilis was his favorite, so of course I had to try! 

Their portion sizes were huge! I don't know what other reviewers are talking about when they complain about the size of the dishes. We ordered 4 things for two and that was way too much. No regrets though, I was so excited to try everything that I couldn't help myself. 

Vegetarian spicy cold noodles were excellent. Definitely on the spicy side so watch out! Noodles were the perfect size and density. The sauce was the right consistency so it actually soaked into the noodles. Loved it

Shrimp and chive dumplings were perfect. This was my bf favorite dish! Texture was great and the portion size was extremely generous.

Vegetarian potstickers came 3 per order. They were very flavorful, however I usually like more of a crispier texture. 

Steamed fish with Hunan chili sauce was lovely. Large pieces of fish and tofu in a delicious sauce. The dish was so huge we probably could've just shared this with some rice. 

This unassuming restaurant also has a surprisingly nice beverage list. I always appreciate when hole in the wall mom and pops places care about the whole dining experience, which should include the beverages that they provide for their guests as well. 

Good job Mama Ji's! We'll be back soon
author: Tatiana C.

description:
Dim sum before 10am?  Sure!  

Sadly, our 2016 visit had to come to an end.  The big decision of the day for me was naturally where to eat!  A few restaurant names were thrown at us from our local friend.  Our only restrictions were that it had to be close to our hotel, and we needed to be finished by 12 noon in order to head to SFO.  I was not about to waste this meal on breakfast as I feel it can be easily made at home.  The name Mama Ji's was mentioned, so I hopped on Yelp to check out their pics and menu.  I was a little turned off by what I saw, but you know what?  I'm glad we tried them.  

ATMOSPHERE:
The simple eatery is in the middle of a residential area in the Castro, with regular table seating and a few outdoor sidewalk seats.  It's not a traditional Chinese restaurant by any means.  No gaudy chandeliers, no big floor vases, not a big dining room at all.  Quaint, simple and clean.

Because we came in on a Sunday morning just before 10am, we were the only ones in there.  By the time we left an hour later, the place was jam packed!  

MENU:
Dim sum items though no cart, dumplings, rice rolls, steamed buns, noodles, soups,vegetable dishes, chicken/pork/beef dishes, dessert, teas, wine, beer.

A nicely printed order paper inside the menus are used to mark down your items.

FOOD:
Pan Fried Pot Sticker - Though they're listed under the deep fried category on the menu, they we actually steamed and pan fried the traditional way.  The 3 gyoza were on the larger size, stuffed plump with pork and shrimp, and were nicely finished with crisp bottoms.  Went perfect with the bottle of dark vinegar on the table.

Shrimp Stuffed Mushrooms - 3 big mushrooms caps were stuffed with a heaping shrimp mixture and sat in a pool of a mildly sweet & savory sauce.  Nice and light.

Pork Shumai - One of my favorite dim sum items were tasty as expected here.  The 4 pieces of pork mixture encased in a won tun shell were nicely steamed and flavorful.

Noodle with Chili Bean Paste - Yowza, this was absolutely orgasmic!  The noodles were a thick chow mein style, simply boiled, then topped in a thick, brown chili bean paste gravy that consisted of ground pork, frozen peas and carrots, garlic, and jalapeños.  Maximum savoriness and extremely delicious, and not spicy.  Highly, highly recommended.

Shanghai Dumplings - These 3 little dumplings sat in mini baking aluminum pans that were steamed with a pork mixture and were very juicy when biting into them.  Be mindful of geyser-like squirts lol!

BBQ Pork Rice Roll - Similar to a look funn dish, or what I refer to as Chinese burritos.  The big rice rolls were stuffed with char siu and bits of cilantro (yuck for me), steamed, sliced, and covered in a thin, savory brown sauce.  Delish!!!!

Steamed Golden Lava Buns - The only disappointment of our meal, IMO anyway.  I'm a fan of Chinese custard tarts, but because they weren't available, we thought we'd try this as the menu lists it as "flowy egg custard".  I knew they weren't tarts but knew I'd get that custard flavor that I love.  What came were 3 white steamed buns with a yellow dot marked on the top.  Tore off a piece, and this thick yellow liquid poured out.  It would've been good but the liquid custard was super gritty like unbaked custard.  Yuck.  Pass!

SERVICE:
The female worker who was possibly the owner was friendly, and food service was quick.

OVERALL:
Nice menu, tasty food, good prices.
author: Vince N.

description: I'm so lucky that I love so close to this place.  Their food is very good but if you don't like spicy make sure you let them know b/c we ordered our food to be medium spicy and we were burning.
author: Parastoo E.

description:
Was super excited to try MaMa Ji's as it's in a quaint location that is ultra convenient along the walk between my apartment and the Castro. Not to mention there is generally a solid crowd and often a table wait. So my girlfriend and I decided to give it a whirl with already high expectations. 

Upon arrival we were immediately seated at one of the last remaining two tops.

Detailed below are our thoughts on each item ordered.

Sichuan Beef - Standard, what you would expect at any Chinese restaurant. Nothing to write home about.

Shanghai Dumplings - Found to be rather on the larger side. Was a complete mouthful with each dumpling. As I find dumplings are intended to be consumed in one bite, this made it rather difficult to enjoy.

Chongqing Chicken - And now for the chicken. It was bizarre. It tasted very chemically. My honest thought, is after the chicken had been plated in the kitchen, the cook turned to the right or left to grab something accidentally knocking over a bottle of 409 or Windex which emptied in to the plate. The bottle fell to the ground which when the cook turned back around they were none the wiser. It was then expedited and served to our table. In reality we of course know this is not the case and our only conclusion is that the peppercorns were creating the strong and very distinct flavor. But it was definitely something we couldn't shake or get past.

Regarding the service, MaMa Ji was our primary server and she was extremely pleasant and friendly. We give her 5 stars. The other staff on hand that night was quite good as well. 

We wanted so bad for this place to hit a home run but were a bit disappointed in a few areas. Maybe we'll give it another shot sometime. That remains to be seen.
author: Lee M.

description: I'm a self-confessed soup dumpling addict, and while the dumplings here were by no means terrible, I was very underwhelmed. The seaweed salad might more accurately be labeled a "kelp salad".  The kelp had the texture and appearance of pickled jalapeños that had been julienned, but tasted more like Ocean Beach.  The sake was good, and the service was fine, but for a place that often makes the list of must-try soup dumpling establiments, I'm left wondering WHY?
author: Whitney P.

description:
Ever since I left the city I've been dreaming about Mama Ji's and trying to find a dim sum place near me that even comes close to the quality of this place. 

Upon initial impression, it's a little chaotic trying to find a table since it looks like the staff is all working together to host, serve, bus, and run. But once you're settled in, the rest takes care of itself. It was so so so noisy inside (hey, it's a popular place, what else can you say?) but luckily it was a nice day and we nabbed a spot outside.

We ordered the pork shrimp shumai, pea sprout shrimp, Shanghai dumpling, shrimp dumping, fried potsticker, bbq pork bun, tofu and shrimp, and the sesame balls. All of it was amazing but our favorite was probably the pea sprout shrimp dumpling and Shanghai dumpling. The pea sprout has such fresh and flavored shrimp with the perfect crunch in the pea sprouts. The Shanghai dumpling was presented in a cute little tin and wasn't too full of liquid for us to eat right away. 

This is a must-try spot! I know the next time I visit the city I'll be back faster than you can say 'dim sum!'
author: Sierra F.

description:
The service is alright--abrupt but friendly and efficient. It reminded me of being back in Asia a little. The Xiao long bao (Shanghai dumpling) was amazing. They give good portions and it was all really tasty and fairly affordable for SF. 10/10 will return again. 

NOTE: Shu Mai ONLY SERVED DURING DAYTIME.
author: Bryan K.

description: Supreme dumplings! Nice space with interesting art, great food, tea and beer and wine, nice service, right by Castro.
author: Rob R.

description:
When we went here for first time for Dim sum, it was party for 4. We thought the portion was too small for the price. Food was good though, you can get better Dim sum elsewhere but getting good Asian in Castro is tough. 
Then, we came back as a couple. We love it!
It's hard to go to dim sum as a couple since: A. You would get too much food. B. You have to pay and order like stupid. However, this place allow you to get good bite size of things that you like and a bit of this and that.
author: Richard W.

description: Love Mama Ji's for the hot wings.  The best hot wings that I ever tasted.  My friend and I drove all the way from San Mateo to eat at Mama Ji's.  I had thought that Bon Chon was the best at chicken wings.  I was wrong.  I ordered rice, chicken wings and pot stickers.  So filling.  This is the best chicken wings I have ever tasted.  I will be back.  I will say that this place does get really busy and there is a wait and parking can be a little hard to find because it is in the Castro area.  Price point is about $8 to $12 bucks per dish.  I will be back for sure!
author: Alice T.

description: Mama Ji's is tucked away down 18th Street, a few blocks off the main Castro offering of restaurants and shops. There's an offering of many authentic Sichuan dishes and dim sum. Fast service, spicy food, would go back.
author: Jonathan W.

description:
Weird that I used to go to yoga in the same block for years and never noticed this place before. But my sister knew about it and we decided to go for Saturday Brunch.

We showed up around 11am. What WAS weird was that there were about 10 folks waiting outside and a sign up list to get in. BUT when we did get called to enter the place was only 1/2 full. Not sure if they were managing the kitchen output or what. 

We ordered several things - it has been 2 weeks since I went here and I forget everything we ordered (I remember sesame balls, soup dumplings, shrimp dumplings, some fried pork dumplings, and a fair bit more stuff), - I do know that I LOVED the pumpkin buns filled with red bean paste.

I really appreciated they were NOT stingy with the ice in our glasses (what is it with SF restaurants these days that are so stingy with the ice in the ice water?)
author: Amy W.

description:
Super sweet service. Mama Ji is awesome.
One of her waiters was a bit frazzled when we said we were a group of 12. But $3OO Bill later and we were all very content.
We originally went for dim sum and were sad to find out they don't have many options for dinner. The soup dumplings they do have, are decent. broth is yum, not to doughy but some were left steam a bit longer.
They have these AMAZING lava buns which is a egg custard. careful because it's hot and shoots out. But SO yummy. I have 1 and wanted a whole order to myself.
The rest of the fried rice, chow mein and chicken wings were pretty yummy. the sauce on the wings is everything. spicy, so be careful.
Overall pretty good place. I could see a lot of to-go orders. I'd come back.
author: francis c.

description:
Yummy Yumm Yumm!!

What a great neighborhood chinese joint! My friend and I went here on the saturday night of pride. It's a little bit off the strip from Castro so it was full, but my friend and I were able to get a seat. I got the soup dumplings and the spicy chicken wings.

It was delicious! I really liked my experience at MaMa Ji's. Their hours are optimal and are open basically all day everyday. It's great! I don't know if they do delivery or anything like that, but their food is fantastic.

There are so many vegetarian options as well, which was great for my friend. The place doesn't have that much seating but i highly recommend the food.

Parking is street parking, per usual.

Nice service. NIce food. Definitely will be coming back!
author: Bori B.

description: So disappointed with the quality of food here. This is a neighborhood restaurant and one wants it to succeed. The pot stickers are clearly frozen and dripping and with oil when served. The fish was swimming in what tasted like old oil. Expensive, stale and reheated food. What's worse is the the service is unbelievably poor - it took several requests to get a proper spoon.
author: Vibha B.

description:
I am a big fan of Sichuan food and Mama Ji's was spot on. We went around Noon on Monday and were able to get a table for 4 easily.

Must orders:
- Numbing fish. I'm still dreaming about it! Only order if you can tolerate spice and ma la.
- Shanghai soup dumpling - Cutely served on little foil bowls and yum!
- Pork ribs in black bean sauce
- Kung pao chicken

I wasn't crazy about the ma po tofu, this dish did not have enough garlic or spice, was lacking leeks, and had peas - all in all just not what I was expecting. 

For dimsum- All the shumai and dumplings were on point and standard fare.
author: Amri O.

description:
This is a great spot for some fast easy food before a night in the Castro.

The place can get noisy and super busy but that makes it fun!

It easy comfort food spicy if you want it.
author: Thatcher H.

description:
A solid dumpling spot - you're going to spend around double versus one of the classic Richmond spots but the location can't be beat for a brunch spot on a nice weekend. They have a few outdoor tables but the indoor ambiance is... meh. 

What to order:
Ants Climbing Trees
Soup dumplings
Pork buns
Shrimp and chive dumplings 
Wings
author: Brooke N.

description:
Had late Dim Sum lunch on a Saturday afternoon. Restaurant was half full. Beautiful day so ate at outdoor table.

Had spicy cold noodles, shanghai dumplings, shrimp and cilantro dumplings, shrimp rice roll dumplings.

Everything was fresh and flavorful, service was fast.
author: Annette P.

description:
Actual rating: 3 1/2 stars

Legit dimsum coming from someone who's grown up on it. Tried the shrimp dumplings (har gau), pork dumplings (siu mai), the sticky rice wrapped in lotus leaf (lo mai gai), the pan fried turnip cakes (lo baak gou), the stuffed eggplants (yeung ngai gwa), the shrimp noodle wrap (har cheong), the fried shrimp balls (haa yuen, and the soup dumplings (siu long bao). All the dimsum dishes passed in my book.

This place was also listed as a Szechuan restaurant, so we decided to order the Szechuan cold noodles. Wasn't too impressed. The sauce that coated the noodles had a gritty texture and a bitter taste.

My friends and I came around lunch time and noticed there were some unoccupied tables.  One of the staff members told us to add our names onto the waitlist. I thought that was a bit strange considering the unoccupied tables. 

Overall, legit dimsum, will pass on the Szechuan for next time, and be prepared to put your name down on the waitlist.
author: Nina Z.

description:
They must not have recognized me.  

What other explanation can there be for being a yelper who received good service here?  

Judging from the reviews, it appears that yelpers have problems with Mama Ji's service levels.  On a recent weekday night around 9 p.m. this place was packed with boisterous diners, me among them.  There were two servers, each about whom I have no complaints, and even MaMa Ji herself stepped up to my table to ask how everything was.  So service?  They've got it covered, despite what one might read elsewhere on yelp.  

Food?  They've got that covered too.  

I was prepared not to feel fondly about MaMa Ji's after reading several non-rave reviews from shortly after they opened but I admit to being completely won over by my meal here.  Whatever kinks they opened with appear to have been ironed out, as the crowd and the steamy good food attest to.  

An assortment of small dishes (spicy cucumbers [$5.95], crispy spring rolls [$4.75], excellent pork pot stickers [$4.75]) was followed by a fiery dish of Pickled Long Beans with Ground Pork ($10.95).  So fiery, in fact, that more rice was required just to get through it.  MaMa Ji doesn't lie; when the menu says this Sichuan cuisine is fiery take note.  Fiery and good.    

An eating establishment in the Castro that's alive and hopping on a weekday night?  Good service?  Really good food?  I'm a yelper and I experienced all of that at MaMa Ji's.  There's probably better and cheaper versions of this food to be found elsewhere in the City but when this is where you are, this is the place to go.  I doubt you'll be disappointed.  

MaMa Ji, I'm certain I'll be seeing you again.
author: Tracey A.

description:
Small dim sum restaurant with yummy dim sum. Location is kind of far from BART station, so we had to take uber. 
Good flavor, some very spicy, rather expensive. 2 adults and 3 small kids, we spent $100 for dim sum only.
Nice place to try!
author: Toshie L.

description: Just returned from dinner on a holiday night.   Was greeted by a young wait person that was friendly and cheerful.   We ordered the house clay pot and cumin  lamb.   Both dishes were well prepared and to our requested spiciness.   The rice was fluffy and freshly made.   For a holiday, customers were coming in continuously and also many takeout orders.   Good to see that there is a excellent Chinese restaurant in the Castro/Noe Valley/Mission area of the City.  My recent meal at  Red Jade and Eric's both on Church Street were very bad.
author: James J.

description:
The Shanghai chicken with eggplant was excellent.  I ordered "mild" and my nose still ran a bit!  They have great Belgian beers--the Delirium Tremens was A-Ok!  With an alcohol content of just over 7% --it helped wash down the spiciness of the dish.   The Lucifer was over 8% alcohol.  Too bad that they were $10 each--yikes!
We sat in the window and started with the Shanghai seafood dumplings.  After soaking the julienned ginger in a bit of vinegar, we dunked our dumplings in and enjoyed every bite.  Great dim sim!
The pork chow mein was excellent too.
Kind of pricey.  
Friendly service but on the slow side.
Dinner was just over $77.00.
author: Thomas D.

description: My bf and I just went to this restaurant for the first time last night! Everything we got was absolutely delicious - from the shanghai dumplings to the lava buns to the beef chow fun and eggplant/chicken. Would definitely come back & recommend!
author: Marianna L.

description:
Surprisingly tasty dim sum, if a bit on the pricier side. Apparently, we weren't the only ones to know of this place, because the wait on Sunday for lunch was about an hour! We ended up ordering a wide assortment, and I will say that pretty much everything was spot on. 

Of note were: shu mai (plump, moist, chock full of shrimp and shiitake mushrooms and pork goodness), shrimp dumplings with pea shoots (large in size), fried shrimp balls (these were the smallest I have ever seen, but fried perfectly and not oily at all!), garlic and ginger sauteed gai lan (tender and perfectly cooked, with a nicely light ginger sauce), haw gow (tasty with a lot of shrimp filling), beef chow fun (really good and not too salty or oily which often happens). 

I did not try the chive and shrimp dumplings or the xiao long bao, since I was stuffed, but my friends had no complaints. Nor did I try the dessert custard buns with condensed milk and egg, but they were appropriately oozy and hot upon arrival. 

The only dishes I didn't think were up to snuff given the price were the shrimp in rice noodles with the soy sauce, because the rice noodles were SO mushy and fell apart at the touch. I also thought that the vegetarian egg rolls, while better than most, were still a bit boring. I wish that they would try for the Shanghai style egg rolls which have a much tastier filling, but I do understand that they are a restaurant that specializes in Szechuan-style cuisine. 

Service was speedy and responsive, especially for a Chinese restaurant. I think it's pretty obvious that this is a family run establishment, as the serving staff was not formal at all. It helped that we could speak Mandarin. I would not hesitate to return to try some of the other dishes. 

Another vote in their favor in terms of authenticity? There were actually Chinese people waiting in line amongst the hipster SF crowd that you normally see when there is a wait outside a restaurant.
author: Leslie H.

description:
Tried this place after recommendations from some friends and we were around the Castro anyways so, why not. After reading some reviews i was kind of excited to try the food here. Though i didn't get to try all the meat dishes i wanted i tried enough to come with a verdict of the food here.

My vegetarian friends and i ordered the mama ji's country shrimp, kung pao tofu, shrimp and chives dumplings, chinese broccoli and fish 
fragrant tofu. The ingredients tasted really fresh and cooked well so the veggies it was cooked in was not soggy but still crunchy i.e. the celery in the country shrimp. Our favorite dish was the kung pao tofu (recommended for vegetarians) and the shrimp and chive dumplings.

The mama ji's special country shrimp, though well cooked was overly salty for my liking. Kung pao tofu was just perfect along with the shrimp and chive dumpings and i highly recommend these dishes if you come by. The fish fragrant  tofu was our least favorite dish as the bamboo shoots over powered the dish and it had a kind of prune after taste to it. The chinese broccoli with garlic wasn't as flavorful as we'd expected it to be and i wished they included hoisen sauce to go along with it.

I later found out that this was a Szechuan place and wishes we ordered the soup instead maybe one day. All in all the food was cooked perfectly but the price they charged and the portion you get was definitely not worth it i mean the chinese broccoli alone was almost $10. The service, though great in the beginning they became inattentive once our food was served.
author: Alex T.

description: Nothing special at all and the place is DEAFENING. Even though the restaurant was not full, the sound was awful. If the meal had been good, it might have been bearable.  My noodles were drowning in soupy mix, cold, and not spicy at all as advertised.  To make matters worse, the staff propped the front door open and it was very cold and drafty.  We asked them to close it and they did....for about five minutes, then opened it again. Never understand why restaurants do this if is obviously cold to their customers. Food way below average.  Won't go here again, my ears and taste buds can't take it. It's also a Chinese restaurant with no Chinese beer! How is that possible?
author: Osama B.

description: Terrific dim sum and other delights. Particular favorites are the turnip cakes and the fried pumpkin balls, which I've never found elsewhere. Authentic and well-made. Beware, they don't dumb down the spicy, if a dish says it's hot, it is. They also have an unusually well curated list of beers, mostly Belgian, that pair far better than you'd guess with the food.
author: Michael A.

description: Best gay food spot in the city! Me and girlfriend literally come here at least 4 times a month. The service is great the food is amazing, it's bursting with flavor. I love the kung pau tofu it's so spicy and flavorful. Favorite Chinese food Place to go to off tops!
author: Tasha B.

description:
All the different dumplings are a must! The entrees are great as well but I would definitely order as much as possible from the appetizer menu. 

Surprisingly they have a decently large German draft beer selection although I wasn't a fan of a couple of them. Not sure if it makes sense for the type of restaurant.
author: Craig P.

description: This is the place to go for Dim Sum in Castro on the weekend. They are freshly made per order. Staffs are friendly.
author: Supa S.

description:
We ate here tonight, 6/5/2017, and I was excited because I had not had Chinese food for several months.  We've been here several times before and was always satisfied. 

Here are the issues:

First they brought our entree before our appetizers.  When we commented they brought our appetizers, pan fried pot stickers, which were good. They then brought the same entrees back which were now cold.  

Both entrees were so salty that they were essentially inedible.  When I  commented they apologized but did nothing, they did not even offer to remake the entrees  Rice was $1.75.  I asked for fried rice, which was not on the menu. When I got my check we were charged $13.75 for the rice which seemed expensive.  We typically eat Chinese food from Red Jade on Church Street where fried rice is $8.75.   

Overall it was really disappointing and they absolutely did not seem to care about making anything right.   

I will not be back and I recommend that you do NOT eat here.  There are many other excellent  options in the Castro.
author: Mark W.

description:
Rude!
Will not return to Mama Ji's, I can find Dim Sum better else where.
The lady at the register lied in my face and said she could not take two forms of payment.
Went over to another guy working the register and he did it with no problem.
author: Tiffany F.

description: Very fresh dim sum. I ordered the steamed and fried shrimp dumplings,  both were very good. I also tried the hot and sour soup which was delicious but was still quite spicy, even though I asked for less spicy.
author: Nelly M.

description:
I've been eating here for four years (since they first opened) and I still find them to be the best. I like to take some bad reviews with people just being unreasonable.

 If you've been here on a Sunday or Saturday morning you'd know they are incredibly busy so it can take a moment. 

But what shines is always the food. I have yet to get anything I didn't think was fantastic. Including the dinner menu, the steamed fish with tofu is my favorite.
author: Jourdain D.

description:
The perfect time to go is 5pm, (we went on a Saturday and was able to be seated).  By 6:15pm, it was packed and gets noisy because of no acoustical dampening.

Ordered the Shanghai Seafood Dumplings, (shrimp & pork).  I was surprised to see they were those dumplings with soup inside in a small foil tin.  I'm not a fan of those kind of dumplings but I really liked these, they were really fresh, the wrapper was made that day and was really doughy, (which I like).  There were 3 in an order.

I was surprised to see the portions were good, (slightly above medium).  I was also surprised to see how spicy everything was, (I thought they may tone down the spice being in the Castro but no).  I like spicy & you have your choice of mild, medium or spicy and we went with spicy.  They weren't messing around, this is for-real Asian spicy!  

Got Noodles with Chile black bean sauce.  The noodles seemed homemade & fresh and the sauce was very flavorful, had a hint of sweet that offset the spicy.  Ordered Szechuan Beef, which was o.k, the beef was tender & fresh with bell peppers and onions.  Per the Waitstaff recommendation we ordered Chongqing Chicken which were small, fried pieces of chicken, (like popcorn chicken), with chiles and numbing peppercorns.  The chicken was good, also had a sweet/spicy taste to it, but they weren't messing around with the numbing peppercorns, there was about 2 tablespoons of them!  Good & interesting but next time I'll order the clay pot chicken & mushrooms.

Will definitely come back at an off-hour, every thing they have there is so fresh.  About $40 per person with tip for this dinner which is reasonable to me.
author: Johnnie N.

description:
What is with the hype? My friend and I left with numb tongues and runny noses because our dishes had an obsessive amount of Szechuan Chili.

Mapo Tofu: Look at the photo attached. Spoonfuls of Szechuan chili oil... It has a somewhat bitter flavor and numbs your lips/tongue. Definitely a negative when overused. 

Triple C chicken: Crumbs of fried batter and chicken. Batter is leaking with oil. Chicken is dry and tough. Other than Szechuan chili flavor, it is very bland with no seasoning. 

Potstickers: I am shocked that they're somewhat known for their dumplings/potstickers. The skin is thick and doughy. Outsides were extremely oily. Low pork filling ratio. Worst potsticker I've ever had. And 5$ for 3 pieces??

They seem to have cool imported beers but price is steep for 11$ a glass.

Thanks but no thanks, Mama Ji.
author: Mandy L.

description: It's very hard for me writing a bad review with the restaurant i like. I really love the food here. My bf and I always here many times. But you know we got the same problem many times. Many times they forget about the food that we orders and tea. And no one say anything or "sorry" to us. And today it happened again. Same problem and the restaurant wasn't busy at all. I felt like why always us. If you can't remember what the customer order, why don't you just write it down. It's very easy. Right?
author: Gay M.

description:
Love this place. A great neighborhood Chinese restaurant. 

My favorites are the spicy cucumber salad, pan fried potstickers, and egg rolls for appetizers. My favorite shareable dishes are the chicken chow mein, hot and sour soup, broccoli beef, chicken with asparagus, and the fried chicken with green beans (its more like a sauteed chicken vs kfc "fried" chicken) 

Everything is very tasty. There are always very fast with take-out orders. 

It is a very convenient location. I'd definitely recommend the spicy cucumber salad. DELICIOUS!
author: Chris S.

description:
I don't go outside of the Avenues much when I'm craving dim sum. When I saw Mama Ji's on Caviar, the roommate and I decided to order lunch delivery on Sunday, October 11th. We placed our order around 12:15pm and it arrived a little over an hour later. Prices below are what I paid through Caviar. Looking at their online menu, I believe the prices are the same.

*Shumai: pork shrimp shumai ($4.75)
*Shanghai dumplings: contains pork ($4.75)
*Har gow shrimp dumplings: shrimp dumpling ($5.75)
*Pan fried pot sticker: pork w/ground up shrimp ($4.75)
*Dry bean curd skin roll: contains shrimp and pork ($4.75)
*Steamed spareribs with black bean sauce ($4.75)
*Sweet rice with shrimp sausage and egg wrapped in lotus leaf ($5.75)
*Handmade pull rice roll: shrimp rice roll ($8)

Overall, the dim sum was average. I enjoyed the ha gow the most as the shrimp were plump and tender. But half the shrimp fell out of their wrappers due to the take out container. They should have used plastic or something slippery instead of paper containers, so the dim sum didn't stick to the boxes. My least favorite was the lo mai gai (sweet rice wrapped in lotus leaf). It was super bland and the rice wasn't cooked enough so it wasn't really sticky. And at $8, the ha cheong (shrimp rice roll) was grossly overpriced.

I'm glad I didn't go out of my way to the Castro to try Mama Ji's as I don't think it would have been worth it. I'll just stick close to home for my dim sum fix.
author: Elena N.

description:
Delicious. Always great for takeout when I do not want to cook. 

Must get foods: spicy cucumber salad, crispy spring rolls, pan fried potstickers, hot & sour soup, and chicken chow mein.

Not a fan of their tofu. 
Typically pretty busy on the weekends with big crowds.
author: Chris S.

description: Yummy!  So, so good. Stopped in for dim sum and was delighted! A highlight of our trip to SFO!
author: Shannon K.

description: Delicious, fresh food, friendly service. Really fun spot.
author: Jonny A.

description: What a great little  neighborhood hidden gem this is. The menu is not huge, but all of the dim sum was piping hot, very fresh, and tasted like it was made from very high-quality ingredients. It's a little bit more expensive than other dim sum places that I've evening, but I don't mind at all paying extra for the quality and freshness.
author: Rob L.

description: Delicious, well prepared food served in a casual relaxed setting.  It's a neighborhood place with good service and good food.   Solid.
author: Harris A.

description:
DISAPPOINTED. 
First sign I should have picked up on it was when after being seated, the four of us only got handed three menu's. Service was inconsistent. Food portion was small for the price you pay. Don't order a glass of white wine. It tasted flat. The water glass was served dirty. The last dish never made it to the table even after two attempts were made to substitute it. "It's coming". When?
I recommended this place to my dinner mates after having read such good reviews. But guess what, it wasn't happening tonight. 
FIRST and LAST time for all of US. 
If you should ever be low on toilet paper, just go use the bathroom. You'll find plenty of them piled in there.
author: Moses C.

description: By far the best Chinese food I've tasted in a very long time. CLEAN AND FRESH. I am working in the city these days and I was craving Chinese food but without the fear of having a reaction because the food quality is poor, as well as the restaurant. The DIM SUM, was outstanding! I'm actually going there again tonight! I hope they never change this quality of food to share.
author: maryann t.

description:
So this morning I decided to try a new dim sum place. I opened the books and mama ji's came up.  I came in and it's definitely not your typical Chinese dim sum place, they have Belgian beer on draft which is awesome however I missed having the free hot tea that is usually serve at dim sum. I went ahead and ordered the meat dumplings, which was absolutely amazing, I also got the pea wrap with meat.  Up until this point everything was definitely 5 stars (even though the price was a little steep).  I ended with the egg lava bun and it was not what I was expecting,  the yolk wasn't runny, you could taste the sugar granules within the yolk , and the yolk was like a warm lump.  The shanghai dumplings seem like the thing to get here which I'll have to try.

Hopefully it was just a bad order of the lava bun.
author: Josh Giosue D.

description:
Looking for dim sum in the Castro, come to Mama Ji's. Some dishes are oily and quite spicy but you will have no trouble navigating around them. The space is clean and the service is friendly and attentive.

At $12.75 the Spicy Cold Noodles although a little difficult to mix in such a small bowl were very good. At $8.00 the BBQ Pork Rice Roll has something powdery inside that turned me off.

At $4.75 the Seared Pumpkin Cake were delicious heavy balls stuffed with a semi-sweet red bean, great for desert. At $5.75 the Shrimp Stuffed Bell Pepper has a great juxtaposition in textures and flavors. 

At $5.75 the Pea Sprouts Shrimp Dumplings with their contrasting flavors were also quite delicious. I hope you enjoy your visit here as much as we have, mmm...
author: Caesar A.

description: Best Chinese food place to go in Castro. Feel free to go after party in castro :)My favorite dish is mapo tofu with pork
author: Clancy Y.

description: Stopped in for lunch. Chow Mein was pretty terrible. Mushy, cold and almost tasteless. All for 4. They used to have good food but seems like it's slipping while prices go higher.
author: Connor B.

description:
$6 for 3 mediocre xiao long bao? $13 for green beans?

Save yourself the pain and get your greasy Chinese at Big Lantern on 16th.
author: Mark P.

description: Another good delivery.  Shrimp and chive dumplings with chili sauce, fish with chili sauce (asked for less spicy), ants climbing trees, and pea leaves with garlic.  All were good and they were generous portions - with the one exception that the ants climbing trees was really mostly cellophane noodles and didn't have a lot of meat.
author: Vivian W.

description:
This used to be my number one favorite restaurant in SF. I've lived here for three decades and I'm particular about food. I brought many friends here, including recent immigrants from China, and they said it was their favorite, too! 

But something changed. Suddenly, a little less than two years ago, maybe a year after Mama Jis had opened, the food became AWFUL! I came again, because I couldn't believe it, and again, the food was so awful I couldn't stomach it!   I tried to ask what had happened to my favorite dishes I had so loved, but got nothing but defensiveness or blank stares in response. So I quit them. So sad! 

But tonight, after almost two years, I thought I'd give it another chance. I ordered the fried pumpkin in salty duck egg yolk. The first 6 or 7 times I'd ordered it, after they'd just opened three? four? years ago, it had been divinely light, delicate, and flavorful, with a wonderful, crunchy, dry, salty batter coating the soft, delicious pumpkin inside. Tonight, the batter was thick, heavy, bland, hard, and covered with yellow slime. Bravely, I bit through it anyway, and it had ZeRO flavor, and the texture was absolutely stomach turning.  I objected and asked for my bill, and the owner? or manager came to ask what was wrong, I told her it was terrible, and she argued with me! And handed me the bill! Which I stupidly paid. But she was stupider. If I hadn't wasted $16.50 (with tip) I might not have been pissed enough to write this review. 

They lost their mojo right when they were getting so popular. It's too bad.
author: Sam W.

description:
The spicy and numbing fish is soooo friggin' good. Clean establishment. Great service, great food. Nice beer selection. Great decor.
Love it!!
author: The I.

description: I don't even like vegetables but their garlic pea leaves were utterly delicious. I ordered the cilantro shrimp dumplings and they were SSSOOOO GOOOD. Although this may be because I don't eat enough Chinese food, I've never had a dumpling with a rice-papery outside but I thought it was great and would get again. I would definitely go there again and would recommend to a friend. The serving sizes are a little small in my opinion, as I only got 4 dumplings, but I think think this is typical for this type of cuisine. It's reasonably priced, so next time I go i'll just order two servings.
author: Alexia T.

description:
There are only a few things I ever order on their menu here:
1. the dumplings (esp chive shimp)
2. the dry fried beans 
3. the shrimp & eggplant appetizer

And really we return because of #1 only. 

For a Chinese restaurant in a residential neighborhood away from Chinatown/Richmond/Sunset, the dumpling is probably as good as it gets.
author: Hua W.

description:
Mama Ji's is not perfect. But this is our go-to Chinese place. Why you ask? Let me provide some talking points.

A) Besides Mama Ji's, there isn't even a decent Chinese place on this side of the city. Where else you going to go in the Bernal / Mission / Castro area for Chinese food? Chinese Food & Donuts? Only if you enjoy explosive diarrhea.

B) Run by NICE Chinese people. This is quite a novelty for me. I usually get extremely anxious around my own people. So much so that my boyfriend refuses to go to any other Chinese restaurant with me because I naturally regress to my mother in a Chinese restaurant. Because you know - you gotta fend for yourself. ...But here, they're nice! Mama Ji herself is nice! Perhaps this is the luxury of the restaurant being in Castro. Which takes me to my next point.

C) The dim sum is pricier than say Good Luck Dim Sum in the Richmond. But people, it's dim sum in the Castro. And it's GOOOOD and very authentic. I'd say they have some of the highest quality dim sum in San Francisco. Maybe not as good as Yank Sing, but competitive. Their selection is small. But it's a small restaurant. You can tell that everything is made fresh with great ingredients. And the best part - if you go early, you can get seated right away and not have to wait an hour and a half to get berated by Chinese waiters.

Besides their dim sum, their chow mein, chow fun and string beans with beef are amazing. I have had some other dishes that I think are good, but not great. I'm Cantonese so I can speak more to their dim sum than their "numbing" dishes. 

The absolute must have - Their lava buns. Is it the best in the world? No. But considering I feel like this is something you could only get going to a very chinese dim sum place, but they have it here is amazing. So you must get it.
author: Bonnie H.

description:
I loved the restaurant that was in this spot a few years back and wasnt all that happy when it became MamaJi's. The first time I went here after the change, I had pretty mediocre dim sum as well as a bagel with lox left over from the old menu. It was bad.

Years later  (yesterday) I decided to give it another chance as it's close to my house and I love Sichuan food. Enough time to work out the kinks, right?

Right. Pretty good, in my 'hood and many of the dishes are superb. 

Get the spicy cold noodles if you're a Sichuan style food fan. It's expensive, but a large portion and really good. The shimp/eggplant dim sum are also good, as are the Har Gow. 
I also like the pork rolls, but they were pretty pricey. Yummy if you're splurging.

Skip the xlbs (called Shanghai Dumplings here)  No soup inside and the pork filling was mushy and bleh. I was also not a fan of the deep fried Meat Dumplings because they tasted like they had those icky dried shrimp inside (sooo not a fan of that strong fishy flavor.) Kid really liked those because she said the consistency was perfect, and she doesnt hate on the dried shrimp. She thought the dried shrimp flavor came from the oil they were fried in, but didnt matter where it came from for me....it was there and unwelcome.

I looked at the regular dinner menu before I left, and I'll go back to check it out;  it looks good. Yes, there is definitely better dim sum to be had in SF, but not close to my house. 
I'm so glad I gave this place another chance.
author: El B.

description: Painfully bad. Clumsy service, confusing menu, grimy feeling. Poor quality food. Unfortunate. Not much more to say - avoid.
author: Ryan B.

description:
If you are the adventurous type and want to stray off the tourist path,  you have got to go to Mama Ji's. Since I have a weakness for Dim Sum (more like an obsession),  there was no question that we had to go.  My cousin suggested we try it out after working up an appetite reacquainting myself with my city by the bay  

When we finally found parking, I was so anxious I couldn't contain myself because the reviews were really good. As we were walking up to the restaurant my coworkers were a little apprehensive because Mama Ji's is smack dab in the the Castro. It was all a little strange for them being from Texas and all.  They soon got over it when we began receiving our orders. We ordered pretty much every thing on the menu and everyone was in food bliss five minutes into our meal. 

This was the freshest, best tasting Szechuan and Dim Sum I have had in, well, forever...

This is a must visit, a destination if you will. The only drawback is that I wish this place was bigger!  As far as flavor, there is nothing bigger!
author: Rey D.

description:
Having just moved to SF from South Bay, my bf and I were excited to check out dim sum here. We ordered the below:

Chicken & Shrimp Shui Mai: Good, but just 4 pieces for $4.75. That's more than $1 a piece! 

Shrimp & Cilantro Rice Roll: Also good but not spectacular. My biggest gripe was that they barely put any sauce in! It was kind of bland and I had to dip in soy sauce instead. For $8 I expected much more. 

Pork Rib: Disappointing. This one took forever to come out and it was way too hot. I burned my tongue eating a piece. Also too fatty. I've had better.

Fried Eggplant w/ Stuffed Shrimp: I think this was the best dish we had and I liked it a lot. Only three pieces but they are pretty huge.

Overall tasty but way too overpriced. Our bill came out to be almost $30 with tax and tip and we left hungry. I think we're still spoiled by South Bay dim sum cause prices are so much cheaper and the food is better. I probably won't return.
author: Sophia H.

description: Consistently high quality Szechuan.  Best restaurant in the Castro.  Everything is delicious.  Come here for both eat-in and take-out.  Friendly staff.  They're doing a good business and deserve it!
author: W G.

description:
Absolutely one of my favorite restaurants in the city. Their Shanghai Dumplings (soup dumplings) are unbelievable. On a whim, I ordered the "Ants climbing trees," a spicy noodle dish with ground pork, and now I'm totally obsessed. Even their desserts, while simple, are lovely.

I've only ever gotten take-out, so I can't speak to the service or the cleanliness of the restaurant, but the food is outstanding. It's not your typical dim sum or Chinese restaurant by any means. I highly recommend it, especially if you like spicy food.
author: Julie B.

description: The service here is horrible. Came on a slow Sunday night, was seated right away, but waited nearly 30 minutes for server to come by. When we expressed our concern of poor service, the server mocked us -- not to mention waiting nearly an hour for our food. We will never be back and we will tell everyone to avoid this place at all costs. Go to Burma Superstar for MUCH better food and way better service.
author: Kristin S.

description:
MaMa Ji's
SF: Castro
2pm Wednesday 15th April 2015
Four Stars

Checking off places on Sara's to eat list. Mama Ji is the name of a divine character in Neil Gaiman's American Gods. I am glad to say that this dim sum restaurant was just heavenly. We enjoyed our meal outside with the pup. The black tea came in a cool container/mug. We ordered vegetarian to share. The veggie steamed buns contained mainly mushrooms. They were surprisingly delicious and flavorful. The shrimp dumplings (shumai) lacked the traditional pork flavor making it feel incomplete. The shrimp dumpling (Ha Gao) was amazing. The supple rice wrapper encased perfectly cook baby shrimp. Overall this place had great but okay service. 

Next time: soup dumplings and meat.
author: Leonard L.

description:
We ordered a hot feast of deliciousness and were not disappointed with the service , the flavors, the heat, the ambiance and so on...

go eat there...often.
author: Neil C.

description:
Didn't expect to have such good dim sum in Castro, but I was pleasantly surprised.

The prices are a little steep for certain dishes here, at least considering that it's for dim sum. For example, the shrimp rice noodle roll was $8. That was a little crazy to me, but maybe that's just my LA roots talking from being used to cheaper dim sum dishes.

Otherwise, my boyfriend and I ordered a bunch of different shumai and dumpling items on the menu, and we enjoyed everything. All of the skins were cooked well and had a great texture, and all the fillings were flavorful.

Overall, this is a great place to satisfy a dim sum craving when you're in the area and don't feel like going all the way to Inner/Outer Richmond or the Sunset.
author: Sara L.

description:
A surprisingly dependable place for real dim sum in a neighborhood that seems to lack quality dining establishments, let alone authentic ones. While it's not the bestest dim sum ever, everything on the menu is definitely legit. Stalwarts like har gow and siu mai are well-done and well-portioned, and the prices are quite decent. Service is fast and efficient, and the people who run this place are bona fide Chinese folks.

If you're from the neighborhood, this is actually a dim sum experience worth staying close to home for, instead of spending lots of time venturing elsewhere.
author: Vincent L.

description: Went to this place because they had received a Michelin Star but was very disappointed with the food. We ordered the eggplant shrimp, noodles, and the spicy fish.  The food was bland and the meats/fish were not fresh.  Definitely not recommending this place.
author: Kobe B.

description:
I basically grew up eating dim sum, about half my diet was probably shrimp dumplings and shrimp rice rolls, and I'm happy to say that this place serves dim sum that's just as good as any hole-in-the-wall shop in Chinatown or Sunset! 

We came early afternoon on a Saturday and there was a huge line of people waiting. Took about 30 minutes but after we were seated, the food came out pretty fast! 

While the prices are definitely a lot higher than what I'm used to (almost $5 for 3 shrimp dumplings?!), the dim sum was sooooooo good. Everything was so authentic, and so fresh it tasted like it was all freshly made :) 

Here's what we ordered:

Shrimp dumplings: Must get!! These are top tier dumplings and I've definitely sampled a good number of these in SF
Shrimp dumplings with pea sprouts: I saw on Yelp that these were good so instead of getting two orders of shrimp dumplings, we got one of these instead but definitely not as tasty as the normal shrimp dumplings. Would just stick to the shrimp dumplings.
Shrimp Rice Rolls: So good! The sauce is everything and the rice rolls are so soft.
Cold Spicy Noodles: Once again, the noodles tasted so fresh I swear they must make the all the dough for the dumplings/noodles in house. The taste is definitely legit Szechuan-style but pretty spicy.
Eggplant-stuffed with shrimp: This was sooooo flavorful, definitely get this. I don't even really like eggplant but this was so good!

Overall, a little pricey, but it's definitely top-quality authentic dimsum/Szechuan food. Dim sum craving satisfied!!
author: Jingxi Z.

description:
My friend recommended this place, so I turned to yelp to see what they had to offer besides dim sum. I was hoping they would have chow fun on their menu (if you know me, I lalalove chow fun. I could eat that errrryday for the rest of my life!!!!) but I didn't see any on their yelp menu or photos. Booo!  

We came here on a Saturday night. The restaurant was jam packed at the time. It was about a 20 min wait for a party of 3 (we waited outside in the cold brrrr). After being seated we were handed the menus and I scanned it...hard. What caught my eye were the shrimp dumplings and the shanghai dumplings (you know..the one with the soup inside). When I turned to the back of the menu it had a list of "Tonight's specials" and to my surprise I saw Beef Chow Fun on the list. I was so happy, like WOW it was my night! *insert crying emoji here *insert XD emoji here

Orders came out in a reasonable amount of time and we dove in.

Beef chow fun--Very nommy but was very greasy..It looked like I had lip gloss on after I was finished. It was chow fun with obstacles, I had to dodge the green onions and regular onions (I'm not a fan of either). I guess there was miscommunication with the waiter when I asked him what was in the beef chow fun and he said something about celery and I didn't want that. Anyways it had a good amount of beef, bean sprouts, and carrots which I didn't mind. I wanted ordered more but I didn't want to be the only one eating/finishing it. Plus I would've skipped into a foodcoma and I was the driver...

Shrimp dumplings--Delishness! especially with the special soy sauce that went with it. My friends and I ordered extra it was so nom nom nom.

Shanghai dumplings--It was okay. There was nothing special about them and they didn't have much soup inside. I've had the authentic shanghai dumplings in Shanghai and these were nothing close to the legit ones. The only thing they had in common was prolly the appearance. 

Overall, service was good, food was good, but parking was a BIT CHallenging! It was so bad that we were so close to not wanting to eat here anymore on the night we went. I think it took us longer to find parking than waiting and eating here. It was so RIDIC! They're located in a residential area-- we had to park about 3 blocks away. The struggle was real. Would I come here again? of course! if it's easy to get parking.
author: Vicky L.

description: Best local fresh staple for lazy or busy days. Pea shoots, salt baked shrimp, eggplant and shhrip chive dumplings and soup dumplings are among my favorites. Plus the owner is A+ asset to the neighborhood to boot! Tough hard working woman with a kind and generous heart.
author: Sean C.

description: This is my favorite Dim Sum place by far. Every time we're in the Bay Area, we start our day here. The shrimp rice roll and cilantro shrimp dumplings are THE BEST... honestly, my kids love this place so much that they would drive the 4 1/2 hours just to eat here. Mama Ji, Lily,  is the best too. She makes you feel at home.
author: Victoria B.

description: Mama Ji has become my go to place, especially for my weekend brunch, dim sum. The line usually goes quickly and I've become acquainted with the staff more and also realized that after my trip to China that they serve the numbing fish stew that I  now have an acquired taste for. Also, try the combo fried rice, seafood shumai, pot stickers, afligem, xiao long bao.
author: Sarah T.

description: I came here with five friends on a Sunday afternoon for Dimsum. The place is very small with modern white ambiance with a feel of mom & pop place. Our friends found this place randomly looking for a dim sum place in Mission. We ordered jjanmyun; hot black bean noodle dish with ground beef, carrots, peas, and cumcumber. I definitely recommend this dish, a must try :) We also ordered cold noodle dish, similar to jajjanmyun but stronger Anis seed flavor. We also ordered, Shu Mai,  shrimp dim sum, shrim & veggie dim sum, grilled green beans, turnip squares, tamale, hot grilled shortly rib, Hum Bao, Sha Long Bao, sasame balls, and other way too much food for  6 people, lol. The Sha Long Bao was surprisingly pleasant. The turnip square was the best I've tasted at a dim sum so far. There was tons of left over to go, yet our total was very reasonable. If you are looking for a dim sum place in Mission, go here :)
author: Lisa O.

description:
A couple Sundays ago, my friends and I wanted to get dim sum, but the usual Richmond spots were overflowing with people. We decided to come here since we had to get one of our friends from the Castro anyway. I wasn't sure how to feel about a restaurant with Szechuan food and Dim Sum under the same roof. That's weird. It's like having mushroom risotto and chicken tikka masala on the same menu. I like to think of myself as a pretty open minded person so I mean, why not?

Ha Gow - They were plump and filled with nicely cooked shrimp. The shrimp stuffing was underseasoned and needed more young bamboo though. Also, the skins were too tough. Most Bay Area Dim Sum places make ha gow skins too delicate, but MaMa Ji's fall on the other side of the spectrum.

Siu Mai - Not enough shrimp or shiitake. The flavor is mostly dominated by the ground pork so it could use some more balance. 

XLB - Plump and juicy. The skin wasn't too thick, and there was a good amount of broth inside. Some more ginger and green onions would help, but these weren't bad at all.

Pan Fried Radish Cake - These tasted pretty good. There was a good amount of radish, dried shrimp, and Chinese sausage mixed in. The thing that bothered me was that they didn't seem pan fried enough. They came out piping hot, but there was zero browning on the top and bottom. I'm not sure how to explain that.

Sticky Rice Wrapped in Lotus Leaf - The rice was stuffed with a good combination of pork, shiitake, and dried shrimp. I like having some Chinese sausage in there, but it's not crucial. One thing that stood out to me was that there was a plain egg yolk inside. Usually when there's an egg yolk inside the rice, you're supposed to use salted egg yolk as a flavoring agent. A plain egg yolk doesn't really add much to the rice. I don't even like sticky rice with the egg yolk, but if there's one inside, it should be salt brined. 

Fried Shrimp Balls - These were probably the best thing we had here. Thin, crispy waves of batter on the outside with juicy, tender shrimp paste on the inside. There's not much to complain about. 

We also ordered a Szechuan dish just for the heck of it. I'm a big fan of Szechuan style garlic pork belly, but the one at MaMa Ji's wasn't all that great. The pork wasn't very tender, and the sauce wasn't that flavorful. I could taste the highlighting flavors of garlic and Szechuan peppercorns, but it didn't have a strong base. Maybe it needed more soy sauce or stronger stock, but I think there are better versions elsewhere. Little Sichuan in San Mateo and Z&Y in Chinatown make great garlic pork belly and Szechuan food in general. 

Given the location, it's hard to expect MaMa Ji's to compete with more established restaurants in other parts of the city. For a place that stands out by offering this kind of food in the Castro, it's fine.
author: Nei N.

description:
Inconsistent service 
Heard about this place through a blog that gave it great reviews. 
Food is a bit pricy. We usually go to Yank Sing for dim sum but this place is even more expensive. Can you believe? And it's located in the Castro! With a smaller quantity too.
Great beer selection but also quiet expensive. $9 for a small draft beer. 
Will not be coming back.
author: Ree M.

description:
TLDR: Mom and Pop Chinese. Everything here is delicious. Especially the dim sum.

On a quick layover in San Francisco, I was finally able to try the famous Mama Ji's, recommended by my sister, who absolutely adores this place. Came here on a Monday around 11ish? And thankfully, guess no one likes Mondays because it wasn't as packed as people have complained it to be YAY!

It's a very hole-in-the-wall place, and if I didn't know of it, I'd pass by it without looking back. It's pretty easy to miss (as someone who's not from here), because it's located in a neighborhood area.

But let's talk about the food. WOW. I have been disappointed multiple times by people overhyping restaurants but this place was amazing!! We ordered the har gao (shrimp dumplings), pork and shrimp shumai, the soup dumplings (xiao long bao), Bang Bang chicken, and the fried pumpkin. Everything was so delicious, I can't even begin to describe it, but I'll try.

Starting with the dim sum: har gao and shumai. I love both those things, and since they're some of the basic dim sums, hard to go wrong. But the har gao was perfectly juicy and steaming hot. It was pretty packed to the brim with delicious shrimp and was really melts in your mouth good. The shumai taste was pretty average (obviously on the tastier side of average), but the texture was awesome. It's topped with some kind of fish roe or something and it gives another dimension to the texture, which is really fun. 

I dedicate an entire paragraph to the xiao long bao (soup dumplings) because I LOVE THEM. I LOVE THEM TO THE ENDS OF THE EARTH AND I WISH I COULD EAT THEM EVERY SINGLE DAY BUT UNFORTUNATELY IT IS NOT POSSIBLE. But anyway, the way the XLB is served here is pretty interesting, because it's not on top of the steam paper on inside of the bamboo/metal steamer like most XLB are. They come in their own cute little scalloped individual tin (almost like an egg tart tin). It's 3 to a steamer, which isn't that many, but HO LEE COW. It's one of the best XLB I've ever had. Haven't had Din Tai Fung, so sorry I don't know, but this place is juicy and the piping hot soup inside is AMAZING. The only downside it that the XLB wrapper is a little bit thicker than I'm used to, but I can dig it. Doesn't affect the wonderful taste at all.

The Bang Bang chicken was WOW. I love love spicy food, and this totally hit the spot. Perfectly crunchy, and the garlic hits you (in a good way). Some of the best wings I've had. Wingstop and BWW, please step up your game (sorry, do you guys have this in California??) Then comes the fried pumpkin. At first, the name was not appealing to me at all--"fried pumpkin with salty duck egg yolks"--??! What?? Do not be repealed by the name! The pumpkin is sweet, and goes well with the saltiness of the egg yolk. The egg yolk gives yet another texture to the fried crispiness of the pumpkin with its soft powdery-ness. At first, the taste is a bit odd, but I found myself liking it more and more and kept eating until I wanted to pass out from food coma.

Between 2 people, this was more than enough and we were really really full afterwards. We left with happy bellies. Can't wait to visit again.
author: Erin K.

description: Good family style restaurant. The food was great, especially the dumplings. The wait staff was super attentive and helpful.
author: Amanda S.
