description: You can taste the love that is poured into each carefully crafted dish. The owner greets you, buses her own tables and really shines through with her great attitude. Comfort food at its finest as she shares dishes from her childhood. By far the best Chinese I've had in years I highly recommend this place to anyone!
author: Camilo F.

description:
Mama Ji's my fav Szechuan restaurant! They have amazing foods!
Quality of delivery is also good.
author: Daniel O.

description:
Wasn't a huge fan. The line was long, the space is small and the food was mediocre. We came for dimsum, which should have been a warning sign - a Szechuan restaurant serving dimsum? Dimsum is a traditionally Cantonese food and should not be spicy at all. 

The best thing was probably the spicy cold noodles - which makes sense, because it's szechuanese, but even that was a bit strange, using egg noodles, more typical of Cantonese cuisine.
author: Cynthia X.

description:
A regular here for dinner (haven't had dimsum). Love Szechuan! 

We usually do walk in. Groups up to 4 should be easy.  Service can be a bit slow at times but nothing outrageous. They don't have a huge staff and are incredibly nice. 

 Regularly order:
Xlb (a bit pricier than normal but delicious)
Hot/numbing fish ( if you like numbing peppercorn-unique!)
Crispy eggplant (I was skeptical at a fried veggie but delicious and our guests always surprised /enjoy taste)
Szechuan beef 
Pickled beans w. pork
Ants Noodle Dish

Looking to add more to this list :)
author: Josephine L.

description:
Why did I not pay closer attention to this place when I lived in the heart of the Castro??? I live with regret.

My favorite dishes are the fried eggplant (deep fried, fluffy, battery fluff, yum) and the beef chow mein (I have no idea what they put in this stuff that makes it so addictive, but it's more complex than your standard old mein). I just love these hole in the wall places with great food and muy fantastico prices and just a very low key vibe. A super awesome find in a neighborhood that honestly is very limited in down to earth good food. You get tired of the slice of pizza after awhile, ya know what I mean?

I will be back to try the dim sum.
author: Natasha P.

description:
Was craving dim sum and it was perfect because I was in SF, it was the weekend before Chinese NY, and this place was half a mile away! 

There was no wait and the food came out pretty quick as is the case with all asian places. 

We ordered the veggie pot stickers, spring rolls, vegetable clay pot, and kung pao tofu. All were delish! The clay pot had some really good mushrooms and the kung pao tofu was crispy and soft in all the right places. Spice level was high, just like we requested. 

They have beer/wine with a pretty good assortment of both. Neither are really that cheap though. I just got a blue moon because it was $5 since the other stuff, both bottle/draft was more like $7-10. 

Food prices were normal.. entrees $10-13 and potsticker/dumplings $5ish. Not super cheap like you might get in Chinatown but definitely affordable. 

The server was a very..ya know.. we were in the Castro ;) He was exuberant and fun. Only weird thing was that he was hovering over me when I was signing the check/writing his tip down.
author: Aria S.

description: Thought we would go for the Dim Sum for dinner but Dim Sum only served for lunch. They should of mentioned that on their website. But will have to say the food was excellent and fresh. Have to go for lunch to try their Dim Sum.
author: Teresa M.

description:
Best Hunan Chinese in San Francisco. Nothing fancy, a bit off the beaten path about 6 blocks off the Castro strip. Parking is difficult.

The staff is friendly as can be and the food is fresh and spicy. Expect a wait at busy times. 

I have been 5 times now and keep going back. I have had the Shrimp, the Shanghai Dumplings, the Eggplant, the Green Beans, the Cumin Lamb. All really authentic, unique and very tasty. Portions are generous and reasonably priced. 

However, I was on one occasion disappointed with my order: whole fish. The spice level was high, but I can take it hot. However, the fish was so salty as to be inedible. They did not offer to get me something else. So only one disappointment in 5 visits, hence only 4 stars.

For those who don't stray far from Har Gow and Su Mai, you may not be impressed. They probably don't make these everyday staples in house anyway. I don't know why they call it a Dim Sum restaurant because there aren't many Dim Sum items. Stick to the entrees they make in house.
author: Norm G.

description: Longhair waiter was awful. He skipped us 3 groups because we were 3 people not 4 people. That is luck of character.
author: Shinya M.

description:
I really don't understand the high reviews on Yelp for this. We've had take out here on two occasions. Neither were spectacular.

The steams pork buns lacked filling, and the bread wasn't as fluffy as it should be. And the quality of the food didn't seem as fresh as many other Dim Sum locations?

The second experience is what takes the cake. The food is probably a 3-star level, but one of us got food poisoning from their seafood options. 

To everyone else fortunate enough to have a better experience, I envy you all. But I for one, am not going back.
author: Alton D.

description:
When I first moved to Castro, I had to get my bearings by Yelp searching all my culinary essentials... including dim sum. It has taken me months to finally end up here, and alas I've tried MaMa Ji's dim sum. I came here with my boyfriend on a Saturday morning (brunch time) and was pleasantly surprised to find that the restaurant was nearly empty. Shockingly I'm learning from other Yelpers that the line can get pretty long. Didn't seem to be the case that morning. 

I love Szechuan food, but I was in the mood for some good ol' dim sum. Gotta try the basics first. We ordered the shrimp rice roll, pork shrimp shumai, shrimp dumplings, deep fried meat dumplings, and sweet rice. Clearly we like shrimp. All the things we ordered were pretty standard. My favorite was the sweet rice. I like almost anything wrapped in lotus or banana leaves.

They failed to bring us one of our orders by the time our check came, which is also reflective of the fact that the service here is kinda iffy. Anyways, I'm glad I finally got to try MaMa Ji's. I've eaten at more better dim sum places in Daly City and the Sunset District, but this place is pretty close to where I live, so it's a convenient option!
author: Stefanie C.

description:
This place is alright... and it's pretty expensive. I thought all of the dishes were a bit on the salty/oily side, but it wasn't terrible. After trying many of dim sum places in Los Angeles, this place is mediocre. 

Also, I ordered to-go after my meal and our server literally mixed the dim sum dishes together in one container. Not sure if that's a thing, but I wasn't too pleased with that. Anyways, there are better dim sum places out there :P
author: Jenny H.

description: This place is amazing. Don't know why it's received anything below four stars. Affordable food that's d-lish. BBQ rice tolls are amazing.
author: Armen Z.

description:
I'm pretty torn about what to score this place. On the whole, they're just okay. They've changed their menu a lot over the last 6 months (at least it seems that way) and while some of the food is good, some dishes are seriously bland. 

Let's go back to my first visit here... I walked over from my Airbnb and was pretty new to dim sum - not to mention San Francisco. I still hadn't been to Chinatown (or Inner/Outer Sunset & Richmond) and the Castro was really something to see. It's safe to say the coolness of the neighborhood might have made me think it was better than it was. Among the good food that time were shrimp and shanghai dumplings, fried rice, and some sort of chicken dish. My friend and I left super full and really happy.

The second time eating-in was totally underwhelming. There was a super long wait, the service took FOREVER because they "forgot" our order, and then the food was really meh. The bean paste noodles --- not good at all. Dunno why people are stoked about them.

Finally, I've gotten takeout a few times. This has been fine. It's just nice to have someone cook for you though. The food is good, it's served hot, they're pretty quick and it's all reasonably priced, but I'm just no longer impressed with the flavors.

If you're looking for dim sum and for some reason you can't travel anywhere else in the city, go, but would I recommend this place as a go-to spot? Nah.

Other notes...
-- It's a bit cramped
-- If you order food to go they ask you to wait outside
-- Shanghai dumplings are really good
-- they serve beer/wine
-- they are conveniently located just a few short blocks from the heart of the Castro
author: Andrea D.

description: Mama Ji's has some solid dim sum food.  Their menu may not be the most extensive, nor as large as some dim sum restaurants, but they still manage to serve out a great meal.  This particular area of SF is lacking in dim sum restaurants so if you're in the neighborhood and craving it, this is your best bet.  The food is a bit pricier than dim sum on average in SF.  They offer most of the basics.  You order by marking what you want on a menu, no carts here of course given that the place doesn't seat a whole lot.  But fortunately, despite it's tiny humble size, it doesn't get over the top busy.  It's great that you can get your dim sum fix without the excessive wait that some places draw.  This place is definitely more of a locals only kind of place away from the busy parts of SF.  It's pretty relaxing to grab some dim sum here with some friends.
author: Bryson L.

description: Excellent. Casual and yet amazing food. Just what you want in a neighborhood restaurant. Great menu options--we shared an entree style dish and several dim sum options.
author: JD M.

description: Simplified dim sum. Good for a smaller space such as this. Don't expect as many selections as regular dim sum places but they have the main essentials.
author: Yad L.

description:
Their Chongqing chicken left more to be desired. The meat was too dry and while the dish is meant to be crispy, it was overly so to the point where it hurt to eat.

EDIT: I originally gave this place 3 stars based on the food however due to the horrible customer service we had, I reduced my rating to one. The phone was ringing right by my ear the whole time with no one to attend to it. The staff was poorly managed so that we spent more time waiting for our check than eating. With better management, this could be a decent place to go to but right now, it's chaotic.
author: Sharon W.

description:
Mama Ji's offers up some yummy homely entrees, when it comes to cooking up dim sum food for brunch and a mix of Sichuan spicy food for dinner!

They surely know how to perfectly steam their rice rolls, such as their shrimp roll and pea sprouts with shrimp steamed dish!  Add on their house made hot sauce and it enhances the taste of all the dim sum dishes!  Their dim sum dishes, such as their steamed pork ribs and fried eggplants with shrimp, were very clean in terms of sauce ingredients and not very much of the starchiness used!  I loved it!

I also do find their signature sauced up noodles, very slurpalicously amazing and de-ri-cious!  We ordered up their Noodle Chili Bean Paste and the diced up jalepeno pieces were spice killers on the mouth palate!  Order up their Spicy Cold Noodles, if you want something refreshing and a portion of a mix salad - especially for a sunny San Francisco day!

What I recommend, is to bring you and another person!  No more than 4 people!  The wait is long and the place is fairly small, so turnover is about a 30 minute wait!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
yelp and SF Magazine, you have failed me. Perhaps this place gets great ratings b/c it is shocking to find a dim sum place in the Castro. And certainly the staff and chef are authentic. Perhaps my palate has become american-ized. 

I ordered lots of food and kept waiting to find something that merited the 4 stars, but I found nothing.

The Xiao Long bao - were a disappointment. did not come with vinegar and ginger - which is standard. Nothing special (only 3 pieces for $4.75)
Har gow - nothing special
BBQ pork bun - nothing special
sticky rice - nothing special. and not as soft as others. and they don't use the standard chinese sausage that is deliciously sweet. 

House special wonton soup with noodles ($14)- Saltier than anything I have ever had in my LIFE! We had to fix it by diluting it with water! The wontons and noodle were good but the soup was pure salt! and the noodle had a base of salt too. 
Lava bun - like custard bun but the custard is runny - scary looking and gritty taste.

We had been warned about the service - had to ask for forks twice. They told us they ran out of 1 item and took off 1 of the item but not the other one I discussed. but left the other 2 on the bill, so I had to ask for that to be removed. They never gave me my tea that I ordered.

The ice water was great, but the refill was not as cold.
author: Sophia Y.

description:
4/4/2017 Tuesday night 8pm.
More than 2/3 of the restaurant was empty.

My friend and I got in and both had bags, so we sat in a 4 people table.
The lady (owner?) asked us to move to a 2 people table.
We asked "Can we just sit here?"
She says "No, You never know".

Never know what? People will flood in and pack the restaurant at 8pm Tuesday night? Again, 2/3 of the restaurant was empty.
We said "Seriously???"

You can't give that 4 people table to the 2 people with bags to put on chairs?

She was serious and we left. 
It was pretty sad that the woman was very near-sighted.
We could have become returning customers, as we go to Eric's in Noe Valley almost every week.
We won't go back there. What a non-sense. I still don't get it.
author: Mac K.

description:
Hands down the best Asian fusion food ever! It's perfect for going with a group and sharing all the dishes. I love the shrimp and chive dumplings as an appetizer. 

My friends are regulars and I'm happy they suggested we dine here.

Tip: get there early because after 7pm, the line is long and there is no waiting area.
author: Ashlee S.

description:
In Hong Kong, we refer to a Dim Sum outing as 'YumCha'. Which literally translates to 'drink tea'. Tea is a very important component to the Dim Sum experience. In fact, a Dim Sum guru would even argue that sampling different types of tea(Bow Lay, Teh Kuan Yin, Oolong) is actually the essence of YumCha. 

Mama Ji's served us Ice Water.

Mama Ji's is an up and coming Dim Sum place located in the Castro district. Word on the street is that the Dim Sum here is very traditional, and hipsters around the area have been flocking to Mama Ji's to get a taste of Hong Kong. But seeing as how there are no tea kettles on the tables here, this is definitely not the place to get that HongKong DimSum experience.

The jury's still out on the quality of the DimSum. I admire that the dumpling stays intact throughout my struggles with the chopsticks. A sturdy dumpling is a good dumpling, and that's definitely not easy to make. Mama Ji can work on the taste a little bit tho. There is no MSG but the food was pretty bland. It doesn't help reduce my sodium intake if I have to drown my Shui Mai in a pool of soy sauce yadada?

I guess Mama Ji's is still alright, as long as they don't start calling DimSum "Chinese Tapas"
author: Ringo M.

description:
Originally came here for dim sum, but as I looked through their dim sum and entree options, we opted for the entrees. In retrospect, I'm really glad we made this decision because their dim sum seemed a bit overpriced.

We got the hot and numbing fish and the fish-fragrant eggplant. The hot and numbing fish was definitely hot and numbing on my tongue, but tasted excellent. I echo the other reviews that it's very addicting. Please be advised that the spiciness level of this dish is no joke, and would only recommend you order it if you can tolerate spiciness. Even my boyfriend who usually tolerates a lot of spice had to down a lot of Sprite in the middle of it! The fish-fragrant eggplant is a misnomer, as it's actually a vegetarian eggplant dish that is sweet and spicy. I thoroughly enjoyed this as well. 

I thought the portion sizes were just right and I will definitely return in the near future. Szechuan food is not for everyone, but if you've never had it, I would definitely give it a shot. You could also always order foods with no or less than 3 pepper signs.
author: Claudia C.

description: Wow this place used to be great (talkin about a year or two ago) but now it's getting uh oh. Just went there for dinner, was soooooo disappointed with the dishes... We ordered the green beans, Mongolian lamb and nam yu spare ribs. I wasn't looking for full authenticity at a place like this, but how can they charge $13 for a crappy spare ribs dish?? I had the same green beans dish there a year and half ago, it was pretty good but not anymore. I'm so bummed. Really bummed. I love that green bean dish since I lived in China... Mama Ji ruined it. My husband and I walked out angry and decided never to go back again, not even for the dim sum - hey there are plenty of good dim sum places in the city. Don't get stuck in Castro!
author: Shaz L.

description: The food was so delicious and service was great! They're very welcoming and getting a seat was easy. Their cilantro and shrimp dumplings were absolutely scrumptious and prices were extremely reasonable. I don't know why this place only has 3 and a half stars, I know standards in sf are extremely high, but come on what's better than amazing dim sum and a cozy little local spot to get it in?!
author: Yasmeen G.

description:
Real good down to earth neighborhood jewel. The cold pork belly with hot chilli oil is amazing. Solid dim sum and more than reasonable prices. The hot and numbing fish is served hot and super crispy and the sischuan fish is not to be missed.

I've read reviews critiquing the service, and it's true it's hit or miss, but this is a small family restaurant; sometimes they are overwhelmed but they are ALWAYS happy to serve you. Having said that, service is great most of the time.
author: Alberto P.

description: Yes, yes, yes.  Always yes.  Mama Ji's is the polar opposite of greasy, Americanized Szechuan/Chinese food.  Fresh, delicious and in a bright atmosphere with fun service and a great selection of Belgian beers.  Trust me -- sour beer *rocks* with more heavily vinegared dishes, like soup dumplings and the like.
author: Don N.

description:
We gave this place a 2nd try because of the good reviews on Yelp.  Bad mistake... Really don't understand the 4 stars on Yelp. Rated by their family and friends?

The dry bean curd was just okay, the fillings were dry. The spicy cold noodles were terrible. The overlooked noodles were mixed with hot chili paste straight from a jar. The shredded pork was more than 50% fat.

Will not return.
author: TopCat W.

description: I came here on a Saturday afternoon around lunch time- probably not the best time to come if you are hungry and want to eat ASAP!! The place is small inside, so if there are big parties or you get there when others are there.... expect a wait.  We waited about 1 hour until we got seated (just a party of 2).  However, the person managing the seating was very apologetic for the wait, not that it was his fault at all.  Anyway, after we were finally sat, we ordered the bean curd rolls, seafood dumplings, seafood and pork shumai, and the beef ho fun. We really enjoyed all the food there!! The dim sum was pretty good- but I can't speak for the Szechuan.
author: Kristen C.

description:
After one visit, MaMa Ji's has made a really great first impression. Everything we got was good. Out of the feast we ordered, I really enjoyed the Fried Pumpkin with Egg Yolk, the Seafood Shumai, and the massive Pan-Fried Pot Stickers. My dining partner loved their Crispy Eggplant. If you want something green, try the Stir Fried Pea Leaves in Garlic Sauce.

As always, I got some Steamed BBQ Pork Buns; the bread was soft, but there could've been more pork inside. The Shanghai Dumplings were good, but not the best I've had in the Bay Area (that prize goes to Panda Dumpling in San Carlos). 

Dessert was awesome. My dining party really enjoyed their Seared Pumpkin Cake. They also serve cookies from Black Jet Bakery: my friend was into their Oreo Cookies and I devoured a delicious Peanut Butter cookie and a Granola with Cream cookie. 

In short, tons of enjoyment from start to finish. Thanks, MaMa Ji's!
author: Mark C.

description: I hate leaving low ratings but wow holy mediocrity! I really don't get the high ratings here but I sat with a friend from the home land and he was so disappointed but hey so was I!! The xia long bao was so doughy and tasteless. And the fish with tofu- was not in chilli oil but a putty kind of substance that had corn starch in it! Atrocious. The cumin lamb was gamey and so tough to chew that we just gave up! Sorry mama ji, I really wanted to like you. But looks like your usual patrons are folks who really have no idea what real Sichuan food is. This is a faux Sichuan place!
author: Trisha H.

description:
We ordered Mama Ji's through Door Dash tonight and were generally pleased with our meal.

The chicken shumai and shrimp dumplings we had as starters were quite flavorful.  Our mains - the chicken chow mein, chicken chongquing (cubed, fried chicken), and vegetable clay pot (mixed veggie dish) were all well seasoned and tasty.

The portions were a bit smaller than expected and the prices are higher than your typical Chinese restaurant.

Overall - very good food, and for that reason, a good find!
author: Barnali D.

description:
Mama Ji's is a small place in the Castro for dim sum.  You order off the menu & they will bring you the food.

Tea is in an Individual small pot $3 per person, but they use good tea from Red Blossom Tea Company.  I picked Farmosa Oolong Tea.

Stuff we got:

pork shrimp shumai $3.75 - 4 to an order.  tasted good
pea sprout shrimp dumpling $4.75  - 3 to order - fine
cilantro shrimp dumpling $4.75 3 to order - fine
dry bean curd roll $3.75  - 3 to order - fine
steam spare ribs $3.75 - just ok
bbq pork rice roll $7.75 -fine
shrimp rice roll $7.75 - fine
veg rice roll $7.75 - fine
pan fried turnip cake $3.75 - good
sesame balls $3.75 - i didn't try, 3 to order
spicy cold noodles $8.75 - enough for 3 people, spicy, we liked it.

sub total $63.25 + $5.53 tax = $68.78 before tip for 3 ppl.  We ate alot though.

One unisex bathroom
author: Ann L.

description:
4.5 stars overall is a bit of a stretch, really. But if I'm grading on a scale of Castro eateries, perhaps.

If you want really legit dim sum, you go to Monterey Park or Alhambra in the LA area. If you're in the SF area, you hit Chinatown or else go to Koi Palace in Daly City (arrive early). But if you're in the Castro, and you're in the mood, and you don't want to drive (or fly) an hour to get lunch, which would be a reasonable justification for eating in the Castro... then this could be a nice option for you.

Pretty decent overall, selection is good, and they do bring it to you quite fresh since it's made-to-order (no carts here). 

Great location, super-convenient for Castro folks, and it's actually above average in quality. Just not a five-star awesome amazing bring all of your friends kind of good place.
author: Sean B.

description: OMG everything here is delicious! I eat here about once a week because I live in the neighborhood. It's the #1 requested dinner place when friends come over.
author: Jennifer O.

description: Delicious! Definitely my go-to in the neighborhood when I crave Chinese food :) the hot & sour soup is very flavorful, the combination chow mein is very good, and the fried rice is simple, yet tasty!
author: J G.

description: Checked this place out on our one day driving tour of san Francisco. This place was highly rated on yelp so we stopped in. The seating arrangement was confusing because no one was on staff at the door to tell us whether to be seated or not so we just sat somewhere and the waitresses were very awkward upon taking our order. Beyond that the food was great! I had never had good Chinese food even close to this in Texas. Fresh everything. Fresh steamed and fried gyoza, dumplings, lavender tea and ground beef shanghai noodles. FRESH FRESH FRESH! Definitely will be back.
author: Ashleigh J.

description: This review is exclusively for Mama Ji's brunch.  Great quality legit tasty dim sum! I noticed the wonton/dumpling wrapper is thicker than I'm used to from other dim sum places. It's slightly chewy but not tough and all of the dim sum we ate was delicious. We had no problems with service and the prices were reasonable. Definitely joining our food rotation.
author: Caroline N.

description: Absolutely delicious Pork buns were to die for, they literally melt in your mouth. So much flavor in the potstickers and paired with the sweet and sour sauce We will definitely be returning
author: Chelsea Christine D.

description:
Not your typical dim sum place, even the environment reminded me of an American brunch restaurant. It's located in a residential neighborhood so it's small in the Mission. I thought I was in the wrong area, but it turns out it was right there.

There was a lot of sunlight in the place, and very simple decore. Did not resemble a Chinese restaurant, but our server was an older Chinese woman, speaking in Chinese.

I posted a photo, we got several dishes (we had a group of 7) so we got to try a lot of dishes. It was a little different then a traditional dim sum place -- they had a similar Korean jia-jiang-mien, a Vietnamese dry noodle, a plate of string beans, the hai-gua, sui-mei and some buns. If you were to come here, I would say the noodle dishes stood out to me. If you wanted to eat the traditional hai-gua sui-mei, I would go somewhere else cause it didn't stand out to me here. 

The waitress also told us that coming before 12PM is much better because people haven't woken up yet. They also don't seat you until your whole party is there. For good dim sum out in Castro, this place is great! I want to come back for their lunch specials, but it takes me about 40 minutes to MUNI here, so IDK!
author: Jessica C.

description:
I stumbled upon this gem thanks to yelp! My mom and I had plans and needed to grab a bite to eat before our activity. We usually always plan our agenda out in advance but for some reason we were left in one of those unfortunate situations driving around aimlessly while trying to yelp something good. Don't you hate when that happens!?

Anyways, we found dim sum in the midst of the Castro. I read some reviews where ppl felt the dim sum is basic and to that I say, you're right, I don't think they are trying to be a full on dim sum house. They don't have a full fledged dim sum menu but they do carry a lot of core dishes while also maintaining a big focus on traditional Szechuan cuisine. (Which for those who don't know, Szechuan is a variant of Chinese cuisine but very different from traditional Cantonese Chinese cuisine which is most prevalent in the Bay Area.)

Needless to say, mama ji's is all about extremely fresh handmade dumplings. It's like grandmas cooking and my mother and I definitely agreed we had to take grams here asap. 

What we ordered: 
Chives and shrimp dumplings - bomb

Shanghai dumpling - comes with 3 in order and ginger. Pretty solid level of soupiness and size.

Hand pulled rice wrap with shrimp - very fresh!

Pork and shrimp siu mai - one of the best I've had

Triple c wings - best wings ever. So juicy with a sweet, spicy, and crunchy skin. So bomb.


Totally coming back. They also deliver on caviar so it's convenient too. Enjoy :)
author: Lauren Y.

description:
Some things are too good to be true.

5'10. Handsome. Cunning. Ambitious. Witty. And a charming smile that will make you melt. Ohhh and...a hinny you can bounce a quarter off of.

Only boobies don't make him go ga-ga, pecs do. Ahhh, why are all the hot guys, gay? I've never seen such a large congregation of hot guys in one place than the Castro. 

Anyhow, after reading that there was a new all-day dim sum joint with full service in the Castro, I was thrilled as none exist in San Francisco (Dim Sum King in Pacifica is the nearest one). I had especially high hopes for MaMa Ji's since early foodie publication reports said that the owners hired a former Koi Palace cook (voted best dim sum in the bay area by SFGate and I agree) but later reports said the cook was from Yank Sing. Regardless of where the cook hailed from, both Koi Palace and Yank Sing are well-known though the latter is more well-known for it's not very Chinesey prices and catering to non-natives.  

I'm all about supporting my peeps and mom and pop shops, but MaMa Ji's dim sum was far from solid with Koi Palace prices at hole-in-the-wall takeout quality that you will find in Sunset or Richmond for 1/3 the cost. If you never had dim sum before then this may suffice but if you're a dim sum connoisseur, you may be sorely disappointed.

The owner was very nice but service was non-existent. We had to go to the counter to order and get our own waters. Our "waitress" lacked basic interpersonal skills and was MIA most of the time. She never checked on us and there was only two other tables there who were laptop camping. I could of cared less had the food been good because inattentive service is a given at most Asian places so I didn't really factor service into my rating. 

Back to the main reason we came here: The Dim Sum. 

Although there's 40 items listed on the menu ($3-$6 per an order), over 1/3rd of the items were not available the day we went. In addition, some of the things arrived not as pictured on the menu. I'm allergic to MSG and was told they don't use it; I even asked again in Cantonese to make sure. However, I could immediately tell there was in fact MSG as my tongue went numb and I became very thirsty. Not a good thing as I had to stop eating midway through, though I'm sure my thunder thighs were relieved. 

Our order:
*Woh Tip: Potstickers ($3): http://bit.ly/10TJIac
*Hai Gow: Shrimp Dumplings ($4): http://bit.ly/16DRpco
*Shrimp "Balls" ($4): http://bit.ly/14oAmUI
*Shrimp Stuffed Mushrooms ($4): http://bit.ly/10LUvqk
*Shrimp & Chive Dumplings ($4): http://bit.ly/14oAzY2
*Chicken Siu Mai Dumplings ($3): http://bit.ly/11RmrKV
*Spareribs in Black Pepper Sauce ($4): http://bit.ly/11mrzF9

The best dish was the plump Chicken Siu Mai. Everything else was 2 stars worthy. The Hai Gow was small with not much shrimp filling. The Potsticker's filling was rancid with an weird aftertaste. The Scallop & Chive Dumpling had a gummy skin and the chive to scallop ratio was way off with just one very teeny weeny scallop bit in each dumpling.

The Beef Ribs in Black Pepper Sauce were brought in lieu of of the Spareribs in Black Bean Sauce because it wasn't available but they didn't bother telling us until they were handing us the beef ribs. Ugh not wanting to argue over a $4 dish, we said we would take the beef ribs which was just basically scraps of bones and fat.

The Shrimp Stuffed Mushrooms were topped with an identifiable opaque white seafoody mousse (4 received versus 8 as pictured on the menu) while the Shrimp Balls were not even balls at all.

Sadly, a solid dim sum joint with no MSG in the Castro was just too good to be true. As we were about to leave, the owner asked us if we liked it and I did as obedient Asian would do. LIE. Shake my head. Smile. AND Lie. *sigh*
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Mama Ji's is a decent spot if you are trying to stay within walking distance of Haight or Castro. Their version of eggplant and shrimp was better than others since it was fried. I also liked the shrimp and pea shoot dumplings. The shanghai dumplings, shu mai, bbq pork steam buns were okay. They forgot a couple dishes and appeared to be shorthanded.
author: Huey N.

description:
I found the food at Mama Ji's to be really good at some points and underwhelming at others. The fried green beans and Kung Pao Tofu were both excellent, although the green beans were a little too expensive imo. I also tried the Spicy Cold Noodles and the Vegetarian Potstickers, both of which were average at best. The Spicy Cold Noodles were intensely, intensely spicy to the point of frying my tastebuds for any subsequent flavors.
     The biggest reason I had a lukewarm experience however mainly had to do with the service. The waiter screamed at me when I asked for water, barked at us in general, and acted frantic and abrupt throughout, even though we came on an otherwise quiet Sunday night. Definitely not rushing to get back here any time soon.
author: Adam F.

description: My very favorite neighborhood restaurant. There are lots of vegetarian options, which is rare for dim sum. It's true that the wait staff is a little disorganized, but I'm ok with it because its a family run place.
author: Leila D.

description:
This restaurant is way off the regular Chinese restaurants locations....  That is probably why not catering to Chinese clients....  Sorry to say, also dar from the most qualified critics, Chinese clients....  For SF, where there are huge amount of Chinese restaurants, quality wise is below average.  They specialized in 2 type of Chinese food, Sichuan, which we order more common dish, chongqing chicken... Pretty bad tasting wise....  Bland, very bland....
Their second specialty is dim sum, quality wise is kind of average, maybe a little below.  The real problem is the price, $6 for hargow, and shrimp rice wrap dish was $8....  That is almost 2x the price of premium dim sum place, including Koi Palace and Dynasty....   
Bottom line, this is not a hidden gem, but ripping off locals who doesn't know what real good Chinese food looks or taste like....
author: Steve D.

description:
Food: 3 stars
Service: 1 stars

MaMa Ji take pride in its authenticity; however, I didn't find their cuisine all that authentic. We ordered "Fried Pumpkin with Salty Duck Egg Yolks".  The Authentic way to cook the dish is to batter sliced pumpkin with salty egg yolks and then pan fried them.  Our dish came out wasn't what I expected at all - it was battered in thick flour and deep fried in oil. There were barely any salty duck egg yolks in the dish.

I mentioned the above to our waiter, who apparently took it offensively. When we finished our meal, he came over and made a comment "well, looks like you finished the dish. I guess it is good after all."  Dear Mister waiter, we finished our meal because we were hungry and we don't waste food. Did you see all the thick batter I striped off every piece?

Funny is, after he made his "point", he went back chitchat with his friend. We got up and got the check ourselves. 

Seriously.
author: Anna Y.

description:
The food was definitely good! They had a good variety of dishes and each was definitely a good portion. 

Their soup dumplings came in foil bowls rather than spoons which was interesting but I ate it nonetheless. 

The service was friendly, but minimal, which was fine since I was honestly too busy stuffing my face! I would definitely come back if I was in the area again
author: Austin L.

description:
We came here for dinner because we were meeting up with a friend who we thought lived nearby (we were a little off on our guess...whoops!).

We showed up and she was still on her way. We were told to put our name on the list outside and we had to wait for our entire party before being seated. For a Thursday night, this place was pretty crowded. A couple tables for two sat empty, so there definitely wasn't much of a wait, if any. Here's the breakdown:

Service: Friendly service. They took our order with a smile and were attentive.

Ambiance: Chill, casual spot. Small. They sat the three of us at a table normally meant for two. We got cozy. Also, we were right by the door, which almost never stays closed (unless you constantly close the hinge on the top of the door every single time after someone enters/exits).

Food: After consulting Yelp, we ordered the shrimp dumplings. Chongqing chicken, and dried fried green beans. Nothing really stood out to me. The shrimp dumplings were pretty solid. The chicken was just deep fried chicken and really more of the crispy exterior than chicken. I was a bit disappointed. The green beans were typical - nothing special, but not bad either.

Drinks: They have quite an extensive wine list, which includes some pricey bottles. We ordered a bottle of white wine (I forgot what it was called), but it was pretty good. Went down nice and smooth.

Would I return? I wasn't particularly blown away with our food, but the table next to us ordered a couple dishes that smelled really good. It's a toss up, but I don't think that's enough to get me to return. I really wish I could like this place more.
author: Leana L.

description:
I have been going to MaMa Ji's ever since they opened a few years ago.  I always loved their food - clean, flavorful.  A little more expensive than standard Chinese restaurants but I am glad they offer me the chance to get higher quality Chinese food (especially Szechuan dishes) for a few dollars more.  Way worth it.

But this place seems to have taken a nose dive in the past few months.  The Country Style Pork tasted like plain gobs of salt with none of the nuanced flavors of the days past.  The Eggplant in Garlic Sauce, the reference dish, tasted like a sweet desert dish.  The kitchen just doesn't seem to know what they are doing anymore.

Another one bites the dust or just a seasonal dip?
author: Remy H.

description:
A favorite neighborhood restaurant, for us it's walking distance so we frequently pop in for dim sum or the spicy cold noodle craving. We love the service and how quaint Mama Ji's feels like your sitting among family having a good meal. 
Shanghai Dumplings, Shrimp Stuffed Eggplant, Crispy Spring Rolls and Dry Fried Green Beans are our favorites. 
The Spicy Cold Noodles were my favorite, now see how I said "were". We came here last night and ordered our favorites just like normal. Out came dim sum and followed with the Spicy Cold Noodles, right off the bat I noticed they were completely different. Usually it's a gorgeous bed of thick egg noodles that's mixed table side. This dish was just a blob of tiny string noodles mushed together in a ball that the server couldn't even mix. Not appetizing looking at all. This dish use to be gorgeous and now it's just a mess. Not to mention it did not taste the same, we actually sent it back because of how bad it was. And I never send anything back no matter how much I detest something so that just gives you an idea of how much they messed up this dish.
So apparently they changed the recipe that day and now will be using the little noodles drenched and mushed in sauce. I am so sad over this change.
I love this place and supporting the staff at Mama Ji's but some changes aren't always good ones, especially when it's a dish that kept us coming back.
author: Victoria T.

description: I must say that I prefer their dim sum lunch to their dinner. The beer selection is great, but moderately priced. Lunch time is extremely busy and often involves a 30 minute wait on weekends.
author: A N.

description: Food was amazing. Spicy where your lips are burning and you're happy about it. We ordered a bunch of appetizers and entrees and shared family style to have a taste of everything, and were not disappointed. The only thing that threw me off was how the xiao long bao was served - in these little foil tins. Not how I am used to. We sat in the back towards the kitchen and it got a little warm back there. Service was off and on. The most annoying thing was that they would only split the bill three ways. We made do but if you're splitting the bill evenly, what's the big deal?
author: Jessica G.

description:
My boyfriend, his buddy, and I had gone up to San Francisco to hang out for the day. We were looking for a Chinese restaurant, and this place was one of the options that came up. It looked like they had good reviews, so we decided to give them a shot. Not happy, at all.

The lady that served us could barely understand any English, so I didn't get what I was looking for. The menu, itself, was kind of small, so there wasn't much to choose from. My boyfriend and I had ordered dumplings, but the lady didn't even ring it! She wrote it down when taking our order, but she didn't even give it to the cooks. At the end of our meal and we asked, she just had this dumb look on her face. We had ordered the egg custard buns before we got the check, but she didn't even ring that, either! 

We don't come up to SF that often, but next time we do, we are NOT coming back this hell hole of a Chinese restaurant.
author: Diemmi H.

description: Really good dim sum! Didn't feel tired after eating it. Everything on the menu was good but my favorite was the shrimp shumai.
author: Mary P.

description:
We were massively disappointed... We came here because this place received Michelin recommendation this year, despite the hype, below are reasons why we think this is such a disgrace to Michelin and Szechuan cuisine.

Food: some of the spicy dishes are too spicy and yet not savory, the chef must blindly throw chilies and thought the spicy it gets the more 'authentic' people will think of it. Growing up in Szechuan myself, I feel sad that people will associate this restaurant with my hometown cuisine.

Service: the waiter and mama Ji constantly mess things up! During our 40min meal there, they misplaced an appetizer and water on our table which were ordered by guests sitting next to us. And needs us to remind them we ordered chili fish not beef twice! Finally they brought us two wrong checks before finally giving us the right one.

Price: despite the mediocre food and absent minded service, don't get misled to think this is your average cheap Chinese eatery: two of us spent over $60 for 3 simple dishes and a beer.

I feel obligated to write this review to inform you, my fellow yelper, so you don't have to repeat our costly mistake.
author: Xi C.

description:
Please believe me when I say that this place serves terrible dim sum. Out of the 6 dishes we ordered, only the seafood shumai turned out to be really good; the rest are really terrible (yes, the contrast is quite stark). 

CRISPY SPRING ROLLS
Not good. Authentic spring rolls should be stuffed with steamed turnip strips, which gives the spring rolls a fresh flavour by countering the oily taste from the deep-frying. These spring rolls were stuffed with cabbage strips, which added to the oily taste. Not good. =( 

STEAMED BBQ PORK BUNS
Any self-respecting dim sum place should get this staple dim sum dish right. But their buns were not nearly as nice as they ought to be: the meat was too hard (the fats didn't melt into the meat like they should), and there isn't enough gravy in the bun to keep the insides moist. The result is a slightly chunky and dry bun. Real BBQ pork buns taste waaaay better than this. =( 

SHRIMP STUFFED EGGPLANTS
The shrimps are deep fried, and taste like fish cake. I think that pretty much sums this dish up. I was SOOO disappointed with this dish, because I like eggplants so much. 

SEAFOOD SHUMAI
Finally, a really decent dish!! This tasted good; the prawns were succulent and not fish-cake-like, and it tastes just like how it should. You should order this dish, if you really have to eat here. 

FRIED RICE
This was terrible. Real fried rice should have a fragrant "wok" flavour, where the rice is semi-caramelised. It's the signature flavour of all fried rice. This is just rice tossed with MSG in a pan (and it's really too salty). It's a shame to call it fried rice. 

 SHANGHAI DUMPLINGS
After reading the raving reviews about the Shanghai dumplings (xiaolongbao), we decided to give it a try and give this place one last chance at redemption. It was a mistake. If you think that this xiaolongbao is good, wait till you taste the real ones. 
1) the skin is too thick; real xiaolongbaos have thin skins that house the meat and soup within. 
2) there isn't enough soup in the dumpling. The soup is a signature of xiaolongbaos. 
3) the meat tastes bad; it doesn't taste very fresh. 

Oh, and they also don't share their wifi password. =(
author: Yu Sheng T.

description:
Food is better than average, but not consistent. Forget planning what order it will come out (small kitchen.)

Service is even less consistent.  Some staff are really nice, others are either not comfortable speaking or have a grumpy attitude. Can't tell.

Dim sum is okay.  Small selection.
author: J B.

description: I had high expectations for this place after reading the reviews but I was just not impressed. The food was just okay and overpriced. The one item that I really didn't like were the rice rolls - too much of the rice noodle and it was overcooked. We ordered a couple of other dim sum items like har gow and shiu mai which were good, not nothing special. The service here was also just so-so. The waitresses we not that attentive and it took a while to get the bill and our card back. I probably won't be coming back, there are much better options elsewhere for less.
author: Angela K.

description:
This is the worst dim sum place ever. They don't even have the basis dishes like chicken feet, congee, etc. And it took forever for the food to come out. 

Maybe this place is for Americans, not Asians.
author: Queenie D.

description: Mama Jis is a lifesaver for weekend brunch dumplings.  There can be a wait but it is always worth it.  Great soup dumplings, Shu Mai and har gow.  Everything is very tasty.
author: Reid H.

description: We went there on Saturday noon but didn't wait at all. Dim sum are good. We were totally impressed by the 重庆辣子鱼 (spicy and numbing fish).
author: Ester W.

description:
Mama Ji tackles two separate Chinese cuisines, Sichuan and Cantonese (Dim Sum) to mixed success. It's kinda as if you went to a restaurant serving southern style bbq and Maine lobster rolls/new england clam chowder. I grew up eating rice-based foods so given the choice at Mama Ji's, I opt for Sichuan unless with friends who insist on dim sum.

With the exception of one item, most of the dishes were solid but hardly the best Sichuan food I've had. Many of the reviewers have mentioned "bland". Chinese food typically is a bit salty, extra flavorful so that you can eat it with rice in an 1:1 ratio. At Mama Ji's, it almost as if the rice/carb hating have demanded dishes that can be eaten without rice. 

The standout menu item for me is "Fried Pumpkin with Salty Duck Egg Yolks". A really interesting dish that I've had not seen anywhere else. At other Sichuan places, I've seen it done with corn or green beans.
author: Dian X.

description:
Pros - The dumplings were freshly made.

Cons - The service was very poor and some of the food came out cold which was disappointing.

All in all an average experience. We wish we had tried somewhere else.
author: Livia M.

description: I don't really understand the hype for this place. My guess is that most people in SF have no taste. I've been four times now and each time have been disappointed with the greasy bland tasteless food. Nice place though and the service isn't bad, if not very friendly. All in all, there is a lot better around for a lot less $!
author: Neill S.

description:
We came here for dim sum only.   

Food  = delicious.  Chicken shrimp siu mai, shrimp pea sprout dumplings, shanghai dumplings, pan fried turnip pudding (here, it is the same as cake, for this dish), BBQ pork rice noodle, and noodles with pork and chili bean paste. Everything came out piping out.  

Service = polite, semi-friendly. Order off the menu for dim sum (and other items). They do not walk around with trays or push carts here.

Decor = simple, clean, and natural lighting. 

Prices = moderate.  $45 for six items for three people is fairly reasonable. And we had leftovers, too. 

Note: There is no chicken feet on the menu.
author: Fannie S.

description: Excellent Szechuan in the Castro, server was busy and bangin', directed us to fantastic choices. Small but cozy, homey and friendly.
author: wendy i.

description:
I loved this place!! Went for the first time today and bookmarked it about 3 years ago to try. I ordered way too much but it was still amazingly delicious when I took it home. I had the rice noodle rolls, shrimp dumplings, potstickers, chive and shrimp dumplings, sesame balls, won ton soup, bean curd skin rolls, a few others and it was all so good! I was not a fan of the cold noodles despite all of the reviews about them, but to each their own. It was not awful, just the only thing I didn't particularly care for.

They were fairly busy and the service was solid.

Yes, it's more expensive than dim sum in Chinatown, but then again I didn't feel weighed down and thirsty from MSG overload afterward like at other dim sum eateries. I don't mind spending more money on having higher quality ingredients. Plus it's very rare to find dim sum available with no MSG.

I will definitely be back!
author: M M.

description:
Came here with a group of friends under the strong recommendation by one of them. I was not disappointed.

The chongqing chicken / la zi ji is highly recommended! Slightly tangy and spicy, this dish is definitely rather authentic. 

The dim sum here is pretty decent, but definitely not as wow as how the other reviewers make it out to be. I've definitely had much better.

The restaurant itself is pretty small, so if you have a large group, definitely do be prepared to wait a longer time for your table!
author: Christina N.

description:
I really wanted to like this place since it seems to have some kind of Michelin nod. But overall this place is totally overrated. I did enjoy certain dishes: soup dumplings, bell pepper with shrimp, pot stickers. However, the kung pao chicken was mediocre and came with cashews instead of peanuts which made the dish very unusual and lacked the peanut flavor. Furthermore, red chiles were the main ingredient instead of chicken. One dish in particular - the sweet rice with shrimp sausage wrapped in lotus leaf and considered a Mama Ji's 'special' was outright inedible. And we got charged nearly $2 for a small bowl of steamed rice. 

This is not to mention the cost. You are paying for the neighborhood not the quality of the food. We spent $60 on a meal that should have been $25. 

I am sorry to say I will not return and would recommend sparing your wallet by giving this place a pass.
author: Shannon V.

description:
This is not a 4 star Chinese restaurant. I legit question every positive review of this place. 

This is all based on a takeout order and does not reflect the service at all but only the food.

Fried dumplings - too doughy 

Egg rolls- first thing I tried and were the best part of the meal. Very good.

Chicken fried rice- this was insulting. I opened the container and it was regular white rice with veggie and chicken toppings on the edges. Not even mixed in. This is not fried rice.

green beans- good

Chicken chow mien- had a weird flavor. Was not a fan at all and I love even the shitty chow mien at Panda Express. 

Broiled beef- had no flavor aside from being way too spicy. Nothing putting it together though.

All in all this food was a huge letdown on a rainy Sunday night.
author: Sean K.

description: Chinese restaurant but NOT for Chinese speaker. Especially the steaming stuffs totally weird.
author: Pei-Lun H.

description: This is a homey, sweet restaurant with really good food.  I liked it so much after the first time I dined here that I went back within the week (I was craving the chicken wings).  The owner and staff are friendly and efficient.
author: T H.

description:
Husband and I went here on a memorial day weekend Sunday. There was no line, and it was not crowded inside. The food came really quick and the staff was very nice!

We went for the dim sum menu. The way of ordering reminded me of tacky all-you-can-eat sushi restaurants in Amsterdam. Giggle :-) 
Very nice menu though! We each chose 3 dishes and had 1 dessert (sesame balls). I have had several dim sum restaurants in my short history of dim sum, but this one is definetly one of the two best places to go. 
The dim sum was really yummy, warm and soft. 
Definetly a yay for this place!

The only not so fun thing was the seating. We sat close to the door which didn't close by itself, so we had a lotta refreshing winds waving through our hair :-)
author: Styn V.

description: My favorite dim sum spot in SF and I've been to MANY. Pretty much every item I've ordered is spot on and the ambience is quick and cluttered like dim sum should always be. Favorites: cilantro shrimp dumplings, hot & sour soup, BBQ pork rice roll, veggie bun, and baby bok choy. Wish they had better drink selection, but no points off on that. I'm there to eat.
author: Max K.

description:
Was actually kind of disappointed with this place. First off, I really like that their menu has pictures of all the things your ordering. The place is also pretty cute, though there were lots of flies by our table...

Though severely understaffed (maybe because it was a holiday?), the waitress was pretty nice.

The food was good enough... I have definitely had better dim sum. I was excited to find Xiao lum pbao, but the dumpling itself was so thick and made it hard to enjoy. Kind of pricey for the quality of food. If you're looking for convenient dim sum in the Castro, definitely a good spot. Otherwise, I would just go to Chinatown for the real deal.
author: Steph D.

description: My favorite neighborhood restaurant!  The dumplings are amazing.  It's always packed but there are quite a few tables so easy to get a seat.
author: Natalia M.

description:
A little on the expensive side, but definitely my go-to dim sum spot. The soup dumplings are delicious, fresh and always piping hot (be careful). They use fresh and flavorful ingredients that will make your taste buds sing for their MaMa. 

In addition to the soup dumplings I recommend the bbq pork buns, the chicken chow mein and pot stickers - hard to go wrong here.
author: Thomas L.

description:
I got an early Tuesday dinner at Mama Ji's with my friend Yoshi A., largely out of convenience. I'd locked my cell phone in my host's house and needed to find a place in walking distance, so I was resigned to having a mediocre meal to pay for my stupidity. Turns out this place is a bit of a hot spot for Chinese food in the Castro. I enjoyed my dinner greatly, and wouldn't mind going back more on purpose in the future.

We went at around 5:30, right at opening, and had the place to ourselves for a bit. The space was small and pleasantly homey. There was friendly service to match.

The menu offered an extensive selection of dim sum and Sichuan specialties. It was hard to choose what to order with just two stomachs to work with, but we settled on some seafood Shanghai dumplings, spicy cold noodles, and fish with chiles and Sichuan pepper. The soup dumplings were tasty, made with pork and maybe shrimp? They were juicy and very hot, but I feel like I'm always burning myself on soup dumplings. The spicy cold noodles were fine, nothing special but easy to eat. The noodles were firm and the sauce had some good flavor. The centerpiece of the meal was really the fish, a giant bowl of fillets swimming in a bright red broth loaded with peppers. The fish was delicious, delicately meaty and permeated by the broth. There seemed to be an endless amount of it, too--must be some cheap-ass fish, not that that mattered at all. The broth was good, spicy and a little bit numbing, if lacking a bit in depth. It tasted great on the fish and splashed over rice.

Mama Ji's isn't the best Chinese restaurant I've ever been to or anything, but it's a solid joint in a central location with seriously satisfying food. I'd make good use of it if it were within walking distance of my house. I might even come to depend on it.
author: Steph C.

description: My favorite Chinese food in the hood. I brought many friends and families with me over the years because they have a small neighborhood restaurant feeling and so close to my apartment. Also they are tasty! I'm not a dim sum person but love LOVE the Szechuan fish and Mapo tofu - these dishes made me get through a day a quite few times when I got sick and couldn't get out of bed (used a delivery service because I was sick ;'( ) so thank you. Mama-Ji is sweet. Now that I have moved out, I really miss this great restaurant. Stay spicy and yummy!
author: Peach S.

description:
dimsum plus Szechuan = Mama Ji's.
The service is good.

I was skeptical of a dimsum spot in the Castro but the food was surprisingly good.
Most of the dimsum items were good and they tasted really fresh.  The shrimp rice noodle roll was good.  The shrimp was plump and the noodle was a good texture.  

The steamed golden custard bun was overcooked and did not have the runny inside.
The noodle with chili bean paste was pretty good.  Flavorful.

The shanghai dumpling was probably my least favorite. The inside texture was too mushy and sweet.

They have a variety of beers, coffees, espresso drinks which I usually don't see in a  typical Chinese restaurant.
author: Heejin L.

description:
Considering the amount of people waiting outside, you'd think that they'd try to expedite service ... just a little bit.  Upon being seated, it took almost 15 minutes to get water and another 10 for our beef chow fun to come out.  It took another 15 minutes to get shrimp dumplings, and another 5 to get our shui mai.  At this point, we're full and are tired of waiting.  We ask where the rest of our food was, and the (very, very nice) server told us that there were a ton of takeout orders and a bunch of tables who ordered before us who have not gotten their food.

I'm totally over it.  The food isn't even good (fuck me, thinking I'd find good dim sum in the Castro) and my stomach is full of grease from the chow fun.  The lo mai gai comes out, and boyfriend asks for everything to be packed up to go.  I'll make the trek into the Sunset/Richmond or even Chinatown next time for dim sum.  It shouldn't take that long for food unless they're slaughtering the animals for meat in the back.
author: Erica A.

description:
I am impressed: ALL of their shrimp dim sum was fantastic! 

The turnip cake was about as good as one can taste.

The service was nice, too. The only drawback, aside from the location, is that prices are rather high. What the heck, the goodies are well worth it!
author: George T.

description: Amazing unexpected find in the Castro...Great food, great atmosphere, well worth the wait!
author: douglas e.

description:
New in the neighborhood and heard high praise about MaMa Ji's - it was justified. As much as I loved the Qongjing Chicken (don't be afraid of the peppers, they're the best part), I think the most interesting part of my dinner experience was the Dim Sum. Super cheap and excellent portions and you should plan on splitting everything. It was just a wonderful variety of flavors. 

They also have an incredible Belgian Beer selection, although I didn't have any. Will definitely be back!
author: Andres B.

description:
On the weekend I love to go out to eat dim sum with my husband and we are both very serious about it, because we had also very bad ones around the world...
At MaMa Ji´s you get a nice variation of different dumplings for a good prize, but our favorite is the"pork shu mei". 
We ate them in so many places here in SF, but the never tasted as good as here! 
We both are not a big fan of the others dishes. We tried them and the are ok, but we decided to eat only dim sum when we visit MaMa Ji´s! 
It´s a crowed places and also very loud inside with not many tables, but if thats ok for you than you can enjoy a good, cheap lunch here. 
Families with small children are also welcome ;D
author: Nadine B.

description: Skip the green tea, it was pretty bland. But the shrimp with asparagus was spicy and delicious.
author: Jorge R.

description:
A dim sum restaurant in Castro? Not the typical place to find dim sum in SF but it's pretty darn good, albeit a bit pricey for dim sum standards.

The handmade rice noodle dishes are great here, definitely order the shrimp rice roll ($7.75 whoah!?) and the pea sprout shrimp dumpling ($4.75). Excellent texture on the dough in each bite.

Not sure what's up with the chili bean paste noodles ($8.75) since they came out a bit limp, but the dish was certainly spicy.

The pork spare ribs & shiu mai ($3.75) tasted like the usual standard you find anywhere else.

Skip the stuffed eggplant ($4.75), the sauce used in this was lacking flavor.

Service was okay for a restaurant filled to the brim, expect a long wait during peak weekend hours.

I'm not sure why there's Belgian beer on tap at a dim sum restaurant, must be for hipsters or a confused identity?
author: Steven C.

description:
Mixed experience. We ordered vegetarian dumplings which were delicious; they didn't come with a typical dumpling sauce, so we used soy sauce and it was really good.

We also had kung pao chicken which was 90% red and green peppers, 5% chicken and 5% veggies and sauce. The sauce was delicious, but the peppers overpowered the dish and the chicken was all dark meat and not the best quality. My dining partner ordered fried rice to go with it and it was pretty greasy.

We then ordered ants crawling up a tree (or something like that -- I always say that incorrectly :) ) and it was absolutely delicious. I was looking for something with a real kick and I got it here! I've never had it with the rice noodles and prefer when it's made with more lo mein-like noodles. But if you like some spice I highly recommend this dish.

Extremely affordable; service was good for us, we didn't experience any of the issues others have. Everyone was very nice to us. If you're in the Castro, I'd say check it out -- not sure I'd make a special trip as we did, especially considering we're staying 3 blocks from China Town!
author: Elizabeth S.

description: I always have a good time here.  Their Shanghai Dumplings are amazing!  Definitely recommend them!  The place is kind of off the beaten path, but yet it's always super busy, so you know the food must be good.  They close after lunch (230) and reopen at 530 during the week.  Be mindful of the times you go because you might have to leave your name on the board and wait for a table to open up.  The place isn't fancy - the walls are white like a track home in the burbs.  The staff are friendly and attentive.  Check them out if you haven't already.
author: Shaun W.

description: Love this place! Food has always been great every time I go. Very consistent. Try the sweet and sour pork...OMG is it good, and different from any other. Dim Sum is as good as any place I have been to in S.F.
author: R H.

description:
Great Szechuan food with some dim sum options available. All of their spicy items are obviously very good, but if you aren't a spicy person, I would recommend:
Shanghai dumplings
Stir friend pea leaves w/ Garlic
Dry Fried Green beans
Sweet & Sour pork
Chicken shrimp Shumai

It is on the pricier side ($2-3 dollars more than the usual). The shanghai dumplings for example are 3.75 but they only give you 3 of them, whereas for the same price, other places give you 4. 

Not saying it's not worth it -- it's completely worth it if you aren't able to travel all the way to Chinatown or Richmond for great Chinese food as there really aren't any other sit down places in the area that are as high quality as this place.

There are lineups from time to time but the wait is usually not more than 15m. They take on the longer side to prepare food, however.

In terms of ambience - it doesn't look like your typical Chinese restaurant since it has a pretty modern look. The owner is Mama Ji and her husband who helps seat and greet people and take orders. The space indoors is very crowded in the sense that the tables are all very close together. If you ever need to go to the restroom, be wary of sharing the narrow walking space with waitresses. They have seating outdoors, too, if you don't mind sitting out there.
author: Elisa L.

description:
wow, I cannot believe that this authentic Chinese Sichuan restaurant in the Castro.  I've had a few of their Sichuan dishes.  They were fantastic!  

Country style pork. 5 stars.  Shredded pork with g onions, jalapeno and fermented black beans.  This is so authentic.  Live this dish.  Yum!

Fish with tofu.  5 stars. Slices of cod and tofu in a garlicky hot oil.  Delicious!

Spicy eggplant.  Good flavor, but a tad too sweet and the slices of eggplant were cut too large so the flavor has not been absorbed into the eggplant. 3 stars.

I am so excited that there's an authentic Sichuan restaurant w good service.  I will be back to try their Cantonese dim sum.
author: Paul K.

description: With a stop outside San Francisco on our way cross-country, we made a quick visit to the city for dumplings and MaMa Ji's came out on top. We did dinner, and sadly could not partake of dim sum, but the dumplings were still worth the trip from Orinda. The teeny soup dumplings were yummy - both kinds! - as were the potstickers and shumai. We also got chicken and eggplant which was just a little spicy and excellent, and the beef with fermented green beans which was unlike anything I've ever had before - v. interesting and worth a taste. We ended up with way too much food, but lunch the next day was delicious :)
author: Ali E.

description: I spilled their hot and sour soup on my hand and when I got home my dog licked my hand for 20 minutes and tried to eat my wedding ring off my finger.
author: Sam M.

description:
There is a reason for the long wait during prime times. It's quality, value and service.   

I usually try to go right after the lunch rush.  Dinner is crazy busy.  

Love that the food is spicy hot without apology.
author: EC N.

description:
When I tried the vegetarian steamed buns, I smiled like a Cheshire cat with every bite.

Best way I have ever been served mushrooms. I don't know how to properly describe such a flavor. It positively danced on my tongue. I really have never had anything quite like it. The soft sweetness of the perfectly steamed bun melting on my tongue against the umami of mushrooms and veggies seasoned in a way I've never tried before--it was veggie heaven. I really cannot complement those steamed buns enough. It was an entirely new experience which hit an absolute home run in both texture and flavor.

If I was a resident of San Francisco, this would become one of my consistent haunts. Do yourselves a favor, vegetarians, and get to Mama Ji's.
author: Ren G.

description:
Uh oh! Ch-ch-ch-changes! Unfortunately not in a good way. Stopped in for dinner last night. 

Most of the dim sum menu unavailable during dinner. 

Caviar has doubled their kitchen wait time so the food came out one dish at a time, by the time the second dish was out we had already eaten a full large dish. 

The XLB, this place always did a hot fresh good XLB. Last night these little puppies came out late and collapsed. They looked about as sad as we did. The top of the bao was leathery from what seems to be from sitting in the kitchen for awhile before they made their debut. The soup had re absorbed back into the skin and the top was leathery. 

The green beans and Kung pow chicken came out delicious but the timing only allowed us to eat one at a time. 

Not rating based on service, but the negligent service was a shock compared to the usually friendly and fast service. 

The additional delivery services they're working with r taking a toll and I hope they work out the kinks. 

I might attempt again for lunch, of course after a much needed break.
author: Megan L.

description:
This place was super weird. They gave me and my cousin one menu to share, one drink menu, and one piece of paper and a pencil to check the boxes on our dimsum order. When we ordered, they took the menu out of hand, and wrote it down on the dimsum sheet instead. The first item we got was wrong, and they were served with the dessert items, which seemed odd. They then gave us the check without refilling our water, or asking if we our order was good, or if we wanted anything else We didn't get the last item we ordered until we asked for it again, after they gave us the check; they said we didn't know we ordered it, but we both saw her write it on the dimsum sheet. While we were eating they started to yell at incoming customers, telling them they were closed. Not politely saying "I'm sorry, we close from 2:30 to 5:30", but just "no, we're closed" while several groups of people were clearly eating.
The food was good, but I wouldn't go back.
author: Danielle C.

description: Ordered MaMa Ji's takeout. It made me sick. Eff this place. Do not order or eat there, or you might end up like me. You have been warned!
author: Dave N.

description:
I really wanted to eat here so bad. Eventually, I made it. I drove almost 1.30 hrs on Saturday for lunch here. It was just one party waiting before my party. I ordered most dim sum dishes I usually get from other dim sum places and a few famous dishes mentioned on Yelp.

I have to say that the food is made from the good quality ingredients. However, the portion for the price they offered is not worth coming here at all. 

Here is what I ordered for two ppl:

Bbq pork rice noodle roll: the noodle roll is too wet and not much bbq pick flavor.

fried shrimp eggplant & Tofu skin roll: way too salty that leave my tongue feels numb.

Famous c chicken: no flavor at all
 
Seafood Shumai: okay but I personally don't like it

Pea spout shrimp dumpling: the best dish for what I have here today.

Seared pumpkin cake & lava bun: it's just alright.

I don't think I will return. There are many good dim sum in the city and Im willing to wait in the line to eat there. As for Szechuan food, there is one place in Concord where I don't have to drive this far.
author: Audrey W.

description:
I guess I'm used to paying dirt cheap money for Chinese food. I guess this is what you call "high end" Chinese food, but I still wasn't very happy about it. I mean, some things were good, but they weren't AMAZING to be worth the price.

We ordered the following: 
1) SHANGHAI DUMPLINGS: This was a huge disappointment to me. I guess I'm really used to the whole "put it in your mouth and have soup squirt in it" kind of feeling. They came in these little silver cups beneath them, and there was definitely no soup taste within them. Real disappointment.
2) BEEF RICE NOODLES: This was good -- not too spicy, and it felt a bit more homie.
3) TRIPLE "C" WINGS: This is a definite must-have at MaMa Ji's. If you're going to get anything, then get these.
4) COUNTRY STYLE PORK: I THINK it was this dish. If it's fiery hot hot hot, then this is it. My date and I were't very happy with this dish. We even asked them to cook it mild, and we couldn't even finish it.

The service was kind of funny. We had servers come up to us every 5 minutes to order. We took a while to decide what to get, so it was just quite entertaining for the waiters to keep asking us what we wanted.
author: Joanne W.

description:
The service was not up to par 
Ask for
Pepper and forks was ignored 
Tea per
Cup  charged 3 $ each 
The food was
Good
Not sure if we will come back
author: Hieu N.

description:
Great dimsum at great prices! Came here for lunch during the week, and it was surprisingly empty. I'll chalk that up to the residential neighborhood it's located in. I don't quite understand the dings from other reviewers on the service. I thought the service was totally fine, but, again, the restaurant was far from crowded when I was there.

The food:
- The noodles with chili bean paste were phenomenal! Perfectly spicy with super fresh ingredients. The noodles had an excellent bite, too. 
- The steamed BBQ pork buns were the best I've ever had, period. Perfect texture on the bun itself -- sweet but light. As far as the pork inside, think perfect Chinese sparerib shredded up. 
- The shanghai (or soup) dumplings were a bit of a let down, though they were at a disadvantage seeing how they immediately followed the life-changing pork buns. They just seemed a little bland and not quite as "soupy" as I prefer. 
- My girlfriend is a veg, so she got the steamed vegetable dumplings. I gave them a try, and they were delicious. The portion was pretty huge (six in an order).

tl;dr MaMa Ji's is a must try for dim sum lovers!
author: Matt T.

description:
Excellent food and good atmosphere. A good choice for Dim Sum. Prices are right.

Yelp doesn't allow short to the point reviews so I have to write more for beefing the post !
author: Ken M.

description: If you looking for food, Just food, it's a good place and the food is delicious. BUT if you like the places you eat to be clean, I would never recommend this pace. It's such a dirty place. Our server ran out to pet a neighborhood dog and then came back in and stepped right behind the counter before washing her hands.  For me it's such a bad experience I had.
author: Ghadir O.

description: I wish they had a 0 star.  I went here for lunch at the end of March and ordered  pork dumplings. They seemed cold so we sent them back. They brought them out again, but they sure tasted funny.  We had a few questioning the flavor and then opened them up to find them NOT cooked all the way as we pulled raw Pork from our mouths...Ugh!  Then we told the wait staff who took it off the bill.  We left and both had gastric upset for over a month , intense parasite treatments, only to learn this place has terrible health scores!  70!?!? "Contaminated or adulterated food- high risk" , foods not protects from contamination, unclean hands or improper use of gloves" and many other risks. Why would they be allowed to operate??  Why isn't this score clearly posted ????Protect yourself, not worth contaminating your body!!!
author: Jen P.

description:
It's really nice to have a dimsum spot in the Castro but service needs work.  Basic items like siu mai and har gow are passable without having to trek to the Richmond or Chinatown.  I loved the turnip cake and scallop and cilantro dumplings.

Apparently, the dim sum chef came from Koi Palace -- well, I wasn't a fan of that place so... there you go.
author: Janice C.

description: Love this place!  One of me and my partner's favorite lunch places in SF!  We bring out dog and sit outside and enjoy the cucumber salad (to die for), pork buns, sesame balls, shanghai dumplings and shrimp and chive dumplings.  We also love the pork and cabbage dumplings!  Very friendly owners, great customer service and moderately priced.  Highly recommend!
author: D. C.

description:
I didn't feel that MaMa Ji's was anything above the ordinary for the price I paid.  Perhaps the cooking techniques had been adjusted to better suit the American palette (rather than my Aussie one).

Having said this, I did like the service here and there was a more than compensatory wine, beer and cider list here.

This place doesn't accept bookings so be sure if you want to get an easy seat, show up around 6pm.
author: John W.

description: Great food! I love their Spicy Fish and the Eggplant Chicken. Ambiance is nothing special, but this place is clean and well maintained and in a quiet part of the Castro.
author: Amandeep A.

description:
Food is pretty good but service is a mess. They over charged us a dish we never received. We placed our orders before another table which got served before us. I tried to ask the waiter if the dish could have been ours but mistakenly served to them. All the servers brushed it off and said some dishes get cooked faster. We had to ask another server for the coke we ordered. When the check came I counted the dishes I realize we got overcharged one. I told the server and he turned around, asked the COOK if she had made it. She said yes so that means we received it? Ok, maybe it was not the exact dish we never received.. It was hard to tell if it was either the  cilantro and shrimp or chive and shrimp dumplings that was the ones we didn't receive. But why ask the cook? Why not ask who served us? Anyway, we ended up paying that extra dish that I thought was mistakenly given to the wrong table in the first place. 

TIP: first come first serve outside patio. Make sure to ask what is being served to you and KEEP TRACK of what you're receiving so they don't charge you for something you never got!
author: Leelee E.

description: I've been eating here for a couple years and the quality just keeps getting worse. The low health department score is also covered up, no soap in the bathroom, and to completely make me sick there was a scott wiener poster in window.
author: Thomas S.

description: The food was pretty good here. I just have high standards for authentic schezuan cuisine. I do think it could've been spicier. We ordered dumplings, spring rolls, pork chow mein, cumin lamb, and pork spareribs. The sauce on the pork spareribs was really flavorful. I added the chili sauce on the table to the chow mein and it tasted awesome. The cumin lamb was really good. Very tender. Our server was wonderful. The other staff was ok. They snapped at me a couple of times when we got there about signing up on the list and wouldn't seat us until the entire party arrived even though I saw other tables seated while they were waiting for people. The restaurant is small - not good for large groups. Up to 5 or 6 people would be the max.
author: Lisa D.

description: Ack!  I wanted to love this place!  I've had lots of Chinese and 20 years of Chinese food in San Francisco and would not return here.  The stars it does get are for the soup dumplings (pretty good, hard to eat) and outstanding pot stickers.  Chicken and mushrooms were pretty standard and not worth the price...the fried (I love fried!) pumpkin (yes?) duck egg (yes!) was every inch of gross.  I like new things, I love Asian cuisine, I'll eat anything, but this was bad.  The service is a shiny one star.  We weren't offered rice, asked for rice, never got it, never checked on by the wait staff.  Less than half full for dinner.
author: Matt M.

description:
Huh? How does this place have four stars?! This is why I have trust issues when it comes to yelp.

Mahbe it's because we're spoiled with really good Chinese food in OC and San Gabriel that this place paled in comparison. Or maybe we ordered the wrong dishes.

Chinqchong chicken - I really wanted to like it because that's what everyone recommended. It was mediocre.

Chow fun - I would skip this. Not good at all.
author: Emily Y.

description:
Came here for a very late dinner with some friends. While the interior of the restaurant is nothing to write home about the Dim Sum we ordered was really good. They are not all authentic but I like their variations- it's really good and very tasty. Don't miss their extensive beer menu!

We ordered the Seafood Shumai, Shanghai Dumplings, Shrimp balls, Steamed BBQ pork buns, Crispy Spring roll, pan fried pot stickers and my favorite, the green bean dish. Everything was delicious! All the dim sum dishes came out timely, really hot and tasted fresh.
