I don't know if the Green Bean dish is regular on their menu but it was highly recommend by their server and we needed a veggie dish to counter all the meats and fish so we ordered it. To my surprise, it was one of my favorites! Excellent service too!
author: Shunnie C.

description:
Wow! So impressed with this place and likely would have never found it if it had not been for my sister - kinda deep into the Castro and I'm still new to the city.

It's a dim sum/home style Chinese spot yet when you walk in you get this cool rustic vibe at the same time. I like that it manages to do that! I didn't get much of a choice on what we ordered bc I was so late but they all picked well.

We had the veggie chow mein which was so good! It didn't feel overly greasy but still a heavier dish packed with flavor. The veggie spring rolls soaked were so good they were wrapped in flat egg noddles and I bet with meat tastes even better!

We ordered some spicy chicken digs that was mixed with bell pepper, onions and such and it was so delicious! I bet all their home style dishes are amazing. We also had pot stickers and soup dumplings all delish. We stuck to shrimp and chicken although I would love to go back and try the beef!

I would definitely go again! Also had a good selection of bottles beers and wine. The bill was so cheap for 4 of us to eat and it was so much food - def a heavier meal I wouldn't have often but as a treat. Good to dine in groups family style to try things.
author: Priya S.

description:
Nice little neighborhood restaurant, although the inside is more of a coffee shop type atmosphere without any Asian decor influence. 

We got there at 10am Sunday.  It's was 1/3 full but we weren't allowed to sit till my husband parked the car, seems silly when there were plenty of tables and we were made to stand...ahh another one of those inflexible staff with no common sense.  I can understand if it were full.

Anyway, we ordered the following
Spicy noodles $8.95 lacked flavoring and very bland for a house special, but had a lot of veg and pork to mix in together.
Ordered a bunch of dim sum from $3.75 medium to large $4.95. Noticed there were no small dim sums. Most came in 3s and we were a group of 3, so it worked out fine. pretty good, nothing special.  Only bad dim sum were shrimp balls, which lacked flavor and texture and they were quite small and not worth the $4.95.
In Chinese restaurants tea is usually around 50 cents person but here, they give you iced water instead and tea is $3 per person.  

Overall, brunch was ok...tried it, done it and probably won't go back.  Will go to the regular Riverside or koi Palace for more authentic and cheaper Chinese Sum.
author: Elaine Y.

description: Been ordering from here for a while and also been to the restaurant a few times. The dim sum they serve at lunch is really good - especially the pork and shrimp shiumai. I've been craving the Sichuan water boil fish for a while and they do it really well here. Definitely really spicy and make me break a sweat.
author: Lianne C.

description: Mama Ji's has excellent dim sum, really makes me feel at home. Be warned though, this place only has their dim sum menu during lunch hours. The first time I went there was during dinner, and it was uninspiring. But after reading about this place on several blogs I decided to give them another try and it was well worth it. The golden lava buns (egg custard) were the highlight for me, you can actually taste the egg bits!
author: Jack W.

description:
Oh mama Ji,
Your food is so good, amazingly good, for Americanized Chinese.  Your service however is terrible. The B who barks out the orders as to where to sit, that was real fun! Your place in empty so why did you think it was a good idea to put the table of kids next to us? This was my go to place in the castro for cheap but good eats but after being spoken to like that I'm done.  Service is either I no speak English or I'm going to go smoke a  vape pen in front while you stair at me and wonder what happened to the food?
author: Corey Jace W.

description:
It's so refreshing to just walk to Dim Sum. I LOVE Dim Sum. Mama Ji's is always Very good. The Hai-gow is the best I've had. Fat and juicy and full of shrimp without a bunch of filler items. The outside is soft and perfectly bitable. The Shau-mai was very good with a clean pork taste. The quality of pork did not need to be over spiced.  We had 5 other dishes including Deep fried shrimp dumpling. I didn't think they compared well to others. A lot of crunchy but greasy stripped wonton, and only a small ball of meat in the center. I never actually could taste any of the center. How ever, that's only one of the dishes and the rest are great. I will happily return. 

Just don't take the table by the front door, because it's like an arctic storm...brrr.

Give them a chance and you'll be quite happy.
author: Matthew F.

description:
Funny place, not too assuming from the outside, and one can eat there, walk in, just a couple of tables taken, young waitress sees us and says 'Sit anywhere.' We do, and take notice of the clever little plate. On the table is our menu, lots of good varieties of the usual, most well priced. Great selection of beers, esp Chimay.

We order, more people come in, the take out counter near the register is busy, and then our food starts arriving. Every dish a winner, on a par with Yank Sing...

Seems and looks new, the black/white/red scheme works, there just needs to be more red. Esp on the column and lintel.

Very good service, our table was well managed and empty baskets were whisked promptly, partly due to it being a slow Monday lunch and not busy.

Finally, in this part of town, great dim sum. 

Enjoy!
author: William M.

description:
Hate writing reviews like this. Cause on one hand, it's well-deserved kudos. But on the other, as soon as people figure out how great this place is, there will be an hour wait at all times of the day. So I'll keep this simple...

I've been to joints such as Yank Sing and Koi Palace here in the City, as well as Michelin-rated and others worldwide. Mama Ji's can hang with the best of them. If you want a reference point, just look up Tim Ho Wan in Hong Kong. Similar vibe. 

Thankfully MJ is tucked away in a quieter neighborhood, so that should keep the casual eaters away and get me a table quickly. For awhile, at least. If they could replicate the Tim Ho Wan BBQ bun (hint, hint), it would be game over for US dim sum fans. So good.
author: Nathan T.

description: Still great, just wanted to add the Beijing Chicken and Eggplant is the bomb.  Also, you can now get delivery through trycaviar.com
author: Bryan H.

description:
LEGIT! I scoffed when I first heard about this place. Dim sum in the Castro? Oh, so it's 'white people' dim sum. Far from it. The food here is authentic and so flavorful/tasty.  Not surprising to read one of the chefs is from Koi Palace, my usual dim sum go-to.  Menu is a bit more limited than your usual joint but still has all the "top sellers" you could crave, plus a couple of noodle dishes that are generous portions and so good.

Everything from its location to the interior is unassuming and cozy.  Service was intimate and on point. The owner and her husband took care to check up on their tables frequently and seem to take real pride in what they do. We went through several refills of tea and even when the line started forming, felt almost encouraged to take our time and enjoy ourselves.

We noticed their wide range of Belgian beer (bottled and on tap) which was a random surprise, but just another reason for us to come back and try dinner, which has expanded options. Yum.  2 thumbs up.
author: Jen E.

description:
Came here on a windy afternoon looking for some solid Chinese food.  Ordered the steamed seafood dumplings and cumin spiced lamb dish (I forget the exact names).  

The steamed seafood dumplings were very small and only came in a a set of 3 per steamed tin.  While they were tasty, the dumplings were very, very overpriced for what was offer. The lamb was spiced well and priced decently.
author: Robert Q.

description: I truly love this place. I have gone during their dinner hours, but I highly recommend their lunch hours for dim sum. I like the noodles with spicy bean paste the most and the pork rice rolls. My boyfriend and I like to go whenever in the Castro area. I took off one star because I think their beer is overpriced. The most inexpensive is $6. At least serve pitchers. Idk just a peeve of mine and perhaps I don't understand restaurant logistics enough and shouldn't even be complaining lol
author: Gabby D.

description:
I've been craving proper dim sum ever since I moved to San Francisco. Even though I found a place that tastes great, everything else made my experience average at best.

Price: 
WTF?!  (Rice noodle w/ the shrimp) was $8 and came in the smallest portion possible. I LOL'd at my misfortune after seeing the plate. The rest of the items were also pretty expensive for dim sum but bearable. 

Food:
All the food tasted pretty good - thank the gods. It didn't blow my mind like Richmond, BC dim sum does, but it was above average. I wish that things would have come out a lot quicker though. This food should have not taken that long to prepare. 

Ambiance:
Small, cramped, simple. Nothing much else to talk about. They have a bit of outside seating, but it's nothing to write home to Mama Ji about. You see what I did there?

Lesson learned. I'd only return if I lived in the Castro or had a lot of money to spend for no damn reason. From now on, I'd do well to stick to Richmond or Sunset where true dim sum belongs.
author: Paul B.

description:
I would give this place a 3.5, definitely have mixed reviews about this place. I came here Saturday Morning with a group of 3 and was sit down immediately. We ordered Su Mai, Shrimp Rice Paper Rolls, BBQ Pork Rice Paper Rolls,  Kung Pao Chicken, Spicy Cold Noodles, and XLB Dumplings. We ordered brown rice with the Kung Pao Chicken but they said they were currently making some and would bring it out once it was done but never did. 
The Spicy Cold Noodles - good but definitely lacking flavor after adding soy sauce and chili oil it was delicious. 
Kung Pao Chicken -  pretty standard, no complaints
Shrimp/BBQ Pork Rice Rolls - Good not great
Su Mai - really yummy
XLB - great flavor! Probably my favorite thing we ordered
I find it hard to find good XLB in the city and I wouldn't say these were the best I have ever had but the outer skin was thin with great soup flavor on the inside. I would say I would come back here again but I dont thing anything I had really stood out and our food took a while to come out.
author: Eileen H.

description: We were looking for rice dishes in the Castro and my friend recommended Mama Ji's for delicious Chinese and Szechuan delicacies. I went with a party of 5 and they were able to sit us at a table in the back. It was a busy Sunday lunch hour so we lucked out. The service was awesome and the food was very appetizing. The menu tells you if the dish is spicy or not. Three chili peppers means its really spicy. MaMa Ji's really hits the spot when your looking for great Chinese food. The food is very affordable and i would definitely come back to their establishment.
author: Jordan C.

description:
Came here after we found out ramen fest was a bust and all the ramen houses were busy. Luckilynfor us we found this place. Great place to have an enjoyable lunch at an affordable price. The staff is friendly, although it did take us awhile to be seated when a couple tables were free.

Its a small restaurant. So small you can touch elbows with the person at the next table. It wasn't too bothersome though because the service was fast. 

Big plus for me: they serve ritual. Right off the bat i ordered a latte. It was my day off that day and as a barista I certainly did enjoy this nice surprise that I didn't have to have to be away from ritual coffee for too long ;)

Also, I like the dim sum write-in menu where you can just specify what you want and how many you'd like on the menu. Very easy and so cheap for how good everything was! I recommend the shrimp stuffed mushrooms and the fried shrimp dumplings. 

The fried rice was a little bit on the salty side. I bit into granules of salt from the egg a couple times. Also, the wonton noodle soup didn't have any flavor to it at all. I'm sorry to say that the broth tasted like plain water

Besides that, the whole meal was very enjoyable particularly the dim sum and i will definitely come back. i'm sure my other friends would enjoy this place
author: Nessa R.

description:
Food was great! Service was amazing! From Boston, wanted to try dim sum, mama ji's had the best review and I see why. We went when it first opened and we were the only customers there but people quickly showed up after they opened

The restaurant is in a beautiful area in Castro. Friendly neighborhood and people
author: Jeff C.

description: If you're looking for a place comparable to bostons gourmet dumpling house... This place is it! Authentic Chinese dim sum with personalized service.... Felt like we were being served at mama Ji's home!
author: Nina H.

description: This review is for dinner, not dim sum. Clean, warm, inviting space. Service leaves much to be desired - the young, fresh off the boat staff didn't speak enough English to communicate how spicy the dishes were. Fortunately the food was mostly solid. Their take on pot stickers (3 over-sized dumplings, $6) were delicious, though the seafood Shanghai dumplings were tasteless. My kung pao shrimp (yes, I'm a gui lo) was too spicy, but otherwise tasty, and a large portion. The highlight was the Chinese broccoli in garlic, which sounds pedestrian but actually contained large, perfectly cooked (still crunchy) veggie stalks. They might have been the best I've ever had at a restaurant.  Brown rice was fresh.
author: Nick C.

description:
Oh my good god! 
This place is awesome! Not expensive at all, and the dumplings are soooo good!!! 
I went there for dinner and hence missed out on the dim sums (only available for lunch), but if they're anything like the entrees, I will be a happy camper! 
Definitely need to go back sometime during lunch and try the dim sums.
author: Deepak P.

description: Mama Ji's is amazing not only because of the food, it's because the wonderful staff. As soon as you step foot outside, the nice server opens the door and greets you. He is very tentative and prompt. The ambiance there is very pleasing. This is a go to for great dim sum and to get your day started on the right foot. VERY PLEASED WITH MY SERVICE HERE
author: Vic A.

description:
Vegan Factor: 3.5 Stars
Took some menu hunting and verbal confirmation from the waiter, but when all said and done, the vegan dishes were solid. 

Food: 4 Stars
1. Vegetarian Pot Stickers: Questionably non-vegan, but I love 'em fried! Blame the bottle of wine (clearly cheaper than buying by the glass even for someone as mathematically challenged as me). But that's ok. Non repeater. Better options on the menu.

2. Stir-Fried Pea Leaves with Garlic: I love all variations of this dish and this one did not disappoint.

3. Fish Fragrant Eggplant: The star of the night. Don't be fooled by the name, this dish is all vegan. The spices used are usually reserved for a similar dish made with fish. Best ordered w/ rice to soak up the dark, fragrant sauce. Oh, and wait for the eggplant to cool before biting into one.

Repeatability: 4 Stars
There's a reason why there's always a line at MaMa Ji's. The ten minute wait was worth it.
author: Jay C.

description:
Outside dining for one 
Asked server for suggestions
Brought shrimp rice roll, then shanghai dumplings (my favorite) and chicken-pork shumai $20 total
Water beverage of choice 
Friendly speedy service
author: Adrian B.

description:
Third time's not a charm.

Overpriced, greasy food that skimps on meat. Their "Kung Pao Chicken" should be called "Green Peppers and Other Minor Vegetables Swimming in Red Oil with a Dash of Small Chicken Bits". WTF.

$30 on a meal should leave you feeling satisfied and full, not cheated.

Never coming back.

Henry's Hunan in Noe Valley is a better deal.
author: Inigo M.

description:
I had recently moved into the Casto and a coworker of mine has always lived nearby. He had always suggested to try MaMa Ji's. Finally had a chance to try it with a friend that loves dimsum after he helped me move places. 

We got there around 10am or so and there was no line to get seated (about half an hour to an hour later, there was a line out the door waiting). We ordered a bunch of typical dimsum foods, and enjoyed it all very much. Service was spotty, but we got the food we needed and got the water when we needed that too. 

It is expensive though. eek. Between the two of us, we spent $50. 

Another time, I've got Mama Ji's delivered to my friend's place since he really wanted dimsum. Not as expensive, but still pretty delicious. I think getting it to go is much better because some of it was a lot warmer than when I ate it in the restaurant - figures right? 

Overall, delicious place, a little pricey, but you get what you pay for. I mean, it's in a neighborhood not known for dimsum. 

Protip: get there early, and order off the dimsum menu. Hope for the best.
author: Nina Y.

description:
The best Chinese food! I had the beef fun noodles with pork bun and poststickers, and thought I'd died and gone to heaven! Walked right in on a Saturday night and scored a table immediately. The staff was attentive. The noise level wasn't too bad.

I will definitely be back!
author: Karen K.

description: I finally got to Mama Ji's  restaurant and I totally loved the food. My friend and I had the Dumplings and an asparagus dish  which was Great! It's a small restaurant but we were a party of two so we didn't have to wait too long. We also loved the beer selection. The service was great also. It's located in the Castro area which made it more fun! If you are ever in San Francisco try this place out,great food at a great price!! Five stars for Mama Ji's!!
author: Rachel B.

description:
So I live nearby and have watched this place, heard positive things about it and finally tried it. 

Short version: Food is okay, on the greasy side. Service however is atrocious. 3 stars for food, 1 for service. 

Had various dim sum/appetizer items. All ended with pools of grease on the plates. Otherwise slightly better than average. 

The serving staff was clueless. Kept trying to bring us other people's food. After 3 requests for silverware, with all our food on the table, I finally got up and got it myself. Same with our drink order. After 3 requests, we got half of it. 

Don't see any reason to return.
author: Steve C.

description: I went there because of the recommendation of Michelin guide, but ended up so disappointed. Compared to many Chinese restaurants I tried in Bay Area, their foods are mediocre and seriously over-priced. Also, the waitress and waiter messed up our orders with our neighbor's several times :( I feel really bad if people think these are authentic Chinese food, and don't understand why Michelin recommend it. Definitely won't go back again and won't recommend any of my friend go there.
author: Xiaowei L.

description: Really great szechuan food. No MSG! I adore their hot and sour soup. We also had the kung pao shrimp, dry beef with green beans and vegetable chow mein. Everything is fresh and delicious. Located in the historic Castro distrct, mama ji's fills up for dnner fast. Go a lttle early to avoid a wait. Dim sum is at lunch time and is not available for dinner. Fast and super friendly service. Big selection of beers. Highly recommend.
author: Jerry M.

description: I ordered delivery thru Caviar.  Beef Chow Fun was delicious with great flat noodles, Beijing Style Eggplant and Pork was very good - crisp not soggy eggplant.  Country Fry Pork was excellent just a bit too spicy for me.  Steamed Spareribs with Black Bean not much meat (but was only 4.75) and steamed makes it fatty.  Shanghai Dumplings and Steamed Buns were divine.
author: Rosie H.

description:
It is very seldom that I go to a new restaurant on the first day that it opens. Usually, there are many things that they are still trying to get right including the food. However, since my partner and I had been to Queen Malika before the renovation to change it over to MaMa Ji's and had tried the Dim Sum and had a great experience then, we decided to come and show support for the new incarnation as MaMa Ji's.

What we were not prepared for was the fact that with the new renovation comes a new head chef directly from Yang Sing (known as one of the top Dim Sum restaurants in San Francisco). The chef makes all his own sauces from scratch and has a NO MSG policy. The food was top notch, from the amazing Seafood Shumai, to the delicious Steamed B.B.Q. Pork Bun, and the Chive Shrimp Dumplings. However, if I had to pick only one Dim Sum as #1, I would say that the Steamed Egg Custard Bun is probably the best I have ever tasted -- including several trips that I have taken to Hong Kong!

There were a few Dim Sum that one could not yet order as I guess they were not yet ready for prime time -- but we will definitely be back to try them soon. 

They serve four types of Chinese teas directly from Taiwan and each one is served with it's own small teapot -- so that everyone at the table can order what they want and get unlimited refills of hot water.

The other exciting thing about MaMa Ji's is that at night they will be open to serve Szechuan cuisine -- if the food is anything close to the Dim Sum, which I'm sure it will be, it will be very exciting to have a great Chinese dinner place in the Castro.

If you love Dim Sum as much as I do and want a local neighborhood setting, then you should definitely try MaMa Ji's!
author: Laurence N.

description: My boyfriend and I both love Asian food and choose this place due to good reviews, but I wish we wouldn`t. We have specifically told our server that we`d like our dishes to not be spicy, still both of them came EXTRA spicy. I politely asked the server if he might have forgotten to mention our request to a cook. He quickly grabbed my dish only, promising to change it (would be nice if he have wondered about my boyfriend`s dish, as it was extremely spicy as well) After a few minutes he brought my dish back, it was less spicy, but so salty that it was just impossible to eat. We just paid our bill and left hungry and disappointed. There is absolutely nothing to like about this place: interior, service, food could be much improved.
author: Tonichka R.

description: Very poor service, multiple tables seated after us were served their food before we even got to order. Nothing that we ordered made up for the long wait. The numbing fish had a weird spicy flavor, and we couldn't get our waters refilled after our mouths were on fire. We both had upset stomachs and the bathroom was out of order so we had to run home. Bad, bad, bad.
author: Ange R.

description:
Came here for lunch yesterday with 2 friends and it was delightful. We happened to be in the area and wanted some tasty dim sum, mama.ji's, popped up on Google maps so we tried it out!

They have dim sum available for lunch only and you have a small paper menu on each table with a pencil. You mark off how many of each dish you want and then they start serving it up! 

I am sure there is better dim sum in SF, but great for the  location and the price was right. We ordered  15 small plates and tea for the table, we all walked out paying about $25 each, including tip!
author: Lynette G.

description: Yah this restaurant has it going on. The dim sum dishes were all really excellent and very fresh. Great flavor and the right amount of spice - but be careful spicy means spicy. i always ask for mild. The best thing us the flavor and the freshness. Yum - but also take care the place is often packed.
author: Sean M.

description:
All the best parts of Dim Sum (the food) without the overly pushy servers. MaMa Ji's is a casual place that does Chinese well (especially considering it's in the Castro). Avoid the Shanghai Dumplings, they just don't get those right. Make sure you get the Lava Balls for dessert.

On the non Dim Sum menu try the spicy fish for a (literally) tongue numbing experience.
author: Adam H.

description: Was working and took an uber over here. It was so good. We all enjoyed are lunches. I would definitely go again. It was a little off the beaten path and not a big place.
author: Julie M.

description: I tried to place an order I tried calling both numbers listed after 6 tries I finally got an answer I said I would like to place an order for pick up I was told " we are very busy - 20 minutes for pick up " I said I was ok as I still had to get over there then she hung up on me while I was still talking ! If you don't want my business it's ok there are plenty of friendly business owners that welcome my business ! Also perhaps if you're busy at least have a message on your voicemail and having two phone numbers is confusing as you don't know if you have the correct number
author: lyn m.

description: Congrats, Mama. The food has drastically improved from our last visit, after which we promised never to return, and although the service is not great, at least they're not rude anymore.
author: smrt O.

description:
Service is non-existent. The short hair Chinese waitress was rude. She didn't greet us or say thank you when we left. When I asked her where the restroom was, she said the restroom was unavailable. However, when the other lady asked where the restroom was, the waitress pointed out the direction. WTF! You think I am some kind of homeless person and plan to take a shower in your restroom!?

Food is pretty good in general, but it's a bit pricey. For example, they charge $3/person if you order tea vs. Hong Kong Lounge charges $1/person on tea. Shrimp rice roll is $7.75 vs most dim sum restaurants charge $5 max. 

If service is not this worst, we will probably come back.  I hate people treating us like folks in concentration camp.
author: J L.

description: Good dim sum. I had two pork and one shrimp and it was all very good. I would recommend this place. Next time I will try one of the noodle dishes.
author: Chandler H.

description:
Very cool little restaurant in a nice area of SF with a lot of hills... We were visiting from LA, where we have many good Szechuan restaurants.

We tried two Szechuan dishes, not any dim sum. I liked what we had here. The fried fish was amazing, and the chicken in a clay pot (not the official name) was delicious too. Prices for the dim sum was much higher than I'm used too. But I like this place and definitely would return if I lived in this area..
author: Jeff J.

description: The overall experience is bad, food is okay, the owner attitude is very annoying, she started cursing very loud for about 5 mins as soon as we say down, mainly about we brought soda along; she could have come over tell us if that's not allowed, sitting there cursing out loud is not helping and I would have give 0 if there is.
author: Lyla D.

description:
Great to find a new place in the Castro. Unfortunately, the food was sub-par. The chicken was worse than day-old chicken McNuggets. The hot and sour soup was fine. The green beans were fresh but basic and nothing you couldn't do with a microwave at home. Not a place I would advise. Stick to the regular Castro Chinese haunts.
PS - the service was very good, which gives it an extra star for a total of 2 stars
author: Stephen O.

description:
After a good celebration on Pride Friday, we headed out to dinner. We were able to get table for our group, though it was near closing time.   

The food here is really tasty, but it was also oily and heavy. Be prepared. Though I guess that was a good thing since it allowed me to soak up all the liquid beverages I had earlier. 

The dishes that we ordered were the dry-fried green beans, mapo tofu,chongqing spicy chicken, boiled beef slices in fiery sauce, kung pao chicken, wonton noodle soup, pot stickers, and  crispy spring rolls.   From all the dishes, my favorites were the boiled beef slices in fiery sauce, wonton noodle soup, spring rolls, and pot stickers.  The boiled beef meat was tender and flavored well. It was really a good dish, that I would have eaten all of it, if I didn't have to share. 

I didn't care for the dry-fried green beans as it was too difficult of a dish to eat with chopsticks. The green beans were chopped into small pieces that it was just difficult to eat. Not a pleasant eating experience.  The chongqinq spicy chicken taste was nothing special. I couldn't taste any flavors that would make it stand out unfortunately.   The mapo tofu was just too oily.

I think Mama Ji's would be a great lunch/dim sum experience, that I would be willing come back to give it another go.
author: Marck N.

description: Really good dim sum. Tried several types. All good.  Nice change from Cantonese style.  Always busy.Pleasant and efficient servers. Fair prices.
author: Joe M.

description: Nice Chinese food in Castro. I ordered mapo tofu, fish sauce eggplant and pepper with pork. Mapo tofu is good, not too spicy. Fish sauce eggplant is delicious. They both are pretty authentic. Pepper with pork is yummy, but not exactly Sichuan style. The service is great. Very polite and give you what you need quickly. The environment is fine and clean. The price is fair. I Will come back.
author: Emma C.

description:
Mediocre overpriced food. 

Crammed in with pretentious Castro San Francisco smug "I'm better and more interesting than you" crowd, you will have the pleasure of being bumped 30 times by macho waitresses or the rolled up pant leg (pegged, we called it in the 90's) patrons due to the mini dining area. 

No thanks.
author: Jason L.

description: Not great for delivery, the food was so bland. We got beef chow mein, sweet and sour pork and Chinese broccoli. Chow mein didn't taste like anything, sweet and sour pork was mostly sour, and mostly onions and green bell peppers. The chicken wings were actually really good and flavorful. But everything else was a big disappointment.
author: Adele A.

description: For the combo of price, quality, wait time, uncomfortable tables, not so great service, 3 stars. Beer selection kicks it up 1/2 star but again the whole experience is not so great and I am not going back.
author: Lo F.

description:
Great food, fast service, and home-y atmosphere!

We got the cucumber salad, which was a phenomenal start -- refreshing and very flavorful. The spicy cold noodles were solid, but lacked any special punch. Wouldn't order again. The stars where the hot & numbing (Chongqing-style) chicken and fish. They were crispy on the outside, tender on the inside, and spicy and rich with the quintessential Szechuan peppercorn. My mouth was tingling: it was fantastic.

Great spot for dates, family dinners, or just hanging out! Not necessarily the most authentic Szechuan food, but boy does it taste good. 

If you're up for a challenge, ask your server to make it extra spicy!
author: Vicki N.

description: Came here with a friend during my last trip to SF hoping for great things because of the great reviews, only to be let down with "just OK" dimsum - nothing mind-blowingly delicious, unfortunately. Ordered a few things off of the menu but it just didn't compare to other dim sum places I've tried. Disappointing! The staff was friendly, though a bit slow.
author: Emily K.

description:
Dumplings were excellent.  Chongquing chicken was basically Gen. Tso's without sauce.  
Mama Chen's Tofu = ma po, good, not great though. 

I would go back for dumplings and rate again.
author: Jared B.

description:
Of all the things I expected to find and did find in the Castro (dudes, leather sex shops, unnecessarily expensive organic grocery stores, more salons per square foot than anywhere else in the country), a super legit dim sum place was not one of them.

This place has all the traditional favorites - shrimp rice rolls, turnip cakes, and dumplings - with none of the grunginess that typically accompanies Chinatown dim sum restaurants.  Ordering is easy and simple: just mark up the menu with the golf pencils they've given you and marvel at the speed at which the food comes out.

Unfortunately, the clean food and fast service come with higher prices.  You're paying a premium compared to most Chinatown places.  Just tell yourself it's a diarrhea tax and continue to stuff face.
author: Kevin C.

description:
OK, so I went to this place for dim sum a few times when they first opened and loved it.  I haven't been in a while so last night I decided to go try it out for dinner & I was EXTREMELY disappointed.  I was so starving that I forced myself to eat, but had that not been the case I would have left the entire order untouched.  The potstickers were OK, not terrible but not great.  The hot-n-sour soup was SO bland and tasted only like pepper. It looked delicious but looks can clearly be deceiving.  We also ordered the kung pao chicken and beef with string beans.  The KPC was extremely bland and the chicken pieces were overcooked so much-they were the hardest pieces of chicken I have ever eaten--seriously, it was like eating little rocks!  The beef was chewy and overly salty.  Both dishes seemed to lack flavor with the exception of Soy Sauce.  Service was also pretty bad.  We had to ask for water numerous times and still didnt get it until after half our meal was over.  In addition to that, I had to get up to get our own plates and chopsticks to eat our meals.(like HELLO were we supposed to eat with our hands or our soup spoons?)

Overall, I was lucky I had good company at the dinner with me, because otherwise it would have been a total BUST!  Really sad because this place has potential & used to be good, but it seems they have gone downhill fast. Definitely not worth the $$ either!
author: Gary H.

description:
We met the co-owner Marv while having dinner the week that Mama Ji's opened. He lives right in the castro, and told us he started Mama Ji's with his wife because he knows how hard it is to find good food in the district. 100% agree.

As far as the food goes, it's good quality sichuan that doesn't require a trip to Chinatown and actually has good service. The dim sum was a bit standard but good. I enjoyed the specials and dinner plates :D

So, I love the owners now, and there's solid sichuan food right near where I live. Food is about 4 stars, service is 5 stars. I see a lot more Mama Ji's in my future.
author: Jade M.

description:
2 Vegetarians go into the restaurant and order some delicious food. 

We got the mapo tofu, and the entire waitstaff watched and giggled as we ate the incredibly spicy, but very good, dish. Accompanied by 17 glasses of water.
author: Dimple B.

description: The food is pretty good - I especially enjoyed the har gow shrimp dumplings. A bit disappointed with the limited menu. I was looking for soup dumplings and egg custard but they didn't have either. Overall good food.
author: Connie S.

description: Bad quality dim sum. This place will never survive in chinatown or inner richmond. Everything tastes like they are made elsewhere and heated up here. Probably the same quality as the dim sum place in sfo.  I would not advise as a chinese native. On the other hand, if you never had dim sum and this is nearby, you may not be as disappointed as I am.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
I really don't understand why people line up for this place when there are so many other Chinese restaurants that are way better.  Both food and service were lacking at this place.

We ordered shrimp dumplings.  My friend took a bite and realized that the thick layer of dough was still raw.  We explained this to the waiter, and he took the dish away.  About 10 minutes later, the waiter brought back the SAME plate of dumplings after they were re-cooked - including the one from which my friend initially took a bite.  Oh yes he did.

I think MaMa badly needs lessons on cooking and food service procedures.
author: Shin C.

description: Superb on all fronts. Best enjoyed however for lunch and their scrumptious dim sum choices. Dinner entrees seem a bit expensive and the choices not as varied. Still these dishes totally rocked
author: Alfonso L.

description:
I actually like this place. Dim sum selection is not great but my favorites are all here, especially the rice rolls( shrimp and pork). Shumai, pork dumplings, and the spare ribs are really good too! Surprisingly the taste is actually decent enough(like the ones i had in Asia). This place is also convenient because i live nearby, and i prefer going here rather the richmond or sunset. 

One thing though about this place is that, service does GET slow when the place is crowded. Ive been here when its empty and crowded, when its empty, the service is awesome! My water gets refilled and they always ask how the food is. However, when its crowded, service is so slow, that it takes 15 mins to get your bill to come to you! so beware of that or take it as a pre-warning when you go to mama-ji. 

Big groups are not always good cause the place is too small, so youd have to be careful with that. 

But anyways, id always go here when its less crowded. Dim sum in the castro! Pretty rare, eh i might say.
author: Cavin T.

description:
"Is your entire party here?"

"Almost"

"It's a yes or no question" 

Expect a little attitude from the host. 


Other than that, great food. We had the dumplings (decent), cold noodles (meh), shu Mai (great), chow mein with chicken (delicious), spring rolls (also delicious)... Pork buns never showed up. 

Great beer list.
author: Jay S.

description: Do not miss this one of a kind restaurant.  The recipes apparently were the chef 's mother's recipes, and they are awesome.  Love this place.
author: Keith M.

description:
Food still gonna be good- i have no doubt about that.

Rules: follow your order and presented reservation of having people either fall in line or putting their name on a list. Do not try to FUBAR a list by seating acquaintances or friends first. That'll piss me off (especially when you're not full to even 3/5 capacity.
author: Brad L.

description: We ordered the sweet and sour pork, fried chicken with green beans, and shanghai dumplings. The sweet and sour pork looked tasty but was actually tasteless. However, fried chicken with green beans and shanghai dumplings were delicious! I would come back for the dumplings again.
author: Leesur S.

description: This place is a nice family run restaurant.  The food is good and the service was attentive. I recommend this place if ur looking for Chinese near the Castro.
author: Mike K.

description: Great food. Had the eggplant shrimp mushroom apptz and vegetarian pot sticker. I wanted to order more after my initial order and before my food came out, but the server wouldn't let me order more food bcus food would take long to cook. She wanted to get more ppl in the restaurant. Plus, more than one worker assumed I was getting take out rather than eat in. I'd go again hoping for a better experience.
author: Raymond G.

description:
I have been in the Castro over 10 years.  I eat out frequently.  

With that said, I didn't bother waiting to eat here due to the poor customer skills from the owner and employees.

A friend and I were waiting for a 3rd friend to get there who was about 2 minutes away.  We wanted to be seated and start ordering right away.  They refused to seat us until everyone in the party was present.  Now, I would normally agree with this policy if we wanted to be seated and not order (obviously taking up a table that someone else could have), but we wanted to start ordering right away.

The policy I understand is to maximize seating which allows them to generate more money for the business however I am not eating there for their convenience.  I am the one who will potentially give them money.  I mean, I am the customer right?

They claimed it was standard policy which it is for the most part with one exception.  When someone is ready to be seated and start ordering.  

Regardless, the owner basically stated that if we didn't like the policy that we could go somewhere else.  We did since the Castro has a lot of places we can choose to eat.  Our friend arrived 2 minutes later, and we walked away.

I won't bother with this place again.
author: Desmond P.

description:
Probably some of the best sezchuan, chinese, dim sum food I have ever had. Dry fried chicken with green beans were out of this world, perfectly seasoned, green beans fresh with a nice crunch, chicken melted in your mouth. Shanghai dumplings, shumai, and beef chow fun were also amazing. And it was super busy and the service was still fast and attentive. Going back again today for dim sum. Not a fan of the pork and cabbage boiled dumplings, but probably just because it didn't shine compared to everything else.

And so affordable compared to SF standards. Ordered all that and it was only 46 bucks.
author: Emily B.

description:
I'm going to give it another shot after a friend explained this is Catonese style. Not fair of me to give it a one star if that's not my food preference.


ORIGINAL BELOW:


I gave this place 3 times and had a very mediocre to terrible experience each time. 

I even tried easy things (like pork bun, spring roll, and cold noodle) and they were just mehhhhh. Tasted like airport quality. We ordered a dish off the specials and it was pure oil and 4 shrimp for $13. WTF?

I really really really wanted to like this place based on all the reviews, but after trying multiple dishes and bringing friends along to verify, I had three really bad experiences and will never go back. Now as a joke, my friends will say  "Do you want to go to MaMa Ji's" when we are picking a place to get some laughs.
author: Megan V.

description:
Quite a decent dim sum place in the Castro! I've been a few times with friends for brunch and their dim sum is tasty and fresh. The sizes are a little bit small for items like har gow but prices are still low, especially for the Castro.

I've enjoyed most of their typical dim sum dishes like har gow, siu mai, lo mai gai, and such. You can also try some of their Sichuan dinner items like the specialized Chongqing chicken, which is the Sichuan fillet fish in mala oil, fried. 

Expect the wait to be really long on the weekends on a sunny day and the service to be a bit scattered.
author: Kate M.

description: Today I drove out here to pick up some stuff from my family's house we stop by this  restaurant and they had the worst customer service I try to Oder my food is h young lady stuck her finger in my face And told me you see me work you need to hold on and all that happened was my son run up and said I want some soda she could only seen that he was disable and only 4 years old..... I was so mad I would never recommend the palace to nobody.
author: Andres J.

description: Quick and efficient even on a rainy Sunday afternoon. We ordered way too much of everything and managed to finish it all - it was delicious! Their XLB is not the best I've had, but they get 5 stars anyway because the food was so good overall and we got it all fresh and quickly. Can't really go wrong with anything on the dim sum menu. There was an infant in our party, for whom a high chair was available.
author: Namita D.

description: I was craving dim sum and MaMa Ji's didn't fail to deliver!  Deviin joined us on this adventure so we could enjoy more dim sum than we normally would. We had a wide assortment of yummy filled dumplings. The  pea sprout shrimp dumplings were my favorite but we also enjoyed pork-shrimp shu mai, pot stickers, sweet meat dumplings, sesame balls, won ton soup (surprisingly good an the sesame oil didn't overpower) and a few other items. We left full and happily full of dumplings!
author: Jack-Carla L.

description:
We came here for dinner one night and we were hoping to get great Chinese food since they had such high yelp reviews. Be aware that this is Not your standard Chinese restaurant. Chinese food from Szechuan province is definitely different and some of their dishes takes an acquired taste to enjoy it. We ordered the numbing fish dish which was a big letdown. It was basically just fish fillet deep-fried and a whole bunch of peppercorns numb your tongue not much else. I also ordered the beef and gravy and the flavor was just barely edible to me. The other dishes that we ordered were OK.
Most of the dishes were very salty even the fried rice. The place has a nice new modern feel to it. I have a variety of very good beer though they're fairly pricey starting from eight to $50. Definitely a trendy hip place to go to if you're into that. But if you just want real good Chinese food I drive across town and go to Chinatown. The service was very slowand the food arrived one at a time although most of the servers are nice.
author: Vjay R.

description:
Quaint and delicious little spot right of Market in the Castro. Great neighborhood feel, with friendly service and nice vibes. 

FOOD:

Delicious. I've never had a bad meal here, and It's great that they serve Dim Sum all day. Their Shui Mai is giant, and perfectly cooked. Steamed pork buns maybe my favorite in the city. It may sound weird, but their Dim Sum seems really... clean too? Just compared to some of the Dim Sum places in the city that can feel seedy or sticky or rushed, this is not like that at all.  Their non-Dim Sum menu is wonderful as well.  I've had their black bean noodles, their super spicy fish, and some of their more Americanized dishes like the Kung Pow chicken, all wonderfully cooked, generous portions and quick.

SERVICE:

non-invasive, quick, and freindly. No complaints. 

PRO TIP:

It can get a little warm in there, so try and sit on the right side, they often leave the door open and there is a nice breeze.
author: Patrick T.

description: Pick up for lunch, we ordered mo-po tofu, a cold noodles, and fried greens. The environment is decent for a Chinese restaurant, but to be honest, the taste is just okay in terms of lunch. We might try dim sum someday.
author: Peiyao Z.

description:
Brought my visiting family to Mama Ji's - they wanted Dim Sum. I'm not in the city that often so needed some help to find where to get our dim sum - and I found this place from Yelp. Huge success! 
Mama Ji's is a small restaurant on 18th near Castro - probably not good for groups unless you come at an off-peak time when they could slide tables together. You won't be here for the decor or the ambiance, but you'll come back for the food.
The dim sum were so much better than my standard go-to spot - fresher, interesting flavors, different types and varieties, buns with so-good fillings.
I'll be baack!
author: M B.

description:
I really wasn't impressed with this place.  We got take out, so this review is for the food only, not the service (which seemed to be good from what I could tell).

We ordered the Nam Yu Spareribs, the Triple "C" Wings (Crispy Caramelized Chili Wings), Shanghai Dumplings, and the Chicken Wonton Soup.  

The Chicken Wonton soup was okay, but nothing special.  The Shanghai dumplings were very dry, as if they had been sitting out for an extended amount of time.  The Nam Yu Spareribs were terrible.  Bland and gelatinous.  It was like someone had poured some cold gravy on top of them.  The Tripple "C" Wings were probably my favorite part of the meal, but they were basically a less flavorful version of the korean chicken wings served at Heung Yuen or San Tung.

It was all edible, but not worth a return trip.  Also, pretty expensive for the quality.
author: Brendan B.

description:
Naturally coming to San Francisco we were looking for a great little dim sum shop and I was excited when I heard about Mama Ji's on Yelp. Overall, it wasn't a terrible experience, it just lacked in a few really important areas. 

It took awhile to get a table on a Saturday afternoon, which is normal for a place like this, but took even longer just for the waitress to take our order. We had probably been seated 15-20 minutes before we even were asked if we wanted drinks, and then another 10-15 or so before she took our food order. After that it was downhill. It took over an hour for us to finally get all our food and eat, we were actually quite full when the manger (I assume, since she showed up later) came and asked if we had everything and we just asked for our check - she ran back, grabbed the 3-4 items we had received yet and brought them to the table. Just a really poor experience on a really busy day, I'm hopeful this isn't normal for them. 

In terms of food, it was actually quite good. The pork buns were great and we loved the spicy chili noodles. Excellent dish. The low score is more for the poor service than anything, they seemed to be way, way understaffed. I'd definitely like to go back and see if the service is any better.
author: Cory N.

description: So. Good. The Hot Numbing Fish is insanely delicious. Everything we had (about 8 different items) were all amazing.
author: Courtney M.

description: Four of us loved the crispy salt-baked shrimp. So much so, it was our favorite dish in 5 days of grazing San Francisco. The rest of the meal was good. The Dragon's Breath ginger drink was unusual.
author: M H.

description:
Uhm. Well first things first, I wasn't expecting this restaurant to be so...Americanized. I guess its location in the Castro was a pretty good hint that dim sum was not a common cuisine in that neighborhood, but still I was expecting something more authentic and Chinese-y when I was reading the yelp reviews. Instead of that rowdiness and loudness I normally associate with going out to eat dim sum, my experience at Mama Ji's was surprisingly quiet and civilized (I'm only half joking). The restaurant itself is a sit-down environment, rather than the round tables with dim sum cart pushers walking to and fro. What is normally a half sheet of 8x11 paper given with a little pencil at most other dim sum places, the ordering sheet here was a piece of paper complete with full-on color, sufficient English titles of the dishes, and pictures (that's practically unheard of!) I was so amazed for the first 5 minutes because I've never seen such a well-done ordering sheet in my life. I didn't even want to write on it, but I was hungry...so I did. 

Here, dim sum is served all day, which you order on their glossy colorful ordering sheet, or you can order from their regular bound menu. We only ordered dim sum at our particular visit last week, but we saw other people enjoying dishes off their regular menu that looked amazing! 

Just a few comments on the dim sum we ordered:
-for the most part, I was able to recognize the dishes on the menu, but their selection is extremely limited compared to a legit dim sum place. But it is reasonable to say they have a smaller menu since their size is a lot smaller and the restaurant does not have the capacity to offer as many dim sum selections as other established dim sum joints. 
- soup dumplings were served with tin cups underneath..what's up with that? Never have I ever been served soup dumplings that way (see pic.) it was just a bit off-putting for me, and ruined the experience of eating them as all the soup would fall out when you peel the dumpling off the cup. Oh, and also, they're tiny as hell. I could eat one in one bite if I really wanted to. (PS: make your own soup dumpling sauce with the vinegar, soy sauce, and chili oil.) 
- shrimp shumai was on the better side of ok. Meat was juicy but it tasted a little bit sweeter than what I'm used to tasting with shrimp shumais?
- rice roll plates were close to 75% rice roll and 25% meat (in our case, we ordered shrimp rice rolls, and there were only 3 pieces of shrimp lying in a huge bed of rice sheet). We did not finish this dish because it just did not taste right with the disproportionate ratio.
-pea sprout shrimp dumpling: I DO recommend this dish. It's awesome, try it.
- steamed pork buns was too dry for my taste. Bleh.
- lotus rice order was made traditional and was wrapped with not only the tea leaf, but also two layers of paper. Talk about really unwrapping your meal before you eat it. Made with dried shrimp and salted duck yolk, which are traditional ingredients, but over all, it tasted a lil bland.

In general, I do not consider myself a picky person but after reading what I wrote in this review, I am reconsidering that conception. I do say that I enjoyed my meal here at Mama Ji's but not as much as I could have, knowing that I've had much much better dim sum experiences. Also, the prices are higher, with portions smaller, for what I've had before, which comes to no surprise, given its location. Overall, I cannot see myself making a special trip back to this place for dim sum when there are way better places in Chinatown, but if I ever do find myself in that neighborhood with a killer craving for dim sum, yall already know I'll be at Mama Ji's.
author: Kristi L.

description:
The food here is delicious, all the time, consistently.  I have eaten there alone, with friends, lunch, dinner, day night.  

So so so so good.
Service is good too.

Love me some Mama Ji's!
author: maker of p.

description: Went as a group to Mama Ji's recently. The food was excellent, the service was slow. If you're starving and can't wait 10 minutes to get a menu and something to drink, you're better off going somewhere else. However, if you can wait, then this place is worth it. The pork steam buns were great as well as the green beans! I couldn't replicate or find another place that could. I usually always never finish my plates when we go out, but there was nothing left once I was done! Will definitely be coming here again!
author: Jessica L.

description: Bougie and overpriced. The waitress kept going to our table with someone else's order. Four plates of food was already $30. Not worth it. If you want good dim sum, go to Oakland.
author: Thu L.

description: This place is delicious! It's a little spot in between homes. Hidden little jem. Although it was small the place has really good food. Had a few beers on draft with my husband and then from the chow mien and dumplings sooo good. And the waitress she was very nice, she's all by herself waiting all the tables and she was very lovely.
author: Cindy H.

description:
Very friendly and comfortable place, but food only average.
I think I'd return, but not rush to do so.
Prices reasonable.
author: IQuack D.

description: Chinese restaurant with great food, clean minimalist decor, really friendly staff - I'll take it!!! The food was above average. Just beware that when they say spicey they are not kidding. The eggplant dish leaves yu craving it again the next day; the long beans are very fresh and well done; I try not to eat a lot of gluten but everyone at the table said that the noodles with black bean sauce was near perfect.
author: Ina D.

description: Have you heard an expression that a dirty restaurant bathroom often means a dirty kitchen? Well, Mama Ji's restroom was extremely dirty and shabby last time I was there with my friends. Clean place is as important as quality food. I couldn't relax and enjoy my meal at that restaurant. I worried that my plates could not be washed well etc. In fact, the table we were sitting at, was sticky. I have to say though, I've been there a few months ago, hopefully they upgraded their restrooms.
author: Halyna S.

description:
Nestled in a quiet residential neighborhood, MaMa Ji's serves up clean, quality Chinese (more specifically, Szechuan) cuisine. I've had a good share of authentic Szechuan food and I believe MaMa Ji's borders more on Szechuan fusion, in a good way. Sometimes it's nice to get away from the yelling waiters running back and forth from the kitchen, which is a common scene in most authentic Chinese establishments. The entrees can be shared or enjoyed individually.

I got the Noodles with Chili Bean Paste ($8.75). For some reason, I was expecting a noodle soup, but this is literally cooked noodles with a thick layer of sauce on top. It also came with a lot more vegetables (peas and carrots) than I envisioned. The sauce is not too spicy and makes the dish a comforting, non-oily dinner option.

My friend got the Fish Fragrant Eggplant ($9.95), which is actually vegetarian (they just use the same sauces that would traditionally be paired with fish I believe). It was a bit spicy, but quite delicious, and I was jealous.

There were many local, almost-next-door couples and individuals dining here; the table next to us said this was their favorite go-to dinner spot. I loved that the food wasn't overloaded with salt, MSG, and oil, as Chinese food usually goes.
author: Jessica F.

description: Great dim sum!  Much better than some of the hole-in-the-wall shops. Good quality and the menu makes it easy to select.
author: Alan P.

description: Love Mama Ji's. Had the dry chicken and green beans - soooo good. Wish I could eat it for dinner tomorrow, too. And the food comes out super fast. Looking forward to coming back and having more sometime soon.
author: Jeremy B.

description:
My brother has been talking about how great this place is for quite awhile and one lazy Saturday he suggested we try it for lunch. He warned me ahead of time that there might be a wait but since we weren't starving and it was a warm sunny day, we decided it didn't really matter. We totally lucked out and found a parking spot right in front of the place (usually parking is at a premium in this neighborhood) -  we were already off to a good start...

Brother put us on the waiting list (we were #4) and no more than 5 minutes later, we were ushered into the bustling restaurant. 

We decided to order the pork buns, pork & shrimp shumai, shrimp & pea sprout dumplings and the shanghai dumplings. The service was quick and the food hot and tasty. There was a line outside the whole time we were there, but never once did we feel rushed to finish our steamy treats.  

My only wish was that the shanghai dumplings (aka soup dumplings) were more soupy. I was expecting to bite into the plump little dumpling and taste a lusciously flavorful broth like I did when I ate my very first Xiao Long Bao at Joe's Shanghai...but that was NYC, and well, this is not. It was good, but more soupi-ness would only serve to enhance the meaty morsel.

I'd definitely go back and try some of the other dumplings on the menu, it all looked great. And the best part, the prices were very reasonable.
author: Rach D.

description:
Not recommended.
We were (politely) asked to leavej, by the owner, in order to accommodate patrons waiting for a table, although we just finished our last bite of food and were seated only 40 minutes prior.
The service is horrible, which was noted by other reviewers.  For example, the appetizers came out last.  
Dumplings were served on paper that stuck to them.
The plus, interesting food.  But, you can get good food in many SF restaurants with better service.  
I do not recommend dining here.
author: Todd A.

description: What a gem! The food is decently priced and delicious! Service is on point and attentively waits on you as you eat. You don't feel as if they are waiting for you to leave as soon as possible so you'll feel like you can enjoy yourself. Nice ambiance too! Definitely returning here!
author: Janette L.

description:
From the reviews I had high hopes for my mid-afternoon snack, but dry fried beef was too greasy, batter-y, and had too much msg. The sesame balls were decent, but too greasy as well. The tea was ok (a tad expensive,) and I was not convinced that the tea pot was very clean. Service was good, but her hair was tied up really loose, and I kept feeling paranoid that she would shed hair into my dish. 

Not sure what others saw in here, but I was unimpressed.
author: Sneha P.

description:
What can I say?  I am crazy for Dim Sum.

Ma Ma Ji's does not disappoint.  Very fresh and delicious!

Always get prompt and courteous service.

And a real bargain, very reasonable prices.

I am so happy MaMa Ji's is in the Castro.
author: Daniel P.

description:
Came here hungover on New Year's. Mostly decided to come here because we were too lazy and hungover to go into the Richmond or Sunset neighborhood.

3 stars for food and price. Dim sum here is legit. Not the tastiest dim sum ever, but at least it tasted healthy. Also it's on the pricey side. I think everything cost at least 25-50% times more than your typical dim sum restaurant. 

We ordered everything on the menu times 2. Turns out that's a lot of food for 6 people! They served everything in rounds. After about the 4th round of food, we started asking every time if there was more coming hoping the answer would be no.

Some of my favorite things about Mama Ji's are
- green bell peppers stuffed with shrimp 
- sweet rice with egg and sausage filling
- shrimp stuffed eggplant
- good selection shu mai and other dumplings. they have at least 3 different types of shu mai. omg. also the deep fried meat dumpling is excellent.
- their beer, cider, and wine selection

Next time I might skip on the pan fried turnip dish and the shanghai dumplings.

I do give them an extra star because MaMa Ji's had a warm and cozy vibe compared to other dim sum restaurants. Location is great too. Healthy tasting dim sum is a nice change too.

Overall, I had a good experience at Mama Ji's. I'll definitely be back if it's convenient. Also to try some of the noodles I saw people eating that looked delicious.
author: Veronica T.

description: Authentic Chinese cuisine here. The food is great and the service is nice. Mandarin works here.
author: Teng-hao C.

description: I found this place through my SF trip in 2015 , really love Shrimp Eggplant and all of DimSum dishes over here , strongly recommend to our friends and family.
author: Bao N.

description:
Loved the garlic pea shoots and the spicy shrimp with green onions and jalapeno. Asked for montepulciano, a red, and they brought me white. No, i said, i ordered the red. Out came the red, chilled like a white. What?
Tried the chicken wings and they are very sweet, maybe a plum sauce glaze. Duck egg pumpkin strips are more tempura than duck egg, try Hakka on clement in the richmond for an authentic version.
Definitely did not feel the schezuan vibe, nothing was particularly spicy though we asked for it to be so. The chili oil on the table is oily, not spicy or hot, really a bit seedy and tired.
Ok, so what was good? The vegetables in the food were fresh and well prepared, crispy yet tender. Same for the shrimp, perfectly cooked. The garlic pea shoots were a star, tasty, silky, and a bit off the beaten taste path.
Kids are welcome, a pair were doing homework while awaiting their chow mein.
Restaurant is clean, comfortable, well priced items and friendly. Just don't expect schezuan food, i tried and didn't find any. Parking is plentiful on the street outside. Definitely a neighborhood restaurant, welcoming and reliable.
author: Kelly K.

description:
I've eaten from Mama Ji's 3 times. The first time I thought it was awesome, but since then it seems to have gotten a lot worse. The dim sum is really subpar for SF - the BBQ pork buns are decent but the pork shumai was mediocre, and the shrimp dumplings were nearly uneatable. 

Food aside, the service is terrible. The second time I went to Mama Ji's, we had been waiting ~15 minutes for a check at the end. At one point, one of the waitresses looked at me, I made the hand signal to indicate we wanted a check, and then she just looked away and ignored it! I've never had someone purposefully ignore me trying to pay. It's probably because they're so busy with the delivery, but even so that was unacceptable for me.

The third time I ate from there was delivery (I swear I'd never bother going back to the restaurant after that service), and they made a number of errors in the order. 

On the plus side, their Szechuan fare is better than their dim sum, and they have really good coffee.
author: Andrew H.

description:
I had written a tip/review about this place a year ago. It had just opened (I think I was there within the first week of opening). At the time, I thought the food was fantastic and even said it was the best Dim Sum I had ever had. 

However, I went there again recently and was underwhelmed. The service was awful and the dim sum tasted mediocre. I am not sure what happened but I wish i had the same experience as my initial visit. The dim sum is not bad, it just didn't have the freshness that I had tasted the first time I was there, and the wait staff was unattentive and different from before.
author: A. M.

description:
We had the Pan Fried Pot Stickers for an appetizer. They were pretty good, but were helped by dashes of chili and soy sauces. We also had the Triple "C" Wings. They were also good, but the skin should have been a bit crispier. (Full disclosure: I'm totally spoiled by the Angel Wings at Marnee Thai against which nothing has ever come close.)

For our entrees, we had the Chongqing Chicken and the Dry Fried Beef with Green Beans. The chicken was crispy out the outside and juicy on the inside with just enough spice. The beef was tender, but, oddly, not dry (considering it's supposed to be from the name). The beans were average, however.
author: Paul L.

description: Good service.  LOVE the wings.. They're bomb. Everything was great. My favorite dish was the bean sprouts! It fresh and yummy！I will definitely go back!
author: Emily H.

description: The food is good.  The wait staff Steven is great but a female waitress needs to be more customer service oriented.  She was non-engaged and borderline rude!
author: T L.

description: Takes forever to get your food and food is either to salty or had no flavor. Super dissapointed with their food. Chow mein has no flavor, fried rice is plain, i could make better fried rice. Just dissapointing i would bot recommend this llace at all. Deserves no stars.
author: Thomas E S.

description: I really like this non-traditional dim sum spot. You order off of the menu and they bring it to you like a typical restaurant vs. using carts. I have been a few times and liked everything I have had here. They also randomly have good Belgian beers on tap. Service is friendly and the vibe is casual. All around a nice neighborhood spot.
author: Jessica H.

description: Don't order anything fried here, you get things soaked in oil. The steamed things were pretty good. Overall flavor was lacking (had to add shoyu to most of it) and the oiliness left us with much to desire. Service was horrible...there practical add none and food was just dumped on our table. And the restaurant wasn't even full.
author: Donny S.

description:
Awesome. Simply awesome. One of the best dim sum places outside of Chinatown or Milbrae. 

Eat here, Don't let this place close, people!  Support restaurant of  quality in the baffling zone of food mediocrity that is the Castro. 

That is all.
author: Luis F.

description: If your don't feel like going to the Richmond for dim sum, this is a great alternative. You order on a paper, and with your waiter.  The dishes come out piping hot.  seseme balls was good, soup dumpling was light skin and soup.
author: Tony T.

description:
One of the best places for Chinese food in downtown SF! This is my go-to spot for comfort Chinese food around Castro and Mission districts. 

MaMa Ji's food features Dim-Sum for lunch, and Szechuan food for dinner. You won't find stuff like Orange Chicken, or General Tso's Chicken here. Instead, you will find authentic Sichuan food there. How many "Szechuan" restaurants offer MaPo Toufu? Not so many. And among those, how many would actually call it "Madam Chen's MaPo Tofu" (how this dish is called in Sichuan)? None but MaMa Ji's. 

I came here for dinner one day being extremely hungry as I skipped lunch on that day. I was planning to get some noodles or so, until I saw their special of the day "Braised Chicken with Chestnuts". I have never had that dish anywhere outside of home kitchens. I know I had no choice but to try that. It did not disappoint me at all. The rich flavors of chicken, shitake mushrooms and chestnuts remind of home and my mom's kitchen. I ordered some shrimp and chive dumplings too and they were so fresh and delicious. I can't wait for the next time to go back and try some other dishes!
author: Christine C.

description: The Mama C's wings might be some of the best in the City!  A little spicy, little sweet, crunchy and Juicy!  I love this place and the staff is excellent.
author: Matt W.

description:
It's a pretty long wait for okay dim, but a solid place nevertheless. Don't go here hungry, because: 

1) You have to wait a bit before getting a table and the restaurant doesn't take reservations.

2) Once you've ordered, the food immediately comes out, but it comes out piping hot so you'll burn yourself if you don't wait long enough. If you wait for the steam to die down a little, and you think you've waited long enough, give it a little more time because you're just going to burn your mouth again.

I was pretty excited to see that they serve Ritual coffee, and while it's unlimited refills, the coffee was somewhat watery.

The dried bean curd skin roll and sweet rice with shrimp wrapped in lotus leaf were probably my favorite. The pork shumai was better than the shrimp shumai.
author: Tiffany L.

description: If you are hungry. If you like cocaine. This is the place to be. I swear, there is cocaine in their BBQ pork buns because they ARE SO GOOD! Like, sometimes I'll be sitting in my living room, and I'll be like, "oh, I gotta get some pork buns ASAP!" Other than a long line, which is totally worth it - nothing could keep me away from this place!
author: Tanya K.

description:
One of the reason that this restaurant has become popular in the area is that there is no other good Chinese food in this neighborhood. We had tried this restaurants a few times. Every time when we went we tried different things. The food is really just ok. 

Often restaurant gets busy and the quality of food degrades significantly. Last time we were in the restaurant we ordered the snow pea pod ( peas leaves ). The stem of the pea leaves was so tough we had to spit out most part of this dish. (It's supposed to be tender and crisp at the same time.) We talked to the owner of the restaurant and she justified the dish was just fine because she had it for lunch. 

If you really know food, before you go you might need to curb your expectation. It is really not a 4 * rating like you seen on Yelp.
author: Ben L.

description: A decent place if you can't get to the avenues for dim sum or don't want to wait in line. We tried the cold noodles, shanghai dumplings, pork siu mai, and rice noodle shrimp dumplings. The cold noodles were unappetizing and flavorless, so perhaps they have other better noodle dishes. The dim sum was decent but falls apart; the shrimp constantly slipped out of the rice noodle dumpling and a shanghai dumpling popped open. The good thing is that service is quick but I probably won't be back and would rather drive a bit further for my dim sum.
author: Jamie B.

description:
This place is great - good quality dim sum for a very affordable price.  

Everything we ordered was on point and up to par with dim sum that I've had in the past.  However I'd say that nothing was had was especially unique or out of this world amazing.  They had a good selection of dim sum on their day to day menu (shu mai, pork buns, turnip cake, sesame balls, egg custard buns etc.) and also had some daily specials (i.e. cabbage and pork dumplings).  

There was a bit of a wait when we got there but once we were seated the service was fairly quick and efficient.  The pricing was also very reasonable, especially compared to Yank Sing.  We ordered 12 dishes (which was more than enough for 4 people) and the check only came out to $55!  

I'll definitely head back here for dim sum but will also be back to try their Sichuan dinner menu!
author: Dayna S.

description: Good spot for the only dim sum place in the Castro!! The place is tiny so don't expect dim sum carts being pushed around. The food is delicious and made fresh to order. I'm impressed! Service is not so fast but the servers are friendly. I'm giving it 3 stars because it is pricey!! But the food is def worth 4 stars.
author: j m.

description:
Okay, this place is fantastic. Hooray for some great food in the Castro! And some of the best Chinese food I've had in the city. I totally stand by that. 

Both the dim sum and the wok-fried entrees were excellent. And dim sum for dinner! I don't know why this isn't more common. Why wouldn't I want that? Why wouldn't ANYONE want that? 

We got the pork buns, fried turnip, seafood shumai, and shanghai dumplings to start. Everything was a cut above what I was expecting, except the shanghai dumplings, which were not as delicate as the best ones are. Still tasty. We got a beef with green beans entree, and it, too, was better than I was expecting.

The desserts are amazing. The egg custard lava bun might be my new favorite thing, and the black-bean-filled sesame balls were rich and delicious.
author: vanessa r.

description: The best place for authentic Chinese in the Castro/Noe/Mission area. Particularly like the steamed dimsum, as well as the Nam Yu Spareribs.
author: Alice W.

description: Fried pot stickers and shrimp dumplings were amazing!!! Well priced, cute location (we found parking), clean and friendly.
author: Kat A.

description:
A little gem of a restaurant on 18th street in the Castro district. We came here near closing and ordered two dishes:
-Steamed fish with tofu in hunan chili sauce
-Boiled beef slices in fiery sauce

Both were numbingly (quite literally) authentic and spicy! In general, szechuan food is spicy and on the greasy side but I would recommend coming here. it's definitely a delicious place to grab food but be prepared for the numbing kind of spicy!
author: Lillian C.

description:
My boyfriend and I use to live at nob hill (close to Chinatown). And when we moved to duboce triangle, we were devastated at how far we were from any good dim sum. Luckily we found this place!

They have good dim sum selection including some very well made xiaolongbao. The Sichuan dishes are amazing as well. And you can wash it all down with some Belgium beer!

The place is clean and well maintained. Service is great and with a smile. The owners are a very sweet local couple who seem to really love what they do.
author: Hiyasmin D.

description: This small restaurant boasts rich flavors, spicy spices and friendly staff. The wings were enormous and full of meat and the garlic broccoli made me smile. Ordered much food expecting leftovers but ended up eating it all because it was so good.
author: Mike S.

description:
"Me and my girlfriend went to this place. We came in and the guy said anywhere so we sat near the window. The servers all ignored us until 10 mins after, the lady gave everyone a water bottle except us. Odd that everyone else got served before us, now I
felt that this is just sexist... The food is okay not the best. Definitely not coming back anymore!"
author: Mimi Y.

description:
I used to come here a lot, but after extensive reflection, I have decided the szechuan food is just too oily.  And there's very, very few vegetables in any dish with meat.  Especially green vegetables.  So even though MaMa Ji's is spicy and delicious, and the staff is exceptionally friendly, I should eat better.  So I've been going to Szechuan Home, Spices II, and Chili House up in Richmond instead.  They're a lot further away, but I feel better after eating at them, and they're pretty delicious too.

Also, I wish they had chinese beer.  I like a pilsner when eating very spicy food.  Pilsner is delicious after some szechuan peppercorns.
author: Jon E.

description:
HOW DO YOU NOT HAVE FREE TEA!? THIS IS A DIM SUM RESTAURANT.

Rant aside, I was scrambling to find a good dim sum restaurant to take a coworker who on the scale of 1-10 in whiteness, a solid 7. And a quick search turned up Mama Ji's. I rolled up on a Sunday morning with an intense hangover at 10am and was quickly seated. This is like a weird Americanized dim sum brunch place. Highlights include: the rice roll wrappers, har gow, char siu bao and stuffed eggplant with shrimp. And the meal came out to be $40 for 3 with tip, so while it's a little pricier than typical dim sum, it's about average for brunch in the city.

I would recommend coming here if this is your first foray into dim sum and would like a nice Americanized introduction with a little handholding. But if you want an actual dim sum restaurant, look elsewhere. It's seriously a tragedy when there's no chicken feet, congee, or free tea.
author: Tony H.

description:
This place is over-hyped. I get it though, it's the only place in the hood that serves dim sum.

Turnip cake was very salty, steam custard bun filling was grainy, Dan Dan noodles were bitty and the sauce was gelatinous.
author: Jeanne C.

description: Good neighborhood dim sum place, nice quick service, no long lines. Easy ordering. Kids liked the food. Hit the spot for Sunday breakfast.
author: Angus H.

description: Green beans were served hot off the grill; hot but not scalding.  They were also crunchy but not raw.  The insides of the beans were definitely cooked and exterior is not oily at all.  Good amount of garlic and onions and not salty like most Chinese restaurants.  The tofu fish we ordered was pretty standard.  The thing that stood out in this Chinese restaurant is the selection of good quality beers!  When does that ever happen in a Chinese restaurant?  That doesn't even happen often in a bar.  Chimay and Delirium to name a couple good beers available.  Service is hospitable, but they don't come by often enough to make sure we have enough napkins and water.  Total bill including tips is $45 for two dishes and a beer.  Not cheap at all, but it's good Chinese food for sure.  If you can find parking in the area and want Chinese food, then eat here.
author: Byron L.

description:
Best. I eat here at least once a week. 

I love the food and the atmosphere at Mama Ji's. The staff are super friendly. It's unpretentious and reasonably priced. I highly recommend the cilantro shrimp dumplings and dried fried green beans. If you like spicy Chinese food that's well prepared and fresh, then this is the place for you. 

The restaurant can get overwhelmingly loud on Friday and Saturday nights but what good restaurant isn't? The food is worth it. They also have beers on tap which I really appreciate.
author: Katie C.

description: Expensive, average dum sum. Potstickers contained gristle. Shanghai dumplings fell apart. I'll stick with pretty much anywhere in the Richmond.
author: Christian W.

description: Always come for dim sum whenever I come to SF for brunch. Beat out rivals even from Chinatown and am Asian so my food palate is right on for such. Very nice owners just that the neighborhood is very hard to find parking and the wait can be long if you come right at noon.
author: Huan T.

description:
Delicious!

I came here with a couple friends after spending a few (very) happy hours at Badlands on Friday. Dimsum and spicy Chinese food isn't something I usually think of eating after having a couple drinks, but now that you can, it's fantastic!
