We ordered way too much food, but in so doing, got to try a number of dishes. We ordered the Shanghai dumplings, shrimp dumplings, Chongqing chicken, pickled long beans with pork, and spicy fish with tofu. 

Is the dim sum here among the best in the Bay Area? Uh no, duh. You're in the Castro- you just stumbled here from a bar. What do you think? Is it good, fairly authentic, and conveniently located in the Castro? You betcha.

As far as the dishes were concerned, they were delicious. Most were salty, spicy, and tasty in the best possible way. But the Chongqing chicken really stood out- crispy and perfectly seasoned.

The waiters weren't bad- patiently going through the menu with us, and attentively refilling our water glasses. I'll definitely be back!
author: Terry N.

description:
Okay, this probably isn't a restaurant intended for vegetarians to like but I am going to review it anyway. Because it is just one more shitty restaurant in the Castro. 

I ordered a few dishes. I got the fried pumpkin with duck egg, kung pao tofu and some veggie buns. I was expecting the veggie buns to be what they were but the pumpkin could have been amazing. It was gross. Imagine the worst, flavorless, fried-something you ever had...it was like that. Just a heaping pile of flavorless fried food. 

The kung pao was ok. Ok in the sense that if my friends dragged me there and I got that I wouldn't bitch too much. 

The service was a lot like the food, mediocre.
author: Jerry S.

description: They used to have really good food with bad service.  Now they have both--bad food, and bad service.  Last night's nam yu spare ribs were tough, and the chicken with asparagus had an oddly bitter, acrid flavor.  The pork dumplings weren't bad, but how bad can dumplings be?  They left one thing off of our delivery order (shanghai dumplings) and then refused to do anything to fix it, even though we had paid for it.  Then mama herself screamed over the phone that she was really busy.  Well, perhaps not for long....
author: Kevin W.

description:
Food is pretty good. They have both Sichuan and Cantonese food. Haven't tried the Cantonese ones yet, but so far I'm a fan of their mapo tofu and boiling fish. That pepper flavor was pretty strong.

Kinda surprised this place has ~4 stars reviews, cuz yummy Chinese restaurants usually only receive 2~3 stars.
author: Meg L.

description:
Basket case.

Not a good thing: http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/basket+case

Really good thing: Pea sprout shrimp dumplings served in a beautiful wood basket. Part of an elevated dim sum experience with minimal oil and and maximum fresh flavor.

Served with a Ritual Americano so smooth it didn't even need milk or sugar. Less than $10 for the pair including tax and tip.

Returned to try both the shrimp rice rolls and Kung Pao chicken. On the latter requested light on the oil and got heavy on the chicken and nuts. Both were delicious.

Finally couldn't say no to the Steamed Golden Lava Buns. Interior was filled with a sweet but not overwhelming egg custard. Really enjoyed.

Throughout both visits was impressed by the attentiveness of the staff whether they were keeping my water glass full or suggesting healthier menu items.

Space isn't too large with about 10 - 12 tables including a few outside. Order is placed on individual menus. Everything looks so good it's easy to take a long time trying to choose.

You just might find yourself helpless trying not to eat everything.
author: Jason B.

description:
Pretty average dim sum. I expected SF to have better dim sum, and I heard Chinatown was pretty disappointing, so I headed all the way to the Castro. Not the biggest place (had to wait to seat 3), and parking was not the easiest to find--especially on those huge slopes!

I thought the prices were very reasonable, until I realized $4 only got 3 potstickers! Oh well, that meant it was just averagely priced. My friends really liked the meat ball (I didn't), and the pork buns were probably my favorite. The zhong zi were great, and Shanghai soup dumplings, sesame balls, and potstickers were all solid, but nothing really stood out to be honest.

The inside wasn't as dirty as I expected, obviously a plus. Relatively crowded. I would suggest coming here in twos if you come during peak hours (like weekend lunch) so you won't have to wait as long.
author: Kimberly Y.

description:
Not bad food, but not great. The wonton soup was pretty good, but the shrimp and chicken shumai were pretty dry. We had appetizers so I can't really speak to the more adventurous dishes. I'd be willing to try it again just to make sure I didn't miss something special.

Sake was good at least! They served it in a square cup which was pretty funny. My not-so-quick friend didn't realize you're supposed to drink out of the corners so he spilled all over himself. It might be worth going just for that.
author: Mike W.

description: One of our favorite local restaurants it might even be our favorite place in the city! Their hot and sour soup is the cure all for everything. Everything we have ordered has been fresh and delicious.
author: Anastasia J.

description:
Been here a few times now, and it's definitely one of my favorites in the area. It does commonly get busy, so there can be a wait, and while the prices aren't bad, it's not cheap either. Portions are reasonable overall. Service is also okay, but not great. I sometimes have to ask multiple times for something before getting it. But regardless, the food is great, so I'll keep coming back. Many like it for the dim sum, but I'm all about the dinner food. 

This most recent visit was a Friday night around 7:30pm. Fairly full inside, with another 5-7 parties waiting outside. Happened to slide in at just the right time to get a table for 2 with no wait. Though there were a couple more right after me who had to wait. Turnover does seem pretty good overall though, from what I've observed.

Shared a few items between 2 of us:
- Fish with Chiles and Sichuan Pepper: this is an absolute staple for me, and I've had it 3-4 times now. It's roughly a fish soup with a very oily and spicy chili-based broth, with white fish, mung beans, and cabbage. This is one of my favorite incarnations of the soup, after having had it 4-5 places total. Though after having it this most recent time, I do have to concede that there's not that much fish in there, and overall the portion is fairly small compared to that at Chef Zhao's, another I had recently, for a comparable price ($2-3 difference). Still, it's damn good and not something I think I'll skip anytime soon.
- Mama Ji's country-style shrimp: tried this for the first time. a mix of shrimp (maybe 10-15), bell peppers, and green onions. A little spicy too. Loved the veggies, and the flavor of the dish on the whole, but would have liked more shrimp, and this is coming from a veggie-lover. 
- Stir-Fried Pea Leaves with Garlic: Another relative staple for me. This comes out something like a cross between stir-fried spinach and broccoli rabe, but more on the spinach side of flavor, being a bit lighter. Delicious, and I personally loved putting it in the broth from the fish with chiles, letting it soak that in a bit. 
- Chinese Broccoli with Garlic: Something I've had less here, but still quite good. Not a lot to say about it, but a good serving size of the Chinese broccoli. Came out nicely cooked so that it still had the firmness to it but was a little soft.

Overall, came to about $50 with tip I think. And another wonderful visit. I'll definitely be back.
author: Kris K.

description:
Amazing Sichuan style food - I am totally a fan of their dishes, especially the ones with Sichuan pepper infused into the food. Chongqing chicken being the best - their Mapo - Tofu (Mother Chen's Bean Curd) is phenomenal as well. Additional sides to definitely try: Fish with chilies and Sichuan pepper,  and the Stir fried Pea shoots with Garlic. 

Friendly service!! Place tends to be very busy an a bit loud. They get 4/5 stars, only because of the variability in how the entrees taste from one day to the next. The same dish can be amazing (5 starts) on one day, and good (4 stars, good but not great) another day.
author: Sudhamsu J.

description:
We came here expecting a wait (like most dim sum places on a Sunday) and were told it would be 30 mins for a table for 2. It was actually more like 10 minutes which was awesome!

We ordered about 8 different dishes and it was a bit too much food for us but it was nice to have some for lunch today. My boyfriend's favorite was the rice in the leaf and the pork shumai. My favorite was the cilantro shrimp dumplings. The service was great and the food was good. Only complaint was that one of the dishes (I unfortunately can't remember what it was called now) that was just meat had a TON of bones and fat in it, so most pieces were inedible. However the ones that were edible tasted awesome.
author: Alexandra W.

description:
A much appreciated addition to the selection of restaurants in the Castro, which, let's be real, is nothing to write home about in general.

I think they do Szechuan better than they do dimsum. The fish in chili oil dish we ordered was fantastic, whereas the dumplings we ordered were not bad, but not great either.

The lady somehow figured out I spoke Mandarin, and proceeded to call me, not "handsome" or "good-looking", but "pretty". I'll take it. One more star for you!
author: jon y.

description: Highly recommend their steamed BBQ pork buns, har gao (the wrapper was perfection - so delicate!), and the red bean buns!
author: Camille E.

description: I went there and got the Chongqing Chicken as well as the Chive Shrimp Dumplings. The chicken was pretty standard and pretty good. There was a lot more chicken and less chili than a lot of other places. It didn't mean it was less spicy than other places. That was a plus, they unfortunately spilled some chicken and I was hoping they would give us more since it was their fault...but they did the hit and run :(. The dumplings were definitely housemade. It made it hard to eat since once you took a bite out, the meat just fell. But otherwise the dumplings were very good, even though it was like a dollar per dumpling.
author: Victor D.

description: Tried this place for the first time last night. We went for dinner. The dumplings were really good. The fried rice was a little underfried. It wasn't too busy and we got a seat right away. Service was good.
author: Eddie K.

description:
Dim Sum in the Castro: not a promising header. But this place is fantastic! It's not Koi Palace (in flavor and price), but it is extraordinarily good dim sum for the city. Up there with HK Lounge and other Richmond joints. 

We had the Har Gow (perfectly chewy, good snap to them, great flavor), the shrimp and pea sprout dumplings (very fresh, perfectly cooked), the shrimp-stuffed eggplant (great flavor, not too greasy), the shrimp rice roll (hand-pulled, great filling, soy was a little on the sweet side for my taste) and the XLB / shanghai dumpling. The only one that wasn't fantastic was the XLB (not a ton of soup inside, and made in the little tin cups which is usually a signal of a less delicate wrapper - accurate in this case), and even that was pretty good. 

I will absolutely be back!
author: Rebecca W.

description: Have been to this restraunt twice now, once at dinner time and once at lunch time. We didn't realize at dinner time they didn't serve dim sum so we were a bit disappointed by that. But the second time we went at the right time the food was good and very reasonably priced! I would definitely suggest going there just during the times they serve dim sum.
author: Nina S.

description:
CRAAZY GOOD!  It's strange to say this but this might be the best dim sum and also wonton soups that i've had in san francisco   I liked it better than the famous and celebrated Yank Sing and without all the pretense and high prices.  Excellent service, and honestly, i could go back every day this week just to have their wonton soup.  Whoever called this Americanized is wrong...this is the authentic Asian cooking.  My friend from China who first told me to go here said, "So great!  This is what you would have if someone cooked well for you in their home."

I'm in love with this spot.  Who knew you could get better dim sum in the Castro than the Inner Richmond or Chinatown?  Back tomorrow!

(My only mini-criticisms are that they need 'hot mustard' to serve on the side with the dumplings...AND like the other guy said THEY NEED BETTER CHILI OIL on the tables.  not hot at all!  Also the tables are really too close for comfort so i would only go on an off-time of day.   Or sit outside at nice sidewalk tables.  Oh and it IS a little tacky that tea is $3.  But the food so great that I can't even take a star away for all that.
author: T S.

description: I have to echo Carol C's sentiments. The food has declined precipitously. The service has gotten to terrible territory. The table next to us ordered chive and chicken dumplings they got chive and shrimp and the waitress wouldn't take it off their bill. The waitress tried to argue that they are actually the same dish... Ridiculous. I used to love this place no idea what happened.
author: Joann C.

description:
Nice enough spot for a Szechuan meal by the Castro, although it seemed nearly half of the dishes on the menu were vegetarian (could be in your favor, but not so fitting for my carnivorous tendencies), and do be weary of which dishes are super-spicy (labeled on the menu with three chili icons).

Already spicy with a single chili menu icon was an order of Shredded Pork with Garlic Sauce. Flavorful, but I am glad I had a beverage at my side. I also was eating family style with a group, but simply could not hold up very long with their order of Spicy Fish Fillets with Flaming Chili Oil! Do I need to point out how many chili icons that dish received?

Our vegetable dish was much tamer: Stir-Fried Pea Sprouts with Garlic. So, for two out of three plates, I practically was well off.

We did not come for dim sum, but it might be nice to try out for that.
author: Garett T.

description:
This place is GREAT! 
It's run by a wonderful couple who pay very close attention to their customers and will gladly fix or change anything that you don't like. They have GF and Veg options so we were very happy.  

We will be back.
author: Min M.

description: I really like this neighborhood joint. The food is excellent, especially the pot stickers and dry fried green beens. But the fact that they have great beers and the food prices are really low makes this a standard in my restaurant rotation
author: David B.

description:
Was looking through yelp this morning to find a new dim sum spot.  Wanted to try something sit-down vs. cafeteria style.  Mama Ji's was the shining star among many.  Needless to say, Mama Ji's is amazing! We went for Friday morning dim sum and got to meet mama Ji in the flesh. Great customer service, food, and a killer Belgium beer selection(who would have thought!) I would highly recommend! 

Must orders- steamed pork bun, and the handmade rice rolls!

See you next time Mama Ji!
author: Leah L.

description: Such a yummy place! Id recommend the chicken chow mein, GREEN BEANS, pork buns, hot n sour soup, along with their sour draft beer! A delicious meal! And mama ji is a total G ;) waited a long time on a Saturday night for this place however. Maybe try for lunch. They may be less crowded then or on a week day.
author: Bri K.

description:
A very cute little Chinese restaurant in the outer end of Castro. 

We had the lotus lead wrapped rice, shanghai dumplings and BBQ flat rice noodle rolls (I forgot the name). All were excellent, especially the latter dish with very flavorful pork. 

We also ordered the spicy boiled fish dish, but found that to be ok compared to standouts like Da Sichuan in Palo Alto. 

Overall, I day I would definitely return for the dum sum, but perhaps not the Sichuan stuff.
author: Arjuna S.

description:
The GREEN BEANS, crispy spring rolls and shimp chicken shumi dumplings are to die for. And super affordable. Get take-out though, because the wait can be rather long.

Food actually re-heats well in microwave if needed.
author: Gabriel C.

description:
Went to MaMa Ji's for dinner last night. It was super good! I'm giving it five stars with the expectation that the few hiccups will improve as they work out the kinks in a new operation. Here's the scoop: Szechuan food in the Castro, apparently with a hefty dim sum menu, and a selection of craft beers and Ritual coffee.  Yes, you read all of that right. 

As an aside, I've felt that aside from Frances (hardly a frequent dinner choice), the Castro is a good food desert.  Forever-dieting gay boys do not require a hot food scene.  But the Castro is a food desert no longer. 

I came here last night with my dude, two coworkers, and one of the coworkers' young child.  The place was basically empty, and the ambiance could use a bit of work.  For example, as others note, the lighting is really harsh.  But we were basically attacked by waiters, and the dude behind the counter working the beer taps was answering questions and making suggestions left and right.  I felt like the service was extremely friendly. 

We ordered: 
- Pork Shumai: These were good, but nothing special.  But hey, I like good, and don't usually look for special in my shumai. 

- Shrimp dumplings: The dumplings were great! They were filled with plump, well-cooked (read: not overcooked and pasty) shrimp, and had a delicate lining.  They were kind of higher-priced at around $9, but worth it. 

- Spare ribs:  These were a delicious set of cut up spare ribs in some sort of a soy-like but thickened brown sauce.  Not spicy, and very tasty. 

- Steamed fish and tofu special:  Holy hell, this needs to go on the regular menu.  Big chunks of fish with slices of tofu in a light-your-mouth-on-fire spicy red sauce. Very big yum.  Order a second glass of water. 

- Stir-fried pea sprouts with garlic:  This felt necessary after all of the heavy indulgence.  This again was good, but nothing special, but I just wanted some relief for my tongue so that was what I wanted. 

- Deep-fried pumpkin special: This again needs to go on the regular menu.  Chunks of pumpkin, dipped in I think it was duck eggs, and crispy fried, almost tempura style.  It was delicious, especially after being dunked in a chili-soy-vinegar mixture. 

- They made a special noodle dish for my coworkers' little girl who doesn't like spicy food. 

- We also ordered beer and wine. I think the wine list could use a bit of work (this is San Francisco, after all).  A nice dry rose or crisp riesling would compliment the spicy food very nicely.  But they have a ton of options for beer, and a couple of belgians on tap that will quench the fire in your mouth very nicely. 

In all, a couple of kinks, but I'm excited to see what this place turns into. Keep up the good work!
author: Tom P.

description:
'twas a sunny Sunday in Eureka Valley when I walked over to MaMa Jis for brunch. 
I looked over at the crowd and thought 'crap, this is going to be a long wait'. 

However, even though this is just their second week as a full service restaurant, they're starting to hit their stride. 

Dim sums (?) came out one by one, only a couple of minutes apart. Each one was fresh, delicious, and piping hot. By the time the last dish was on the table, we were lagging behind. 

Both the owners (husband and wife) dropped by to check in on us and were super friendly. It seems they've always wanted to open up a restaurant in this neighborhood that served really good Chinese food. Right now their main focus is picking up great ingredients and making sure that everything that makes it out to each table is of high quality. 

I think they've nailed it. Looking forward to trying them for dinner.
author: Ryan D.

description: FINALLY, The Castro has a good Chinese restaurant!!  The food at MaMa Ji's is consistently good, the service is friendly and I love the fact they have many vegetarian selections. They'll even cook up dishes that aren't on the menu. I don't know what it is about this place, but the atmosphere is always upbeat, fun and cheerful. Maybe it's the combination of the craziness of The Castro and the wonderful food.
author: Gwen M.

description: Dim Sum is quite good. Dumplings are served hot and flavourful and the staff is rather friendly. The menu is short, however they do what's available very well. It's a small place, only seating a max of 49 and I'm not sure how they'd fit that many. I would recommend this place if you're looking for a nice neighbourhood style meal away from the banquet hall Dim Sum places.
author: Alex S.

description: The food was not the best, just ok. We were hoping to have excellent chinese food in SF.
author: Sabine M.

description:
I love this place!  I'm pretty much known as the "kung pao tofu guy" because that's usually what I order, but they do it really well here.  A lot of places use really firm tofu for this dish, since that tends to appeal to American tastes, but I MUCH prefer deep-fried soft tofu.  That's how Mama Ji's does it, so I go there at least twice a week.

Fun fact, they serve a spicy version of Zhajiangmian here, which happens to be the dish that was adopted into Korean cuisine as Jajangmyeon.
author: Tommy R.

description: The most authentic spicy bean curd (Mapo Doufu) I've had in the U.S.. Even beats many made by mainland China restaurant standards.
author: Max Z.

description:
Fresh, FRESH,and tasty Chinese served up with friendly service. OMG, some of the best Kung Pao Prawns I've eaten in San Francisco: fat, juicy and tender shrimp cooked to perfection, mixed up with crisp bell peppers and large and crunchy peanuts, enrobed in a tangy spicy sauce liberally laced with crushed Szechuan peppers. 

I've been eagerly awaiting the opening after its renovations turned the place from a Dim Sum and crepe cafe to a full fledged restaurant adding traditional Chinese fare. There is still work to be done: the walls are bereft of any adornment, and the wait staff are still getting familiar with the variety of dishes, but the meal does not disappoint, au contraire.
author: Daniel S.

description:
Let's face it gays, the Castro is starved for affordable, GOOD food. Most of our fare caters to the happy hour crowd which I happily partake in but because I'm not drunk 24/7 Mama Ji's is a happy addition to the neighborhood. Oh, and it's literally a hop skip and a jump from my house which makes it even better. I can literally hear the dishes crashing from my bedroom window. Yet I just smile because this restaurant is so feel good, so not pretentious b.s. San Francisco. It is just good food, good friendly people and good atmosphere. My partner and I usually go for dinner and have never been disappointed. It's the freshest tasting Chinese food I've ever had, period. 

Try it. Your colon might regret the visit (some of the dishes are SPICY) but while you're there you'll feel warm, happy and full. Also, try the Belgian beer on tap. Great pairing with the food!
author: Zachary C.

description: Get your dim sum fix without the wait or the price tag. Mama Ji's serves up fresh and filling dim sum options in a homey atmosphere with prompt and gracious staff. While the food itself could benefit from more flavor, the overall experience and affordability make the trip to Mama Ji's worth it.
author: Justine H.

description: Absolutely amazing dim sum!! My boyfriend and I went to san francisco for vacation and we were craving dim sum. Everything was spot on. I can't wait to go back. The best dim sum we've ever had. Thank you mama ji's!
author: Sully L.

description:
Oh man!  This place is WAY too convenient for our family.  Heck, we might even just set up an account here because we live practically next door.  But, alas, the good thing is that you can only eat so much dim sum.  Because if you eat too much dim sum, you probably surpassed your daily sodium intake in one sitting.  So, just eat some dim sum, but not too much dim sum.  Hmmm.  Is "dim sum" a term to describe a type of food presentation- you know, like hot pot or buffet and I am totally butchering its use?  I really don't want to look it up in wikipedia.  

The wifey and I bring our toddler here when we don't feel like cooking dinner.  Sure, it may not be the best toddler food in the world, what with the spicy cold noodles and the salty dim sum.  But it's food.  And it's pretty good.  Just not the best for a toddler.  But heck, tell that to the Szechuan Province full of toddlers.  But I may be using a broad generalization, because this is obviously not an "everyday" sort of thing.  Or is it?  I don't know.  I know of people who eat McDonald's everyday.  Do you remember when McDonald's hamburgers were only 5 cents?  No, because you'd be dead.  

When compared to Z&Y in Chinatown, the cuisine isn't as enticing, but I don't care.  It's practically next door.

Although the dim sum wrappings are variable and many-a-time show signs of premature sloughing as you attempt to pick them up out of the bamboo steamers,   the end product is what matters:  good flavor and substantiating satiety.  If I were younger and more of a d-bag, I'd bemoan the shortcomings of the number of folds on my xiao lum bao's (which would be 18) or whether or not water came to my table in a timely manner (because these flames are not going to be taken out by themselves).  I don't care about any of that anymore.  I mean, have you taken care of your kid when sick?  You know, like carrying a screaming kid with a fever around all night to console him and 3am visit to the emergency room for racemic epinephrine and decadron.  Even as a medical doctor, taking call is like a vacation.  So, yeah, I'm not gonna complain about petty stuff.
author: John L.

description:
I hate being the guy that shows up to a restaurant with a huge party with no reservation, AND a dog, but for some reason these guys were super hospitable. 

Given the area, the price for food of this quality is quite reasonable...
author: Patrick L.

description: The food overall tastes ok; we had beef chow fun, fried rice, and crispy eggplant... But I almost ate a piece of plastic (film, probably from some packaging) that was in the beef chow fun. At first I thought it was a piece of shrimp shell (there was no shrimp in that dish) but I was mortified when I realized it was a piece of plastic! I notified the server about it and all I got was an apology. No discount on the bill or anything comped. You can bet your ass we didn't leave a tip. Horrible service that left me hugely disappointed. Never coming back again!
author: Nance W.

description:
This is a great new addition to the Castro!  Altogether, I would give this place about 3.5 stars.  I wouldn't go out of my way to come here, but if I'm in the area, I will definitely come by for some good dim sum!  The service is minimal, but friendly.  The atmosphere is very casual and simple.  We ordered multiple types of dim sum, mostly with shrimp.  My favorite were the shanghai dumplings - a must try!  The seafood shumai were also pretty good. 

Overall, it's a good, satisfying, and affordable neighborhood spot - so make sure to check it out if you live, or happen to be in the Castro!
author: Juliana K.

description:
I am nearly giddy with happiness that MaMa Ji's is half a block from my house.

They're husband and wife.  He's American.  She's Chinese, from Szechuan Province.  She's also one hell of a cook.  He really knows his wine/beer pairings with Chinese food.  They're as nice as they can be, and the food is fresh, prepared beautifully, and plentiful.  This is more like eating in someone's home than at one of the Chinese restaurants I'm familiar with.  

Disclosure:  I have not tried the dim sum.  All in good time.  Since I plan on returning again and again, I'm sure dim sum will be consumed before too long.

I am a happy diner.
author: Earline A.

description:
I had a great experience at Mama Ji's!  I went there with 5 of my friends from college for dim sum(three of us are Chinese so we know our dim sim). 

The food was freshly made, and not the oily, MSGed up crap that's usually served at dim sum places.  The BBQ dumplings - scrumptous; the shumai - succlent; the xiao long bao, fragrant and flavorful; the turnip cakes - melt-in-your-mouth delightful.

We also got to chat with Mama Ji herself!  A charming lady from the Sechuan region, she casually joked with us during our meal, and was nice enough to send us some complimentary cookies.

Overall great place!  Will come here again.  


-Bernard
author: Bernard W.

description:
Fresh dim sum, friendly staff, and good prices.

Drove all the way up from SJ to try this place out.  We tried practically everything on their menu and everything was fresh and hot.  The dim sum had a sweet taste to it which I really liked.  Especially recommend their: Cilantro Shrimp Dumplings, Pea Sprouts Shrimp Dumplings, Chicken Shrimp Shumai, Shrimp Rice Roll, and Chive Shrimp Dumpling.  We'll be back if in the area.
author: Joycelyn L.

description:
Me: "Excuse me, can I have a fork?"
Mama Ji: "Oh no, you don't know how to use a chopstick?"
Me: "No... its just... it's just it's really hard to pick up the rice on the plate...!"
Mama Ji: "It's okay, let me go back and get it for you"

I can't believe this quaint little place is only 2 blocks up the hill from Badlands. It's amazing how different things can look in a couple blocks in the city. Mama Ji's is located in the heart of Castro, yet somehow this block does feel a bit quiet and homey. 

The food here is great! I recommend any of the dim sum, cold noodles, and fried chicken. The cold noodles come in a hot chili oil platter with cucumbers and ground pork. It's like a savory and spicy noodle salad. The fried chicken here is spicy, crispy, and delicious. It feels like a whiff of peppery smoke releases into the air with each bite. The one thing I like most about Mama Ji's is that it's a really nice looking restaurant. It's simple, clean, but yet kinda hip and charming. It kinda reminds me of a hamburger diner or pancake house. I would love to come back and try all the dinner options. Just need to practice my chopstick skills beforehand.
author: Charlie L.

description: The Meal was good, but the wait was NOT WORTH IT. I went in knowing it wasn't the standard "pick from a cart"  affair, but did NOT think we'd be waiting over 45 minutes to receive food. There was little explanation as to what was taking so long and we left hungry, not wanting to order more and have to WAIT all over again. In the end they ended up overcharging for tea that we ordered BUT never received. .....
author: Corinne B.

description:
Really tasty food!

It is run by a family so don't expect 'professional' service, and it just reopened as a full service restaurant and you will find MaMa Ji's servers doing their best and learning along the way.

Come with a bit of patience, an appetite.  The food is flavorful and fresh.  You will not be disappointed.  We are looking forward to returning soon.

MaMa Ji's also serves coffee (ritual) and pastries in the am.
author: Jon H.

description: 3.5 stars. Dim sum is the way to go. Dry fried green beans with chicken was way overpriced for the amount of chicken and it didn't taste very good. Veggie chow mein was good, but pretty greasy.  If I go back, it'll be for the dim sum.
author: Janelle F.

description:
a great place for dimsum in Castro! Handmade rice roll is delicious but abit pricy which make sense because of the fresh handmade from kitchen. Also the wonton noodle soup is sooo good, special recipe by the wonderful owner Lili. 

Dimsum Recommend:
Chicken Shumai
Sticky Rice
Vegetarian Bun
Vegetarian Rice Roll
Spring Roll
Egg Custard Bun
Wonton Noodle Soup

Dinner Recommend:
Chongqing Chicken 
Spicy Fish Fillet in chili oil
author: Zhe C.

description: The best Sichuan food since I was there.  Have everything super spicy like when you're in China.  Very authentic.
author: Greg G.

description:
I'm very happy to have discovered this. The best Dim Sum outside of the Inner Richmond. Very accessible off the 33 and a short walk from Castro station. Extremely fair prices for the quality.

Not particularly fast paced but I like that. Relax in a more quiet part of the city, enjoy your tea, and have a few bites to eat. 

I have not been here for dinner yet but I am confident it is delicious. There is obvious care put into these morsels and I hope you enjoy them.
author: Peter M.

description:
LOVE this place!  Excellent dim sum, as good as any you'll find in the city, and the prices are so reasonable. Everything we ordered was just perfect -- fresh, hot, delicious. Great service too. 

I am not a fan of spicy food, and I saw a lot of super hot looking main courses coming out of the kitchen. But we stuck to dim sum: dumplings, spring rolls, shu mai, mushroom shrimp, sweet chicken wings, etc, and the spice level was absolute perfection. 

The owners are so friendly, they have worked really hard to get this place up and running, and I hope the neighborhood supports them. I can't think of a better restaurant in our neighborhood. Can't wait to go back!
author: Philip M.

description:
Meh-  sorry mama ji! 

New dim sun joint in the Castro. From what we were told they opened about 3 weeks ago and it was previously a coffee shop (not sure if they were the same owners or not).  Anyways, service was friendly but really slow. Food was a little subpar for me... We eat alot of dim sum and it just didn't compare.  There isn't a of variety and portions are somewhat small. For a medium size dish it's $3.75.
author: Julie F.

description:
We read the reviews and ordered Chong Qing ckicken. It was tasty. A cold draft blond beer. Chicken chow mien , pork fried rice. But the pork Sui Mai was the best!

I found a new favorite Chinese restaurant in San Francisco.
author: Cesar L.

description: There was a line 20 people long out the door in the rain of people waiting for tables when we left last night, and now I know why. This place is great! It has great, exciting food, a fun and happy vibe, and warm service where everyone seems to pitch in doing everything, so that it seems like someone is always taking care of you.
author: Morris R.

description:
Great food. Overpriced, amazing Belgian beers. Occasional inexperienced or clueless service. Inconsistent spiciness. Lectures on how to eat Chinese food. Handsome gays seated in the front windows.

Mama Ji knows her stuff!
author: Mark P.

description:
It's in the neighborhood, and my coworker claimed that their chicken wing is better than San Tung(which is impossible btw). But I had to try it. 

Obviously, their fried chicken wing is not better than San Tung. It was good, and had interesting spice. It's just not that crispy. Onion cake was awful, don't get it. It was tasteless thick greasy fried flour dough. It was wasting of ingredients and my 6 dollars. But but but their wanton soup is amazing! Clean broth, delicious wanton. I will definitely come back for this again. 

I was checking out other table, and everything looks quite delicious. I have to come back to try more, but definitely not onion cake.

This place is serious about selling drinks. I don't drink alcohol at all. I see some people complaint about they charge tea for $3. I think they are not handing out complimentary tea, so more people would get beer.
author: Anna H.

description: I do not know how I missed this amazing establishment coming into my neighborhood but I'm elated it's here! Between the Belgian beer selection and some of the best dim sum I've ever had, i am so happy! Try the pork buns, the chicken shrimp shumai, the dry fried green beans, and the lava buns. Love you mama Ji's!!!
author: Nikki M.

description: I love Taiwanese food, and that is not easy for this  Cantonese to find. Thanks to the recommendation from a Taiwanese friend, I found my fix. So every time I pass by the area, I would make it a point to go to MaMa Ji's.
author: Sean S.

description:
MaMa Ji's is a favorite Friday afternoon lunch stop in the neighborhood.  The service has improved and stabilized--still an area where just a smidge of improvement would make a whopping difference--all in all, good service, friendly for sure.  We have tried many of the dishes and are very happy with the flavor, temperature and consistency.  Lots of choice and none have disappointed.  A delightful mix of locals and visitors--friendly to all that show up to enjoy the very tasty dim sum delights.

Here's to many more Friday treats at MaMa Ji's!
author: Jeff P.

description:
The food looked really good the night we were there.  Unfortunately, the service was abysmal. The server apologized for "forgetting" us and we were served soggy peanuts after 10 minutes.  We left after 15 minutes.  Despite an apology from the owner/manager, we were turned off by the incompetent service.  There were three servers working that night but they seemed disorganized and preoccupied with the back of the house and not the customers. 

Train your wait staff on customer service and engaging customers.  Again, the food looked really good--too bad we were unable to taste it. We just ran out of  patience and dined elsewhere.
author: Robert S.

description: SOSPICYZOMGSO. SPICY. If like me you have a spice tolerance that never seems to increase, beware! Between gasps things were quite tasty though... I think. I was mostly relying on what my significant other claimed to be true. We got the pork shumai, which was traditionally my favorite dim sum dish growing up. It did not disappointment, though was it any better than any other good dim sum? More expensive for sure..But unique for the neighborhood I guess. We also got the boiled beef slices and the ma po tofu, both of which induced streams of sweat through the rest of dinner. But the ingredients seemed fresh and healthy, and really, they did taste quite good. I'd come back! Though maybe I'd be inclined to order more of the dim sum next time. Oh yeah also, it's a small place and gets pretty loud when full.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Wow,,,,nice place!!!! GOOD food.

This place let me miss my hometown,
author: Xiaoyu W.

description:
Really, really good Szechuan food. The numbing fish was wonderful: well-spiced and flavorful without being egregiously spicy, and the country style shrimp was delicious, with wonderful chili oil on the vegetables.

It was actually the dim sum that was the least exciting -- really good, but not as flavorful as the actual dishes. Will absolutely be back, though, can't wait to taste more.
author: H. P.

description: It's hard for me to find decent dim sum in the Civic Center/Tenderloin area. Mama Ji's delivers (via Caviar). It's very authentic! Ha Gao was perfect, shiu mai was excellent and the lotus leaf sticky rice tasted homemade.
author: A L.

description:
I went last night with my boyfriend and had a great time. The food is well priced and very tasty. We ordered the fried pumpkin special, the hot & sour soup, kung pao chicken, and 2 dim sum: bbq pork bun and shrimp siomai... Everything was excellent. 
I would definitely recommend their dim sum - the bbq pork buns were so fluffy, the siomai had big real pieces of shrimp in it and the table next to us ordered the sesame balls which looked great but we were too full. 

We also loved the kung pao chicken - tasty spicy sauce, and good pieces of chicken - also had zucchini, cashews, bamboo shoots, bell peppers. It came in a good portion too. I like how they kept the vegetables in  good sized pieces. 

The reason I give it a 5-star was because of the owners and servers. Nicest couple who really care about your dining experience. 

If you love chinese food and want to try something new, then definitely make a stop by. There's a reason why so many people keep coming back.
author: Shyla W.

description:
Went there for lunch. Really don't know what's the big deal about this place. Just an average dimsum place with rundown enviornment. The selection is very little. The skin for shrimp dumplings is way too thick. Being from Vancouver, I've experienced way better dimsum. 
Maybe it is pretty good for SF standard but if you are from south bay or Vancouver or anywhere that have decent asian population, you are not missing out.
author: Daisy S.

description: Best potstickers on EARF!!! This place is so unassuming, but it is not to be missed if you are in the San Francisco area. The dim sum is the best.
author: Allison P.

description: Came for dim sum, and at first I was a little worried being one of the only Asian people in the restaurant (usually not a good sign for dim sun / Chinese food). However, all the dim sum dishes we ordered were really good, including the xlbs. The shrimp rice roll had cilantro in it which made it a weird flavor, and the combination chow mein was actually not salty enough (very rare in a Chinese restaurant!). A little expensive, but the food is good and the service is fast. Would recommend and come back for dim sum.
author: Amy Y.

description: Didnt get to try the food because I left after being called an idiot after trying to sign my name on a tiny note pad sized board. Maybe next time but being called an idiot for not being able to find space on your literally little wait list was enough to turn me off.
author: Denis D.

description: If I could give this place negative stars I would. We went there and we were asked to put our name on the list (which is a piece of paper hanging on a wall) we were the only people on the list. It was just me and 2 other people with me (so total of 3) we waited for about 15 minutes and still not seated. Then a group of 4 walked up and looked at the list the server quickly came out and asked them how many they said 4, he looked in and said I have a table! Mind you that these people were not told to wait or sign up on a board to wait. I asked him and said we have been waiting before them and he said yes but I have a table for 4. My issue is really a table for 4? What is the difference??? 3 people will go at a table like that as well. I felt disrespected at that point because we were looked over as we were not there. That isn't how you do business at all. I will not go back to this place nor recommend it to anyone. Needless to say we left and went to another place because of the actions of the poor staff here.
author: Roxy H.

description:
I suspect that MaMa Ji's high rating so far has to do with subconsciously lowered expectations since it's 3-4 blocks, and a couple dozen storefronts, uphill from Castro & 18th. For whatever reason, larger restaurants on Market with better food have been slammed on Yelp and run off in less than a year.

For my first and only visit so far, just a takeout order of three dim sum was enough after having a couple drinks nearby. Tucked into unassuming decor were small tables of smiling people. A good sign, I thought.

The mushrooms in the shrimp stuffed mushrooms were large, which helped them remain crisp and juicy after cooking. The pork shumai were fine. The Shanghai dumplings, with broth, were served on individual tiny aluminum plates and interesting. FWIW, I've eaten these in Taipei, Taiwan, but never in Shanghai, China. 

While the two employees who spoke to me were very friendly, the speed of food didn't match. It's a data point of only one, but...takeout at 9pm on a Thursday, and dim sum only to reduce the wait time, shouldn't take 15-20 minutes, should it? I heard "10 minutes," and then a quiet, "Maybe 15," and thought to myself: "Self, what the heck did you just order? Why didn't you just stay on Castro St?"

Too late. Catching my bus, and the alternate, both were off the list by that point. Admittedly, I'd become impatient and it felt like taxi time. Oh well, maybe I'll be back. Or maybe I'll get my dim sum fix elsewhere.
author: Mike H.

description: Overpriced and the food was a salt bomb. Food was served on cheap plastic plates and felt like a low rent experience. The tab was not low rent.
author: Evan S.

description: I usually think Chinese food is nasty. This place rocks! So delicious! I am going back tonight
author: Thomas S.

description: We have been twice now and really enjoyed the food and the service. The space is small for the busy business they do but that should not deter you. Everything is served hot and fresh. the one star missing is that they do not offer any Chinese beer. Boo... But everything else is great and the staff will make you feel welcome.
author: Tyler S.

description: Great spot for dinner and drinks. Fairly generic, but comfortable ambiance. Food was delish and nice to order a collection of small plates to eat, drink, and hang out with a couple friends at our own pace. Food was tasty and dining format was very enjoyable.
author: J K.

description: I would give this place 5 stars just for having chop sticks and chop sticks alone on the tables (It always disappoints me when I walk into a Chinese restaurant with forks on the table and/or I have to ask for chop sticks), but the the Kung Pow chicken was also worthy.
author: Wyatt B.

description:
Good dim sum! We ordered the BBQ pork buns, pork pot stickers, small pork soup dumplings, chicken wonton soup, spare ribs and bran curd dumplings. Everything was fantastic except for the bean curd dumplings, which we sent back. The service is great, they also have exceptional coffee, espresso and tea options. 

This is the kind of dim sum place where you order on a sheet of paper (no ladies with carts). The facility is very clean, it's well decorated and it's in a fun neighborhood. I do wish that there were more vegetable options for lunch. Usually dim sum places offer plates of Chinese broccoli or bok choy, but this was not the case here. Other Yelp posters have included pictures of their vegetable sides, perhaps those are dinner features. That being said, the dumplings are truly exceptional - try it out!
author: Grace C.

description: This is some of the best dim sum I've ever had and very reasonably priced. Everything tastes so fresh and comes out steaming hot. You don't get the traditional dim sum experience of ladies walking around with carts that don't speak English but it's so good it doesn't matter. I would also say there's nothing particularly unique about the dumplings - pretty much all the traditional dumplings. But if you can do traditional really well, why mess with it?
author: Alana R.

description:
My gf and I have visited Mama Ji's twice in the last month, both times for dim sum brunch. The food has been consistently excellent. The spicy cold noodles are a highlight and the dumplings are varied and delicious. 

Our only complaint is that the restaurant has been short-staffed at 10am on Sunday both times. Today, they couldn't make espresso until Mama Ji herself showed up. So, why open at 930 if you can't provide good service? Other than this, we heartily recommend this great new dim sum spot!
author: Andrew J.

description: My chicken dumplings were raw. I ate raw chicken! Id never eat here again. My server didn't even offer me new utensils. Nor was she concerned for my health..
author: Kadi H.

description:
3.5 stars

We arrived on a Saturday for lunch.  There was a short wait.  The place was surprisingly packed.

Every item you're used to ordering at traditional dim sum restaurants off the cart is offered here.  You check off the items you want from their colorful, picture menu and wait... and wait.  Most items we tried were good!  And though service was friendly, it was super slow.  Also, the prices were a bit higher than we're used to for dim sum.

This is no Koi Palace, but it's not half bad either.  And since this is a 10 min walk from our home, we'll be back.
author: K V.

description: Yeah mama G's is a good Asian place in anytime you're in the area come by and check it out she has great prices and delicious food too happy face when is the best ;)
author: Derek F.

description: Visited Mama Ji's on Saturday night, after dancing up an appetite at Badlands, (gay bars play the best music, the guys love to dance and no one tries to pick up on you)!! But I digress..... 7 of us showed up around 10p and were happily accomodated. My 1st visit, but my friend Justin knew it well and ordered for us all. Even though the restaurant was full, the food came out promptly. OMG! From the braised greens, to the sweet/spicy/sticky chicken wings, to the fish stew....EVERYTHING was fresh, perfectly seasoned, hot and delicious! "Mama Ji", herself, even came out to tell my friend Happy Birthday & took a picture of the group for us. I am going back for the Dim Sum and bringing friends. I will also go back for dinner soon. It's an hr drive for me, but worth it.
author: Tanya B.

description:
Not your typical Dim Sum spot but definitely sumthing delicious! 

We showed up here on a sunday around 11... without any call ahead of time and asked to be seated with 9 people. This is a small restaurant, something I didnt realize ahead of time. They didn't hesitate, they said we will see what we can do! They asked if we would be willing to split the table, which was fine, given the situation. Instead, it was a beautiful day so they brought out tables on the sidewalk (where they generally only have one on each side of the door) to accommodate us. 

Now, when I say its not your typical dim sum spot, I mean that I am used to carts coming around and you just pick what you want from the carts as they come around. This place they give you a paper menu and you mark how many of each item you would like (which can be a bit more difficult if you dont know what your doing). I'm pretty confident you cant go wrong. The food was great! 

It's definitely worth a try if you're in the neighborhood and looking to fill yourself to the point of being rolled home in a wheelbarrow!
author: Jess K.

description: OMG this place serves up some mighty spicy food. My favorite was the stir fried dried beef. That was really tasty. The sweet and sour port was quite good too. Their specialty apparently is the spare ribs, which were good. Though I wish they would give a little more.  My least favorite was the fried beans. It had a unique flavor. Overall pretty good. A little greasy but hey, its Chinese, so its expeted.
author: Kenson K.

description: Quick, efficient, and tasty dim sum! Friendly service, & so easy to choose the delectables that you like. Love it's easy location in the Castro.
author: Jill B.

description: Don't judge the restaurant by its dirty windows. Inside you will find amazing and authentic Chinese food and a simple yet inviting interior. The food is very good. You get general faire but also many of the authentic options not usually available like eggplant chicken and steamed catfish in hot oil. Highly recommended. Service could be better.
author: Aman A.

description:
Incredibly happy with this place. We ate so much, we had to drag ourselves out the door. Every single item we ordered was delicious. 

Great great belgian beer selection, hand-picked by the owner. 
Finally dim sum and beer that's not the watered down standards.

Owners are friendly and really focused on the happiness of the customer.

We're already planning our next visit.
author: John C.

description:
Wow. This is better than Yank Sing. Super fresh. Crisp. Excellent service. Very reasonably priced.

Eat here.
author: Anthony A.

description: Not bad.  The food was decent and the staff was pleasant and lb top of things. Bbq pork bun was yummy.
author: Arpie A.

description: 5 stars -- "as good as it gets" even, in my experience, compared to dim sum in Guangzhou and HK. The flavors and textures are perfect. Xiao long bao (Shanghai dumplings) and nai huang bao (custard buns) are astonishingly fresh and tasty. A trendy dining space, option of outdoor seating and extensive [Belgian] beer list may not be authentic features, but they should be.
author: Kevin M.

description: What a difference a day makes! On Saturday night, the food was innovative and delicious. Both the fish fragrant pork and the seafood clay pot were excellent. I would have given them five stars. We returned on Monday night and ordered the Chongqing Chicken and "ants climbing trees". The former was the same as a bad order of chicken McNuggets and the latter was a gooey mass of rice noodles with minced pork. Absolutely terrible! We learned later that the regular chefs were off that night and the "backup" chefs were cooking. Well if the hallmark of a good restaurant is consistently good food then this place deserves three stars at most. The list of Belgian beers on tap (which go well with Chinese food) is a plus but the schizophrenia in the kitchen makes this place a crap shoot.
author: Louis G.

description: I've heard lots of good things about this place, the food was decent but nothing to write home about. We started with the potstickers and dumplings and then we shared the garlic broccoliand a chicken dish that was too spicy to eat even though we ask for non-spicy.
author: Dirk N.

description: I was slightly disappointed that they don't have the full dim sum menu at night for dinner.  That is why we went.  Only selected items on the appetizer menu for dinner.  They don't take reservations, so be prepared to wait outside; it is a small place.  If you do go, I recommend the hot and sour soup and the seafood dumplings.  The chicken entrees leave a little to be desired, as it is all dark meat.  I prefer white meat chicken.
author: Aman S.

description: Pretty legit dim sum place in the Castro. I think they may have just opened up? It's not organized well, and there are random items thrown about like in the restroom. It's got a hole in the wall feel but looks nicer than that. The various dim sum items we ordered were up to par with our favorite dim sum places, if just a little below in taste. BBq pork steam bun, fried eggplant with shrimp, tofu with shrimp, deep fried meat dumplings, noodles. We didn't order entrees just dim sum. We'll go again if in the neighborhood.
author: Vol T.

description:
Was looking forward to trying the food here but was very disappointed. The food was greasy and beyond salty and the worst Chinese food I ever had. 
The service was also poor. Never once were we asked if everything was alright. 
Would never come back.
author: Craig C.

description: Excellent restaurant in Castro!  We had our share of dumplings at this restaurant. An excellent find for sure.  The restaurant is very quaint and open a great gathering with friends.
author: Grey H.

description: First timer chose this from Yelp reviews. Everything I wanted and expected. Pork buns and pot stickers were fabulous.
author: Steve K.

description:
Amazing Szechuan fare, top-notch selection of Belgian beer. Need I say more?

Oh, okay, I'll expound a bit.  After a bad BBQ oyster at Fish in Sausalito for lunch, my wife wasn't sure she'd be able to eat but I somehow convinced her to try again; on top of that, I'm totally baffled how I got her to agree to Szechuan but she did.  Seeing Mama Ji's reviews and staying just around the block we headed over for a late dinner on Sunday night.  

The owners: attentive, engaging, and Mama Ji lives up to her name as she dotes on all the young kids.  Her husband was an absolute pleasure to talk to, making beer pairing suggestions while keeping up a light-hearted banter about food and whatnot.

The food: the deep-fried pumpkin--oh my god, even though hours before my wife swore off food she commenced to put away almost the whole plate.  If you see this on the menu it is an absolute must.

An aside about the menu:  it's limited but rightfully so. You're not going to be given a telephone book full of choices but that's because what they do, they do well.

The other dishes: pork spare ribs were savory, not the sickeningly sweet red dye no. 5 garbage you get elsewhere; BBQ pork buns were sticky, sweet, and fluffy; Kung Pao chicken was full of fresh peppers and cashews, perfect with the brown rice. 

If we were locals this place would take home a good part of our weekly paycheck.  If you're a local you could do much, much worse with all of the mediocre options in the Castro.
author: Michael W.

description:
I really enjoyed the Dim Sum I had at MaMa Ji's! The experience is not quite as authentic as a meal in somewhere like Chinatown and the selection is not nearly as diverse, but the food is incredible. We had the bell peppers with shrimp, Shanghai dumplings, shrimp dumplings, and pork buns, all of which were delicious. Our neighbors had more traditional entrees which looked incredible as well. 

If you are looking for a lot of inexpensive Dim Sum, this is probably not the right restaurant, but if you are looking for quality Chinese cuisine, I would definitely recommend MaMa Ji's.
author: Sophia A.

description:
Very friendly owner who can describe the the dishes and the way they're created in detail. They did forget an order that we made but still - What a friendly neighborhood place! 

In terms of dishes, the dim sum was pretty good although not spectacular. I would have loved more authenticity in the spicy fish soup (it needed a lot more flavor and heat). Parking was easy to find at an earlier dinner time of 6 o'clock. I noticed that it's harder to find a spot after that. 

Quality: 3
Service: 4
Cost: 3
author: Dorene S.

description: We waited two hours for our takeaway. The lamb was gristle, the chicken rubbery and my mouth had a metallic taste afterwards.
author: David B.

description: Kind of torn - ambiance, service, and starters were great but the main courses fell short of that. Our favorites were the Shanghai dumplings, fried potstickers, and the dry fried green beans. Three stars overall but would go back to try dim sum b/c the smaller dishes were good.
author: Andrew S.

description: This place is fabulous. The dim sum is as good as it gets in Chinatown proper - if not better. It's not heavy or oily - it's just right and the price is so reasonable. No reason to leave the Castro when you can get excellent dim sum in the Castro -- that said, it's always packed at peak mealtimes so go early!  My personal favorites are shiao mai and the shrimp stuffed eggplant. Yummy!
author: Martin Y.

description:
This place is awesome if ur looking for authentic szechan food, not for white people, u guys go to brandy hos. 

Their spicy good is made from real chilies from China not from pre-made sauces. 

This place also does not use msg per owners preferences. Next time ur looking to try something new and refreshing go to mama jis, it's the da bomb
author: Sean S.

description:
Not a Chinatown hole in the wall!

In the mood for high-end, attention to textural detail dim sum, and not wanting to pay Yank Sing prices for a solo meal, I went to check this place out.  So, right off the bat: I was not going out for 'authentic' dim sum... which is super cheap, ingredient quality is mostly low, service is hurried and impersonal.  That ain't this place... so reviewers who gripe about 'slow' or 'inauthentic' should already be checking the wisdom of going for dim sum in the upper Castro if those are points by which they will judge the meal.

That said: I am adding an extra star on top of my overall 'meh' rating of the food.  This is because:
1. The ingredients and cooked temperatures were to a very high standard.
2. The service was quite attentive; both owners and several staff regularly checked in on me to make sure I was okay and fill water for both teapot and glass.  The food was not fast, which was not a problem for me in this context.
3. With their heart so clearly in the right place, and knowing that I am very picky about dim sum, I don't think messing up their yelp ranking with another 2 star rating is warranted.  They wouldn't need to fix much for me to give them 5 stars! (more on that below....)  And I look forward to trying them again in the future to see if they have upped their game.

I was only there for the Dim Sum... I cannot comment on the stir fried or deep fried menu items, soups or noodles.

Okay... the problem for me:  The skins on the dumplings are just too thick and gluey.  While the shrimp inside the har gao and the pea sprout/shrimp dumplings was perfectly cooked (very important, and equally as hard to consistently get right), the skin sticks to your teeth and is not adding a positive dimension to the mouthfeel or flavor of the dumplings.  There is a slight raw rice flour flavor that comes through; and that also explains the gluey-ness.  I think they are making their own wraps in-house... so this issue should be easy to tweak and correct.

The XLB (Shanghai Dumplings) are missing the mark by a wider margin.  Again, the wraps are just not quite right.  Serving in the little metal cups is a good idea, but the tops are thick and stodgy where the dumpling has been sealed; while the skin around the midsection and bottom is almost bread-y.  The soup inside is not seasoned enough.

The condiments are also insufficient for one reason: the chili oil has no flavor.  I didn't ask for sambal or paste, or for whatever options they may have available on request, but what is provided on the table fails to offer flavor balance.  Their uber-plain chili oil, black vinegar and soy are not a sufficient palette with which to make a sauce with balance for my palate!

 but, again, great ingredients and cooking!
author: Josh K.

description: Awesome place! I think this is a really easygoing and delicious spot for lunch. They have several menu items which are $4-5 which makes it easy to order several! On a Thursday at lunchtime it was only filled with a few other groups, so it was a nice place to relax. Was craving dumplings and didn't want to go all the way to the Sunset! Soo delicious.
author: Sophie K.

description:
Spicy chicken wings had just the right amount of heat and crispiness. 5 stars.
Shanghai dumplings were tasty but not my fav. 3 stars
Seafood Shu Mai was delicious! 5 stars
Pork Buns were way too sweet for me. 2 stars

Service was awesome. I will definitely be returning!
author: Jordan Q.

description: I was there for the grand opening and I have to say that I have enjoyed going there ever since. Service is good, cuisine is very traditional. Spicy is very "SPICY" . It Gets a little crowded for dinner.  My favorites are the Pork Dumplings.....yummers!
author: Gabriel G.

description:
What a great addition to the Castro! My co-worker and I came here for dinner on 8/20/13 and had a wonderful experience. We were seated quickly and with a smile. The waitress recommended a few dishes, one of them I tried -the dry fried green beans with beef. The flavor of the meat was OUTSTANDING. So flavorful. My date and I also shared the shrimp dumplings and the pork shumai. Both were excellent. I tried some of my dates dish- mothers bean curd with pork. Also, so flavorful and tasty! It goes great over rice. I'll tell you, the fact that they have some great Chinese dinner dishes PLUS dim sum is really going to make this place great. 

One complaint- $3 for iced tea. Boo. If I could give 4 and a half stars I would. Will definitely be back though!!
author: Stephanie W.

description: I appreciate its innovative mindset and yes its much cleaner and more comfortable to dine in that environment.  Yet the dim sums are really not as fresh or authentic as what we got from old or new Chinatowns.
author: Shuting Z.

description: We came here on a Sunday upon finding our old standby Chinese place closed. Took a chance on something new. MaMa Ji's is clean and quaint. The service was a little slow however, and there was a definite language barrier. Made ordering a bit difficult, but we managed. In my opinion the best part about MaMa Ji's are the steamed dumplings. I ordered the shrimp and cilantro, and they were excellent. Delicate dough. Perfect shrimp. Next came the house special clay pot, which was a mix of everything. I found it a little over-seasoned for my tastes. Too much salt. Thick sauce. I didn't care much for it. Overall, if I was in the neighborhood, I would come back for the dumplings, but it would not be a place where I'd go out of my way for.
author: Brian C.

description:
5 stars for the food. 3 stars for the surly attitude at the take out counter.

Two friends of ours ate here earlier in the weekend and said it was the best dim sum they'd had in a long time - saying they finally can get good dim sum without driving from Castro to the Richmond district. We ordered take out, the sweet and sour pork was crispy and sweet, without being greasy or cloying. The shrimp Shu mi (sp?) had a nice texture suggesting fresh seafood was used. We'll definitely get food from here again.

As for the service, well, apparently one of the online websites posted a menu that doesn't belong to Mama Ji's. The man who took our order literally said, "if you are looking at an online menu, I cannot help you." He then re-admonished me when I picked up the food for using a non approved menu. WTF? I just want to pay you money for some Chinese food. I don't have anything to do with your website problems!
author: Kraig M.

description: Best Kung Pao Chicken ever had in States. Tasty food. Will come back definitely. They were open during Christmas Day.
author: G. D.

description: Really enjoyed the service and atmosphere of this neighborhood restaurant in Eureka Valley. Servers are attentive, friendly and welcoming. Dumpling's filing is excellent but thought the wrap was a bit doughy. Ants on tree, a minced pork on silver glass noodles is delicious. Tried chili pepper fish and tofu, like the dish but my wife didn't like the soft texture of the fish. I think the restaurant is a great additional to the neighborhood and we will be back.
author: Dan S.

description: Big disappointment. The food here tastes like it's been diluted of the real Szechuan flavor for the western palate. We'll keep looking.
author: Shashank A.

description:
Review based on seating experience only. We went elsewhere. 

As a former server, I'm a pretty patient and understanding restaurant customer. But I still have some minimum expectations. 

One of those expectations is to not be left outside in the rain, along with two other parties of two, because the only empty tables are four-tops. 

After staring at one such empty table for ten minutes through the window, the two-top squeezed into the kitchen entrance (your standard afterthought table) vacated and was offered to us. We inquired about what was wrong with the more suitably located empty table, and were told it was for four (really?). When I pointed out that a party of four had been seated at a pair of pushed together two-tops, I got a condescending "Young man..." from the host (perhaps the co-owner, though I'm not sure). Clearly this was not a matter of seating rigidity, but rather of greed. 

Very disappointing, as I really wanted to try some of the vegetarian dishes. We instead enjoyed a less exciting dinner around the corner that was entirely free of BS. 

Learn how to run a hospitable restaurant. Give seats to the customers you have, and not the ones you just might. Unreal.
author: Gee E.

description: I really like the mom and pop feeling of this restaurant, unlike a lot of big dim sum restaurants, it feels like a cozy neighborhood restaurant. The shrimp roll was nice and soft with good amount of shrimp. You can definitely taste the home made style of the food. Wait can be long. Even for a weekday lunch. Price wise it's higher than your typical dim sum place but not as much as Yank Sing. I'm ok with that as long as the quality is good.
author: Sam S.

description: The food here was just fine. Didn't seem much better than any other place. Perhaps a bit cleaner than average. The guy who runs the place isn't very friendly.
author: Eater S.

description:
Mediocre Chinese food
Won't be back
Hot and sour too vinegary and they should offer soup in smaller
Size for 1
Shrimp dumplings were filled with a mystery meat not resembling shrimp I know..
Just sayin ...
author: eric s.

description: Not the most spectacular dim-sum place in SF, but hey, it's something that the Castro desperately needs to add a little more color to the food scene in the neighborhood. A bit salty for my taste, but it works fine if you're nearby and craving something close to authentic dim-sum.
author: Blenda L.

description:
Went there for dim-sum and it was great.  There wasn't anything on the menu (pan friend turnip, shumai, dumplings, steamed roast pork bun) that wasn't good.  Also the service was great  - everything came out immediately once it was ready and the folks that worked at the restaurant were very friendly - had a great conversation.

In addition - there is beer and wine - plus dim-sum....great.  I plan on going again very soon.
author: Daniel S.

description: This place became my favorite Chinese place soon after it opened. I was getting regular cravings. Authentic  flavors, and they managed to do both Szechwan and dim sum right - two things that don't go together. However I noticed a real decline during my last two visits.  I think they're resting a bit in their laurels. The flavors have been off and the quality of ingredients are questionable especially the chicken.  Hoping these are isolated incidents.  Won't be rushing back.
author: Eric C.

description:
MaMa Ji's! Ok, I LOVE this spot.

1) GOOD people. Really solid mom & pop.
2) GOOD food. I have such a hard time finding good dim sum in SF - Chinatown is meh and I do not have the means/patience to go all the way to the Inner Richmond/Inner Sunset area.

So, some friends and I were organizing an event and wanted to have some nighttime dim sum (genius, no?). Most dim sum places don't cater/do massive orders or offer dim sum for dinner. But MaMa Ji's was SUPER accommodating AND presented me with a bottle of champagne when we went to pick up the order. Such sweethearts. 

Our guests raved about the food.

We will be back again and again.
author: Lilian W.

description: When dishes are on the floor, on the DIRTY floor, they do not go back in to the clean rack as I witnessed.  This is the down side of having an open kitchen.
author: Matt V.

description: Omg this place was amazing. Reasonable prices and that chicken fried rice was the best I have ever eaten!
author: Tony S.

description: My first time coming to Mama Ji's and I tried the pan-fried turnip cake and some potstickers.  Red bean bun rounded out the meal.  Just meh and nothing I'd come back for.
author: Kristin B.

description:
I've been twice for eat in and three times for take out.  Never great, mostly average.  Tonight was downright bland and nasty.   I keep wanting to have a great experience and have a great place nearby, but I don't know about this favorite spot of so many.  Even the chow mein was bland, overcooked and had almost no vegies or meat in it.  When I've ordered to go all three times there is so much oil floating on the food it is quite nasty.  Maybe I just order wrong.  But there shouldn't be anything that bad on anyone's menu.

Want to love it, but I dont.
author: Zach S.

description: I walked here today with my son to meet my husband for dinner. We arrived at 5:32 and the restaurant was empty except for one couple. I asked if we could be seated and she asked how many we were and I told her three and my husband is on his way from the Church Street station. the hostess said that I can't seat you until the three of you are here. I asked her if this is the policy even though the restaurant is empty and he is on his biking here now from the muni station. She said those were the rules and indicated I should wait outside. It's 5:35 and the restaurant is still empty. I am used to this policy if a) restaurants are holding for reservations or b) the place is even half full. but it was empty and she even said, I have tables for you when you are all here. There are indeed many tables in many other restaurants in San Francisco.
author: Sari S.

description: Wonderful restaurant that combines quality, affordable food, great service and convenient location. Two of us filled up on 2 beers, 3 dim sum, & chow mien for under $50 and the beers were about half of the bill. Great date night with a nice stroll to Castro to go out after dinner. Try the Shu Mai & BBQ Pork Buns!
author: Shane R.

description: Quirky little place.  Don't go here for the decor.  It's very simply furnished with harsh, fluorescent lighting. But do go here for the fun service and great food!  Really good experience.
author: SF G.

description:
Great food at good prices. Nice staff. I'd go here a lot if I lived in the area. 
Dim sum any time they're open (til 9PM).
author: jeff s.

description: Wow ... Never fails.. Great food great service ! Really well priced.. Only wish open longer for lunch! Maybe some bok Choy !!
author: Jason P.

description: "The Chef Doesn't Feel Like Making That Dish Now, So Pick Something Else" So I picked my ass up, went & got a taco at Taqueria Zapata, came back, sat back down  & ate it with my friends. And after 10 visits, that is The Last Time I Go To Mama's!
author: Sean S.

description:
WARNING: DO NOT ORDER FOOD FOR PICK UP FROM HERE. It's not worth the risk of showing up and learning that your order has somehow disappeared.

I will never, EVER eat here again. Because I'm so pissed about the service. I've eaten at the restaurant multiple times, and the service is always lacking and slow (we always wait too long for the check, for example) - but I usually excuse bad service when the food is good enough to keep coming back (which for the most part it is, if you're okay with overpriced dim sum and Szechuan food). BUT I'm finally done with Mama Ji's and am admitting to myself that it is a poorly run business that does NOT deserve my patronage. 

I called in an order for pick up; gave my order, gave my name and phone number, etc. The woman who answered (I'm guessing the owner, who I notice is the one usually picking up the phone when I eat in) gave me a 35-minute estimate. We show up at the restaurant 35 minutes later only to find out that our order DOES NOT EXIST. They had no record of it. Not that they forgot to put the order in to the kitchen - they literally just misplaced our order and apparently don't have my name and order written down anywhere. They even questioned if we called in at all. WELL, WE DID. They said we could order again, and they could have the food ready in 10 minutes (which I doubt was actually possible), but by then, we were pissed. Dinner plans ruined; we drove all the way there for no reason, etc. They really did not care about retaining our business. 

It was a busy night, and I get that they're tending to a lot of customers. But HI, YOU'RE A RESTAURANT. You can't just lose people's orders. 

Goodbye forever, Mama Ji's! Ugh.
author: Melissa P.

description: Mamaji's used to be better. But recently (Nov 2014) very average tasting food.
author: Vik L.

description:
pick up the phone! please if you are not open then do not list false hours of operation  on your website.

This has nothing to do with the restaurant service or the quality of food. Just bad business practice.
author: Niki M.

description: Consistently incredible tasting food, not overly greasy as one can get in Chinese food and dim sum, attentive and friendly staff, killer prices.
author: Joe P.

description: I can't believe how great the food is natural taste very taste spectacular .. Love love love them and recommend every every body to try :))
author: Nebahat S.

description: Okay so...I have lived with my moms cooking for over 18 years, and I can tell you it almost tastes the same. Meaning it's good. It took me back to my childhood years. It's a bit pricy for Chinese food. I mean it's about $11 for fried rice, when you can go to an actual Chinatown and get it for $6-8 dollars. All and all, it's not bad.
author: Vinson H.

description: Fish with chili and Sichuan pepper, cilantro shrimp rice roll, seafood shumai, spareribs are all so delicious. Perfect between two people. Worth the wait!!
author: Anji S.

description: Visiting from the east coast, I was craving some good Dim Sum.  The Dim Sum in NYC isn't exactly great.  I'd been to a few Chinatown dim sum restaurants in my visits to SF and thought they were OK but was looking for a more calm experience this time.  My husband and I visited Mama Ji's on a random weekday during the day.  The ordering was simple enough and the food was scrumptious.  The issue I have is that we walked in and they immediately greeted us with "Hello, welcome.  X, Y, and Z are not available right now."  Of course, everything we had planned to order was "not available".  Still, the food we DID order was delicious and we wish that we had access to such an amazing restaurant in NYC!
author: Diane C.

description: If you are a veggie and/or avoiding carbs I would say this place is not for you. Also if traditional Cantonese is not your jam you might be disappointed. I've tried a couple times to find an alternative option on the menu and have been disappointed. It's just not for me. However my friends love the dim sum and often go back.
author: Edith L.

description:
I heard about this place for great dim sum, but the dinner menu looked much better.

When we went, we had the chongqing chicken, numbing fish, pickled long beans, pumpkin with duck egg coating, and the flowing lava buns. Two servings of brown rice was too much rice for us- one would have been better. Everything was great- lots of Szechuan pepper in the chicken, fish, and green bean dishes (maybe a little bit too much?) We preferred the chicken to the fish dish. iI was *so good* when we'd get a small piece of ginger that had been fried up with the chicken- a nice, bright and clean counterpoint taste to the vinegar and numbing pepper. Those few ginger pieces seemed accidently and we wanted more of them. Unlike dry fried green beans, the pickled long beans were diced into small pieces, which soaked up more sauce and spice. Since all theses dishes were heavy on the Szechuan pepper, it was a little too much of that numbing effect to have all of these in one meal. The pumpkin was our favorite- because it's so good and also because it was a little sweet and totally different from the other things we ordered. The duck egg yolk coating was not quite as powdery as I've had elsewhere and was really nice with a salty dusting on outer surface. The lava buns had a firm center, not the flowing custard that we expected, and that was disappointing. Overall, great food. 

The service was... "serviceable." Fast enough though not super attentive, nor particularly friendly, which is preferable to forced/faked friendliness. As someone else said, the dining room was very warm on a cool night. You might be more comfortable if you wear removable layers or leave your sweaters at home. The night we went, the crowd wasn't very lively. Since it's small in there, every time my husband made me laugh we drew glances from the other, quieter diners. 

My husband asked about bringing my Chinese dad for dinner, but I'm pretty sure he wouldn't be into it. For the type of food it is, it's much more expensive than the places he would frequent. And, to be blunt, there weren't a lot of Asian people eating here. This is very good Americanized Chinese food. It has better flavor and better preparation that your typical "take out Chinese," but that's the general category I'd place this restaurant in.
