Well prepared, tasty, and "safe" or easy Chinese food, using only the parts of that chicken that were used to eating in the US. Though I'm not planning on bringing my dad, we'll go back for sure.
author: M B.

description: Rating only on the taste of food. While it's not bad, it is the furtherest thing from authentic Chinese food possible.
author: Nora X.

description: Over priced and inconsistent. The hot and sour soup was so bad we had to send it back. The fried rice was full of mushy meat and cucumbers. $13 for pea leaves and garlic?! The pot stickers and Shanghai dumplings were both very good and the server was nice but do yourself a favor and avoid this place!
author: Danny O.

description:
Great dimsum!! of course we went when we were hungry, and of course we over ordered. but everything was delicious! The pork and seafood shumai were my favorite.

My only con is the plate of fried rice wasn't anything special and it came out last after all the other dishes had been served. For being priced at around $10, I was a little disappointed at the smaller size of the dish and that it only consisted of peas, carrots, and bits of egg. Not worth it, but still good enough to eat.
author: Natasha S.

description: Absolutely atrocious service. Waiting here for over an hour for basic dumplings while the tables around us all got their food. Worst service ever. Food didn't even impress very mediocre. NEVER go here not worth it at all by any stretch of the imagination.
author: Rahat K.

description: VERY americanized/expensive dimsum food. I had high hopes for this place because of the good yelp reviews but was pretty disappointed. Lots of places on Irving (in inner sunset) have cheaper and better dimsum.
author: Christina L.

description:
Short version: the food was good, but the service was terrible.

Went to dim sum on Sunday, they were not that crowded. Had about a 10 min wait when we got there. Seated at about 12:45. We give the server our order card and proceed to wait. After about 45 min of waiting we finally receive our first dish. We think "maybe the kitchen is understaffed, things will pick up now that the place is emptying out." No such luck. We proceed to get one dish about every 15 to 20 minutes. Tables around us all got their food in one go. We even saw people get seated, order, and receive all of their food (some of which we had ordered and were still waiting on!) in the time it took for one dish to get to us. We asked what was going on, and the server gave no explanation. Finally after 2 hours of waiting and 4 plates our still-hungry party of 4 decided to leave and ask for the check. From there we had to argue with the server and get the dishes that we never received taken off the final bill. In all, a really unpleasant experience. With all of the excellent dim sum places available in the city, I will definitely not be coming to this one again.
author: J T.

description: I found great Chinese in the Castro at a reasonable price!  So this place it tiny but if you get there at the start of lunch, you're in business.  The food was delicious and came out quickly.  For 3 people the bill was $40 or something like that.  The have a full menu as well as dim sum and also a full beer and wine menu.  The service was friendly and everyone said goodbye as we left thanking us for our business.  Definitely worth a try and I will be coming back!  Can't believe it was my first time there.
author: Chris O.

description: Love this neighborhood gem! Friendly staff and great food. The vegetarian buns and shrimp and chive dumplings are my favorites!
author: Rachel G.

description: Had dim sum for lunch.  Service was excellent and food very good.  Will definitely go back.
author: Duncan R.

description: Really good. Have only tried the chongqing but it was exceptional. Good quality meat that is cooked to have a nice crunchy outside. Sauce is delicious & spicy. Will go back to try other options.
author: Patrick D.

description: I really love their dim sums, pork shu mai , shrimp tofu and shrimp dumplings are delicious... The next time Imma go there in the morning :)
author: Francis A.

description:
I drive past here all the time and my boyfriend and I finally decided to try it. The Place is always busy and the reviews were good. I think the owner or someone related was our server, we told her it was our first time so she started recommending things. Everyone around us had the usual, fried green beans, dim sum, so we decided to be different and go with all her "house specialty" recommendations. 

We ended up getting Nam Yu Spare Ribs and Spicy Fish Fillet. The spare ribs resembled Chicken Tikka Masala but more brown, and the fish tasted like hot oil, nothing else. Neither one of them was visually appealing and I actually had to have them remove the fish, it was completely inedible and the fish and tofu together were just mush. I grew up in my parents restaurant so really am not a difficult customer and only say something when it's truly bad.
When I told her we didn't like it she told me how many Chinese people go in there and order it all the time. 1. That will not make me like it. 2. I DOUBT many Chinese people are running to the Castro to Mama Ji's for authentic Fish and Tofu. 
We then ordered chicken Su mei and she brought us pork because she said the chicken would take too long. 
She still charged me for the fish then brought us a dessert of a macaroon and oreo, which I can tell you, I am Chinese and those desserts are not typically paired with Chinese  food.

I think if you stick to the basics, dumplings, green beans, chow mein you're fine. Just be careful of the House Specialty's and recommendations.
author: Diana L.

description: The best Szechuan ! The dry fried beans and numbing fish were delicious. And the service wonderful.
author: Gretchen P.

description: Food was just ok, nothing special but service is horrible!! warning !! dont come if u want rude servers/owner!
author: Alexis K.

description:
I recently moved to SF after graduating from school in Palo Alto, and one of the things I was most excited about was having urban dining options once again.  I was quite disappointed after settling on a place in upper market that there were actually few good dining options in the area.  While a burrito or a slice of pizza might be exactly what I want after a night out, there were shockingly few options for a good dinner.

Enter MaMa Ji's.  A newcomer like me here to save the day.

I know this is said many times in reviews below, but the owners and waitstaff are great and really bring a warmth to an admittedly basic space. 

Forget the space though, I was there for the food.  I went with a couple of friends last night, and can really only echo what others have said.   

The food was great overall, but I would, if you like spice, to especially focus on the spicy items on the menu.  I had the special fish with tofu and it had just the right level of spice.  The kind that gives just the faintest hint of sweat on your brow, that fills your mouth with a kick, but that does not burn off your tastebuds.

The other dishes (wonton soup and Mao Po tofu) were equally good, but as I mentioned the spicy dishes are where the restaurant shines.

One last thing, the prices here are ridiculous.  While they may seem in line with other asian restaurants in the area, that is before they come out and you realise each dish on its own is enough to feed a small family.  I used a bit of the sauce from my dish this morning to add some flavour to  some eggs up and am still able to create an entire additional meal with the leftovers.

Support this local institution.  Looking forward to seeing it succeed in my new adopted city.
author: Doug W.

description: The dim sum is cheap and delicious. What more needs to be said? Great place for a Sunday brunch. It's not very big though, so you won't easily fit more than 4 people.
author: Christophe T.

description:
We decided to brunch here the sunday we spent up in SF. It's a tiny restaurant situated right in the Castro, and it was really cute!

Service was fast, we were running late for an appointment and we were able to get in and out. Food came so quickly!

Im a dim sum noob but my boyfriend is a seasoned veteran and ordered for us. We got the spicy cold noodles, bbq pork buns, soup dumplings, the pea sprout shrimp dumplings, and the sesame dessert buns. 

Spicy cold noodles: SO AMAZING. I inhaled this. My boyfriend seemed surprised as how peanutty it was but it was divine. I secretly wish they were warm, but when I said that's partner looked at me as if I said something blasphemous. 

Bbq pork buns: I was not impressed. I've had these homemade for me before, and in my humble opinion they were much better at home. These buns were entirely too sweet (much more than I tasted in the homemade ones) and it threw me off. Also, there was so little meat inside them that I couldn't really taste it. 

Pea sprout dumplings: delicious!! Big pieces of shrimp and good flavor. 

Soup dumplings: not too much soup in them but good flavor. They brought the ginger and mixed it all up with the vinegar, which is apparently the traditional way to eat them. Super yummy!

Sesame buns (dessert): very yummy. Super crispy outside, complimented by the lightly sweet red bean paste on the inside. 


All in all, a good dim sum brunch experience. We got in and out quickly, food was good, and the whole bill without tip was $27. And I walked out of there stuffed with a doggy bag.
author: Emily L.

description: Very warm and inviting decor, with a great selection of dumplings.
author: Krish P.

description: Able to seat a party of six on short notice. Everyone ordered a plate a shared, everything was delicious.
author: Ben F.

description: MaMa Ji's is certainly no Yank Sing! There's a much smaller selection of DimSum, no roving carts, about one tenth the size and no huge portrait of MaMa Ji on the wall as you walk in. However, in a number of ways we actually liked it more than Yank Sing. First, we tried several dishes and found every one absolutely delicious!  Then there was the fact that there was no wait for primetime Sunday brunch. Service was quick and courteous; the menu held an extensive selection of Belgian beers and ales as well as a few wines; parking was relatively easy and a major difference: the check was about a third of what it would have been had we dined on similar fare at that other place. So, nothing will ever replace Y.S. but as a delectable (and economic) alternative I highly recommend MaMa Ji's. I know I'll certainly return again and again.
author: Joe M.

description: A bunch of non-traditional Chinese food eaters searching for the real thing.. We heard this place was better than Chinatown, so we went for it.. Lucky we got there early we were the only ones there when they opened and by the time we left the line was out the door.. Spicy, (I mean it) delicious authentic Chinese food. The owners were so kind and explained all the foods and beers to us. We had a blast and enjoyed our dinner immensely! Parking was the only problem.
author: Anna C.

description:
Ever since my boss told me that it was the best Sichuan restaurant in San Francisco, my friends and I basically try to go every week. The food is amazing!  

I've never been to Sichuan but I have had Sichuan food in Singapore, Hong Kong, Beijing and Shanghai and this is definitely on par. So amazing to have something taste so good and then be able to pair it with a Chimay Tripel. Love this place and would definitely recommend it to anyone who loves a little spice in their life :)
author: Kara Y.

description: If you are a fan of Szechuan cuisine, you are at the right place. They have the best Chongqing chicken in SF. Crispy, Tongue-Numbing Spicy - Just the way it should be. And there have a great drinks menu to pair the food with. Go to Yang Sink for  dim sums.
author: Karishma K.

description: The only Chinese restaurant in town serves Belgium beer on tap and authentic Szechuan food at the same time. For those who love spicy food and crave for authentic Chinese dishes, this is the place to go!
author: Tina S.

description: The dim sum is light, fresh, and tasty which are words that sometimes don't go in the same sentence when it comes to dim sum. But at Mama's they do. The portions are just right, the atmosphere is a transformed Queen Malika with long tables, school lights and a very lively vibe to it. It's the definition of the Chinese notion of re nao which roughly translates as a restaurant being hot, loud and boisterous. i.e., it's a happy place. The only downside for our palettes is the nighttime dishes (even toned down) are so very spicy that we couldn't even eat it, which is a shame. But that is the Sichuan style of cooking.
author: Kevin H.

description: We just moved back to the Castro and after seeing this placed consistently packed we decided to try it.  I absolutely love the food!  Full of flavor and just enough spice (well could be too much for some).  The shrimp dumplings are fantastic!  Upon recommendation we ordered the Fish with chiles and sichuan peppers and it was amazing!  We have been back again and had another great meal.  Great food, nice friendly staff, and love that it's so close to our new home!  I am eager to try the dim sum. Great neighborhood spot.  If you like spicy Chinese food I highly recommend!
author: Vince G.

description: MaMa Ji's is the only option for dimsum in the Castro, but it is simply fantastic! Almost everything I've gotten there was good. Egg custard bun, rice rolls, noodle dishes, etc. You've gotta try it at least once!
author: Nick L.

description: A hidden Szechuan gem in the Castro! Stuck with dim sum this time but rest assured I'll be back. Shrimp & chive dumplings, potstickers, and dry fried string beans were very good but ... the pork buns!! They're on the smaller side but the flavor of the filling is perfect. Looking forward to trying more! (Go on a weekday and still be prepared for a short wait).
author: Emily L.

description: I really wanted to like this joint - I really didn't.  We ordered take-out and chose some pretty standard dishes: combo chow mein (greasy and bland); ma po tofu (greasy and bland); crispy fried eggplant (greasy, thickly breaded); and pea shoots with garlic (the star of the show).  So, long story short, the food is greasy and most of it is bland and uninspiring.  I wouldn't go back.
author: robert l.

description: Amazeballs.  Amazeballs.  Amazeballs.  Literally.  Little balls of amazing, followed by heaping plates of amazing.
author: Kate T.

description: Went b/c of the good yelp review to this CART-LESS dimsum spot, and the service was so bad I cannot recommend it. The dimsum was ok, not amazing, and certainly not seemingly worthy of the high recommendation on Yelp. Had the fried shrimp, which is my all time fave, and it was smaller than I'm used to, just not as crispy and flavorful as I like, and finally, they did not have the sweet mayonnaise dipping sauce that yummy places like Ocean Seafood in Alameda has. The eggplant with stuffed shrimp was so bland that I actually gave it to some guests sitting at the next table. The shanghai dumplings were good, although seemed small, and the steamed dumplings were fine. The tea is not free - has to be ordered by individual cup not by the pot, and the whole meal was pricey and unsatisfying. Worst of all was the waiter who whizzed by, failed to take my neighbors orders for over 10 minutes, yelled about the restaurant, and made the experience unpleasant.
author: Kelly M.

description: Love Mama Ji's. I love the soup dumplings and pot stickers. Lots of other things I have tried on the menu, but i always go back for the dumplings.
author: Anne K.

description:
I "kid" you not:
Saturday, June 8, 2013 5:30pm - Upon entry to "MaMa Ji's Dim Sum and Dinner" restaurant, waitress waived the front window table to us as she gathered our napkin/chop stick/dish placements (no silverware). There were two other parties in restaurant.  One-couple and one-family w/two children (aprox. age: 6yrs old and 3yrs old).
At 8 minutes: waitress returns to take our order, but hadn't given us menus.
At 10 minutes: I watched waitress hand menus to another party that arrived and was seated after us.
At 13 minutes: Waitress brings 2-waters to table (no ice), and makes second trip to drop off menus.
At 21 minutes: Waitress returns to take our order (each dish ordered was asked and confirmed to be strictly vegetarian):
 Deep fried spring rolls; Vegetarian pot stickers; Deep fried eggplant; 2-side rice; 1-diet coke
At 26 minutes: I was in the restroom washing hands when dinner partner's diet coke arrives in can and full glass of ice (yea!).  He was informed that the house was out of vegetarian pot stickers (waaah-waaah).  Ordered item was replaced with "bean curd" something or other.
At 30 minutes: Wobbly table was getting on nerves, so I took one napkin and folded several times to place under table leg to secure.
At 36 minutes: egg rolls (3) arrived, without silverware.  Silverware was requested.
At 39 minutes: another family w/two children (aprox. age: 2yr old; 4mo old with stroller) arrive and are seated at perpendicular table next to ours.
At 40 minutes: after flagging waitress, asked for drinking straws, silverware and additional napkin.
At 42 minutes: waitress brings sweet and sour sauce for egg rolls to table along with drinking straw, silverware and napkin.
At 45 minutes: dinner partner burns mouth and spits bite of piping hot egg roll into napkin.
At 50 minutes: child at next table turns around to face our table, and then begins to stare at us while her mother begins to breast feed the younger sibling.  Father picks up a couple of crayons and begins to color in a book, attempting to coax the child back to their table.
At 55 minutes: another male waiter brings the tofu dish to the table.  It is cooked in a ground beef sauce.  After examining it for a minute, it becomes apparent to us that the sauce is indeed meat based and we ask for a replacement dish of what we ordered (vegetarian).
At 55 minutes: eggplant dish arrives.  The food item resembled battered and deep fried zucchini.  It appeared to be a very dry item, so we thought we would wait for the rest of our meal to arrive before eating.  We later learned that the food item was heavily salted.  Heavily.
At 60 minutes: we prompted the waitress for our 2-orders of white rice.
At 63 minutes: waitress brings the white rice and quickly runs off (we now had dry white rice and dry fried eggplant before us).
At 65 minutes: having no idea how salty the eggplant dish was going to be, we flag male waiter and ask for soy sauce, which he immediately brings.
At 68 minutes: the tofu dish finally arrives in a spicy bean sauce, cooked with frozen diced carrots and frozen peas.  The food item was also heavily salted.  Very heavily.
At 70 minutes: small children at 3 separate tables are either crying or throwing tantrums.
At 75 minutes: a male manager/owner began walking around to all of the tables asking the parties if all was okay.  We overheard another party complain that they had placed their order a while ago and while making the complaint, a waiter brought out their first item.  This manager shortly thereafter arrived at our table to ask if all was okay.  We were speechless and just nodded, "sure".
At 85 minutes: we were able to finish half of our meal, one diet coke and three glasses of water.  The menu stated "no msg", but it was so low in flavor and so heavily salted that we did not ask for a container to take the unfinished portions home (1/2 of the meal).  I have never, not taken "left over" food with me, if even to give to a homeless person.
At 90 minutes: we paid for the meal and for the duration of our 8 minute walk home, couldn't stop thinking about the poor dining experience.  We will not return.
author: Paul In S. F.

description: Last night I died and went to Dim Sum HEAVEN! The  BBQ Pork Buns were  like fluffy clouds with a delicious zesty tasty filling.  Shu-Mai to die for!  However the Salt Baked Shrimp with Thai Chiles - AMAZING!  Too bad I didn't have time to let it all digest and start over again!!  (Eating the leftovers, today for lunch - excellent!)  It's popular and a small restaurant so plan accordingly.
author: Robert M.

description: Wonderful food and staff. great new add on to our neighborhood. would recommend to friends.
author: Captain Muffin D.

description: Just what we were looking for thanks Yelp!  We picked MaMa Ji's strictly by it's Yelp reviews. The dumplings (Shanghai, shrimp, shumi) were great and the steamed pork buns were little clouds of Yum!   The chicken noodle wonton soups was a bit lacking in flavor I'd pass on that next time. Over all it was a great meal and the staff was super friendly and helpful with ordering.
author: Geo S.

description: I've been here a few times for dine in and take out.  All good experiences!  Great food prepared quickly.  I'd recommend trying the Cold Spicy Noodles!  They are a favorite of mine.
author: Lauren D.

description: Amazing schezuan food. The owners are always present with a big smile to make you feel welcome. Great beer selection which you never find at these places. It gets packed so go early. They do an amazing job getting large groups seated. Just go.
author: Pierre C.

description: This is the best Chinese food we have ever had.  We over ordered because we wanted to try everything and it was all amazing.  The spring rolls were fresh and crispy.  The soup dumplings were the best we have ever had.  The cold noodles were amazing.  We had multiple types of dumplings and shumai and it was all really good.  Highly recommend and worth the wait.  We will be back!
author: Erin D.

description:
Wow! What an excellent meal. And what a great addition to the food scene in the Castro which I feel is a bit lacking.

Every dish we had, a variety of dim sum, pea leaves, pot stickers were excellent. They also have a great beer selection, not the usual Anchor, Stella, Heineken, blah, blah, blah. 

There's a few kinks to iron out, service / decor, but they've only been open 3 weeks. Going back Tuesday night for a friend's b-day dinner. Can't wait!

Go MaMa Ji!!
author: Roy K.

description: This place gets a lot of hype, but it wouldn't be my first choice for Chinese food (at least not dinner). As a group of 4, we waited ~30 minutes for dinner on a weeknight. Once seated, we ordered a variety of dishes including the Sichuan fish stew, soup dumplings, dry fries green beans. The food was A-OK. Good, but nothing special.
author: J L.

description: Dim sum was great. I really enjoyed the seafood, which mostly contained shrimp. Staff is friendly as well.
author: Zain M.

description: We had the beef dumpling special, which was ok. The pumpkin with duck eggs was ok, but lacked seasoning. The triple c chicken wings were excellent.
author: Maria G.

description: The food here is decent, not amazing, but definitely not terrible. The problem is the service. We've been to Mama Ji's almost every time we've traveled to SF, and each time the food takes forever. On our most recent visit (yesterday), our party of four waited for each dish separately - had we waited until everyone had their food, some dishes would have been sitting on the table for 15-20 minutes. The waiters are all super friendly, and the vibe of the place is great, but just be ready to eat when each dish comes out.
author: Michael A.

description: Love the spicy dishes!  Finally a place to get good spicy food in the hood.  Great new find.
author: Tony K.

description: This was the most unique Chinese food I've had. The couple who owns and runs the restaurant are hospitable, social, and accommodating. The recipes are from her grandmother and they don't disappoint. I wasn't a huge fan of the Belgium beer pairing but the seasoning and spices on the chicken are really spicy and delicious. I left sweating but with a smile at the same time.
author: Ryan M.

description: Best dim sum in the city, by far. Have had multiple Cantonese friends say stuff like "This tastes just like how my mom makes it" etc. They also have an awesome Szechuan menu in the evenings, while still serving a subset of the dim sum as appetizers.
author: Eric G.

description:
Best Szechuan food I've had in America.  It's very, very authentic Szechuan.  We had the tofu, pea blossoms, and a custard bun.  Yum.  Everything was so so good.

They also have the best coffee from Ritual Roasters and tea from Red Blossom.  The beer selection looked really, really good, too.  This is a treasure in our hood.  Yay!!!  So happy it's here.
author: chad H.

description: I absolutely can not stop craving mama Ji's!!!! The dim sum is amazing and so are all the other dishes. Great wine and beer selection. This is a small family business. Gotta support places like this that make San Francisco special :)
author: Cel H.

description: The food is great!! BUT . . . the last few times . . . when Mama Ji is not there . . . the service is miserable.  Potstickers coming AFTER a main dish, or not at all. One entrée coming with a second one no where in site? We were getting to be 'regulars', but their service irregularity is causing us to think again. Maybe online ordering/delivery is now the best option.
author: Stephen J.

description:
4 stars for dim sum in the Castro. 

It's decent-- not amazing but not terrible. Pork buns, pot stickers, Lotus leaf rice thing, etc. wonton soup is also good, especially when fighting a cold! Dried fried green beans are excellent. 

Dim sum portions are stingy. 3 pieces/ order on average. 

Avoid the fragrant fish eggplant. Way over spiced and sauced ( no fish at all). It was rated a 1 for mild spice on the menu -- we generally like spicy food and we couldn't eat it.  it was like they doused it in extra spicy Kung pao sauce. Yuck. -1 star for this dish alone.
author: J L.

description:
Very delicious food - amazing dumplings! Flavor was fresh and smacked of ginger.  The Sweet and Sour Pork was crispy and good.  The Chinese Broccoli was "knock your socks off" good.  Very sweet and cute server and the owners were very nice.

The won-ton soup had amazingly fresh wontons but the broth was not my favorite...
That's the only star they are missing.

Great wine and beer selection - I was surpised by the reasonably priced Montapulciano and Chimay on tap.

All in all, I will definitely be back!!

YUMMMY.
author: Yo M.

description: I am so glad I/we returned to MaMa Ji's to give it another try (and this review is about six months overdue!). It is truly a gem in terms of food and quality, although sometimes I feel the service is still a little lacking. That being said, it is a fun atmosphere, clean restaurant and excellent food. The only other downside is that they're constantly busy, but I can live with that. I especially love the spicy cold noodles! Just the right kick!
author: Torrpedo T.

description: I have very much enjoyed the hot and numbing fish during previous visits and that dish alone kept me coming back for more until last night (Memorial Day). Maybe there was different chef due to the holiday but the fish was not crispy as usual and there was something that may have been burnt peppercorns covering the fish which were crispy and tasted bitter, my plate was covered with them at the end of the meal. Not being one to complain I let it go even when the owner thanked us for coming in and said he hoped we enjoyed our meal as we were leaving.  PLEASE make your hot and numbing fish great once again!!
author: Bill B.

description: The dim sum was so fresh and tasty.  Was also so cool to be able to grab a delirium beer with the meal!  Will definitely be coming back here for dim sum, can't wait to try the dinner menu as well.
author: Jonathan C.

description: Yum! Yum! And YUM! Fantastic food, and inexpensive. We had to wait for about 15 minutes this past Saturday around 1pm. 100% worth the wait. We ordered about 5 dim sum items plus the kung pao chicken. All were delicious. Most often when I go to dim sum and the bill arrives it's a scary thing. NOT here!
author: Rob F.

description: Not the best.  I really wanted it to be awesome.  We ordered way more items than we needed, mainly because I wanted to try everything I like and see how great it was.  Unfortunately, I was disappointed.  Unfortunately, you likely will be as well.  There are many better dim sum options, even in china town.
author: Mike I.

description: This restaurant rivals china town right in the castro. Good tasting fresh dim sim served by a very helpful team of servers.  Very reasonable.
author: Cheryl T.

description: Not traditional Chinese dim sum at all. If you are Chinese, please do not come. You will be disappointed.
author: Cindy L.

description: Incredible!!! Wholesome, authentic, delicious, like MADLY delicious. Try the Kung Pao Tofu, you will be blown away.
author: Zo T.

description: Dim sum in the Castro! Really good, reasonably priced dim sum served by a pleasant and attentive staff. The chili noodles are superb and the dim sum comes out fresh and hot..so much more so than you would find at an old school place with carts. I cannot wait to go back.
author: Jamie C.

description: I CRAVE this place pretty much daily. I've always been a dim sum fan, so I was thrilled to discover it was not only in my neighborhood but also delicious. What I didn't expect was how well Belgium beer would pair with Szechuan cuisine! This place is just like coming home, and the owners make you feel like family. Comforting and authentic dishes, good friends and neighbors, and a great bar and dessert menu to boot. I can't wait for my next visit!
author: Jodi W.

description: I am in love. What a cozy wonderful spot with incredible dim sum. We enjoyed everything we ordered... chicken wonton soup, spring rolls, cilantro shrimp dumplings, chow mein, and sesame balls. Everything came out hot and very fresh. The service was equally warm. Can't wait to come back and try everything else on the menu:)
author: Katie L.

description:
I've eaten here twice, and I'm looking forward to many more MaMa Ji meals. Here are some things I really like about it:

-Delicious spicy-hot food, and dishes for more timid palates
-You can request your level of spiciness on most things
-Some dishes that you won't find anywhere else in town
-Very fresh 
-Not greasy compared to other Chinese restaurants
-Food is brought out as it becomes ready
-Very friendly, nice people work here.
-Service is good
-Smallish menu with good variety
-Very good Belgian beers
-CLEAN!
author: Kate M.

description:
very good dim sum. shrimps were very fresh and great texture. absolutely none of that fishy smell yu get from a lot of cheap dim places. it's all about the plump when you bite down on that shrimp dumpling and mama gets 5/5 stars for that!

the shrimp stuft eggplant doesn't really work, the ingredients are fine and it's cooked ok, but it's too big, bland, oily, falls apart easily... nice try but drop this one fellas;-(

you will wait a while, and wait, and wait for food but it's worth it because it really is fresh.

 you will pay twice as much as you might at good luck on clement, but it's worth it because no fishy smell and perfect plump.

pork shu mai was also excellent.

great service. good packaging of to go order.

this place has the potential for 5 stars upon more visits.
author: Jim S.

description: Best Chinese food in the neighborhood, I'm never disappointed. Hot and Sour soup, and Shanghai dumplings are my favs. Awesome beer selection too.
author: Julie S.

description: Delicious, quality food; Super friendly service; Quick turnaround on orders; Decent prices. I'm super excited to come back!
author: alison c.

description: I'm loving their cilantro shrimp dumplings and red bean paste bun so much! Just live nearby the restaurant and I can grab some breakfast dimsum&coffee to-go without hassle when school reopens.
author: Ying L.

description: My new favorite place....fresh ingredients, nearby location without the HK Lounge wait time... Lovely place
author: M S.

description: Order the fish in chili sauce then take the leftover sauce home and use it for two meals at home. It's WONDERFUL. Try to go when it's half empty or it's too noisy to talk. Decibels when full: 80. Love the fact that I can get both delicious Chinese food and good coffee at the same place.
author: Jane M.

description: My boyfriend and I had just gotten back from a trip and were craving dim sum. With the amount of laundry we had, a trek to the Richmond was out of the question, so we decided to order from Mama Ji's via Postmates given the high Yelp rating. We ordered ~6 items. When the order arrived only 2 of the items we ordered were included and we had been charged a lot more than estimates by Postmates. We called Postmates to inquire and after some time on hold, it was determined that Mama Ji's had changed our order because items we selected were not available. I understand that this happens and it's not a big deal, but switching a $5 for a  2 $11 items and then failing to include the more expensive items is shady. We were charged $23 for Seafood Shanghai dumplings which we didn't order, and didn't arrive anyway. The restaurant sent bland veggie egg rolls instead of steamed pork buns. Postmates rectified all of Mama Ji's errors, but this shady place should be avoided.
author: Laura G.

description: The food here was amazing but what I lived the most is the atmosphere and the service. Marv was awesome!! Sweet man.
author: Julie K.

description: Amazing Chinese food!  Was pleasantly surprised last Friday night, will be back again tonight for dinner.  Such a great addition to the neighborhood.
author: John F.

description: Fantastic dim sum and combination with Belgian beer. Super friendly owners and convenient location. Definitely going back.
author: Amy P.

description: The steamed pork buns were fantastic, as was the rest of the dim sum menu. Great place in the Castro, with a few outdoor tables!
author: David M.

description: Dry Fried Beans were incredible. Major party in my mouth! Best food so far on our visit to SF.
author: Willow M.

description: The friend pumpkin dish was fried to a crisp and delicious. The other stuff was not so good, but the sheer amazingness of the friend pumpkin dish will likely luer me back in for another visit to mama ji.
author: Isaac R.

description: I love mama jis, though today I was very disappointed to find out that they changed the menu and removed the non-pork dumplings and steam buns. These options made this place the best for dim sum. I hope they bring it back soon! Definitely a 5 star place with the old menu.
author: Zain K.

description: If you like spicy Sichuan in the Castro, this is THE place to go. Dumplings are a staple, but we have liked everything we've ordered so far.  I'm also partial to noodle soups.  Very fresh vegetables.  Generally very nice staff. It gets VERY crowded and the staff can get a bit overwhelmed.  They have a small handful of tables on the sidewalk patio, so you can dine w with your pooch, but because you're right on the sidewalk, if your dog is reactive to other dogs, you should keep your dog at home. Public transport or ride share here because parking is limited to street parking only.
author: Chibimaru L.

description: It's a very hip, comfortable, easy-going, quintessentially San Francisco place offering extremely high-quality fare. We came for midday dim sum and wished we could have stayed all day sipping oolong tea until dinner when we could start all over with sichuan dishes and Dupont belgian beers. We loved every dish we tried from the turnip cake to the shrimp chive dumplings. It was so good. And where else can you have Ritual Roasters Coffee, choose from 4 belgian beers on tap (no to mention the bottle selection), and Red Blossom tea with delicious dim sum? The location is great, too. It's on a quieter part of 18th, away from the main on a residential block with victorian row houses that makes it all the more San Franciscan. This sweet little place is clearly very lovingly cultivated by the owners. I look forward to eating there again.
author: Nicole C.

description: Holy, friggin Moly.  Suddenly, they are awesome!  I went there a few times before they changed over fully to chinese food and the dumplings were ok, but I just went today and they were really super duper awesome!  Now that they've renovated and gone over to only chinese food, this restaurant is so good.  Shrimp and cilantro steamed dumplings are sooooooo good.  I will definitely be a regular here.
author: Natalie L.

description: Great, intimate spot for some basic dim sum and Szechuan noodles.  Delish!
author: Lily L.

description: I came back on a Sunday night with a group of friends. There were a lot of us, so it took a while to be seated, but everyone was very nice and super patient with some people who were a bit rowdy. This time we tried a variety of non dim sum dishes as well as a couple dim sum as appetizers. The regular dishes were very tasty and well portioned. I appreciated the friendly service. I will probably come back, as it's in my neighborhood and my friends like it. In fact, they told me to revise my previous 3 star (a-ok) review up higher LOL, so I did!
author: Merredith L.

description: Just enjoyed a fabulous meal there. A bit of a wait but entirely worth it. Every dish was flavorful and true it's spirit.  Everything prepared fresh, served hot and always with a smile. Wish I lived here so I could go again and again and again!!
author: Amanda H.

description: Tasty and convenient! Glad I finally tried this and will def go back. I love dim sum but it's not always fun to trek across town so I  am glad this opened in my 'hood!
author: Scott H.

description:
Finally, a solid Chinese / dim sum place in the Castro.

Got dinner here with a friend.  She's white, I'm Chinese, and we both enjoyed the food a lot.  She's very picky about the Chinese food she eats (she doesn't like what she calls the "rubbery" texture of the meat at a lot of Chinese places), but nonetheless liked it, and I'm happy to have a solid Chinese place in the neighborhood.

We ordered some dim sum:
- Chicken shu mai
- Pot stickers
- Shrimp + rice wrapped in tea leaves
- BBQ pork bun
- Shao long baozi (Shanghai dumplings)

We also ordered the pea leaves sauteed with garlic and tea.

Everything was great, except the pot stickers, which were kind of lukewarm, but the restaurant has just opened and it seems they're still getting the hang of things, so I'll give them the benefit of the doubt.  The BBQ pork bun, in particular, was nice and fluffy and the pea leaves were sauteed to just the right level of tenderness.  The green tea was great and provided a refreshing way wash down the savory dishes.

This is not the best dim sum you'll ever eat, but it's definitely solid, and you'll be hard-pressed to find a better place in terms of quality and price outside of Chinatown, let alone the Castro.  I hope this place stays open - I'll definitely be back again.
author: Beyang L.

description: This place opened a couple of weeks ago so they are still working out some of the kinks. The food is great and the prices reasonable. I loved it. A great addition to the neighborhood.
author: Lee D.

description: Went here about six months ago and just realised I forgot to review it. Wouldn't normally bother but this place is so wonderful that I couldn't not. I stumbled upon MaMa Ji's after reading a magazine review that gave it 4 stars - which frankly didn't do it Justice. The food was beautiful, the beer delicious - but most of all, the service left me feeling like I'd come for dinner at a friend's. Run by the most welcoming couple, we were talked through our beer and food order, recommended which goes with which, and smiled at warmly throughout. Go for the food, the beer, and the warm fuzzy wuzzys. Can't wait to go back.
author: Jess M.

description: We loved it. Big dumplings, we way over ordered and had to take a couple containers home (which we promptly devoured later). My favorites were the "house specialty" chive shrimp dumplings, but we didn't' get a dumpling that wasn't great. We also got the noodles with chile sauce which I thought were sublime but too spicy for my wife. The Belgian beer selection is an awesome bonus. Just a heads up that they won't seat you until everyone is there and I had dropped my wife and son off to look for parking and it took awhile, not a big surprise in the Castro.
author: Art S.

description: Thank goodness, some place that doesn't blast loud music all the time. Quiet, good food, and always accommodating. This is a nice place for a leisurely meal with one or two friends.
author: Doctor B.

description: My fiancé and I went here for dinner one night while staying at a friends house near by. We were surprised by the very warm environment. We spoke with the owner and his wife who gave us a little history, explaining that they had only been in business for 3 months. The restaurant was PACKED on a Saturday night and was attracting many people. We had the combination chow mein, black tea and a beer. They waitress were on top of filling up our drinks and were prompt to any requests. Good eat in a nice part of Castro!
author: Alison R.

description: Chongqing chicken perfectly fried spicy goodness. Oh the spring rolls are amazing. Restaurant is cozy and service is fast and friendly.
author: Sam G.

description:
of all the times i've been in the castro (which is every week), finally! a chinese dim sum restaurant to look forward to!! i would say that it is probably not a good idea to come in around noon, because there wasn't a server to greet or seat me right away. 

in terms of their selections, their dim sums were great, fresh and cooked very well! i'm
a huge sucker for steamed dim sums and they weren't disappointing at all.
author: Marc K.

description: Great food, fried pumpkin with egg, pea sprouts, dim sum all great but be prepared for so so service.
author: Alison F.

description:
You know how steamed BBQ pork buns usually taste like a lump of stale white Wonder Bread, stuffed with a dried out hot-pink piece of yesterday's pork soaked in a smear of Costco BBQ sauce? Well even if you don't, that is surely how other pork buns will taste to you in the future once you eat at MaMa Ji's.
The food is lovely--fresh, with subtle flavors and intriguing textures, masterfully prepared. High quality and still very reasonably priced.
I am keeping this short because I'm torn about encouraging other people to come here. I want it all to myself!
author: Alene W.

description: This place is awesome. The Beijing style chicken with eggplant and the shanghai dumplings are my favorite go to options, but I also like most of the other dishes I have tried. I wish that the menu was a little more descriptive, but the service is friendly and fast.
author: Luis H.

description: Previous to my most recent visit, I would have given this place 4 stars for the fresh dim sum. The food has always been a cut above the rest, and the service passable. However, my most recent visit left much to be desired AND the turnip cakes were not up to their usual standards. Whereas before they were impressively fresh (I could taste the turnip) and not oily, this time they were no different than other turnip cakes I've had at other dim sum places. What prompted me to write this review, other than the disappointing lack of consistency of the turnip cakes, was the service. Nobody came to take our order (a piece of paper) for a long time. Our dishes took longer to arrive. Some did not come for a long time, until we asked, twice. In all, I had to flag someone down no fewer than 7 times to get through the meal and out the door. 7 times! And there were definitely lag times when the restaurant was not packed, so it wasn't that they were too busy, just inattentive. Disappointing, because I've been raving about this local neighborhood joint to friends and now I'm less than enthusiastic about going back myself.
author: Carol C.

description: Mama Ji's gives the Castro area a real good choice for Chinese food. The dim sum and spicy plates help make it a cut above the rest. The hot and numbing fish was fried heaven and the shrimp dumplings I had were tasty. Also a thumbs up for their long list of beers (bottle and tap). We drank a very dark Belgium beer that was filling (St Bernadus AB12) and good. The only real minus on the place is the noise within. The place is usually busy and the noise level can make it challenging to hold an extended conversation.
author: Tony P.

description: Very nice overall. Had pea sprout dumpling 5*, shrimp rice roll 4*, deep fried shrimp dumpling 4*, shrimp stuffed egg plant 4* and steamed golden lava bum 4*. Nice service and was not do crowded for a 4,5 yelp star Dim Sum. They may need more non-pork dishes...
author: Ali E.

description: We absolutely loved this meal and this place. Shanghai dumplings, pea sprout shrimp dumplings, pan fried pot stickers and steamed BBQ pork buns to die for! The spicy cold noodles were delicious too!
author: Amanda M.

description: Wow. Bad service and it wasnt busy. 2 is soley the kung pow and beer selection. Arrived they said seat ourselves. Didnt come get drink orders for well over 5 minutes (1 other table occupied and its 4:30) finally get our drinks and order. We order dumplings kung pow and chongqing chicken. We got our food after others who arrived after us (not a huge deal but the dumpling appetizer didnt show up until we were half through our entrees) so appetizer didnt happen and we dont recommend the shanghai dumplings they were bland and not worth it. So we next needed boxes we asked another server (ours literally walked out the front door never to return) he went off never came back. We got our own boxes. Then we finally flag someone down for the check. After confusion we get it and wait another 5 to 10 to get it ran. Jesus. The kungpow is good but get it to go the service is not good mind you its dead ive got better service at slammed restaurants
author: Drew V.

description: Just Mediocre. This place gets busy at lunch time, but I think a lot of that owes being ever-so slightly off the beaten path of the trendy part of Castro. Their Dim Sum is decent. I especially like anything with pork, though I recommend against which ever one comes wrapped in rice noodle, as it just can't seem to hold together. The sweet/sour pork buns are also a decent choice. Though the quality of the food is goos, the environment and the service come up a bit shabby. There's constantly a draft chilling both you and your food, and the staff tend to ignore your table. We had to flag our waiter down to order, to order again, and finally to ask for the check. That's 3 too many times. They also had to return to our table to confirm what we got to drink.
author: Nik K.

description: Ok Dim Sum lovers, this place is for you!  I've eaten dim sum all over the world's china towns and this place is very good.  Nice cozy restaurant cleaner than your typical china town joint.  They have the famous shainghai style soup dumplings and they are great!  Staff was friendly and service was good and oh yeah, they have Belgium beers on tap!  One of the owners I think is european as he was in restaurant while I was there, but did not chat with him.
author: Mark B.

description: Fabulous Chinese food. Wait not too long...they are fast...lol...dumplings are outstanding ..so is asparagus shrimp!
author: Kelvin J.

description: Excellent Chinese food, more authentic than most.  Great dim sum appetizers and deserts are delicious.  There is some super spicy items on the menu that may take you by surprise, so get ready to wipe your forehead.  The owners are genuinely nice.  You can request items that are not on the menu, the Kung Pao with fried tofu is one of those and is exceptionally delicious. Love the pot stickers also and vegetable dishes are tasty and fresh. The soups including the hot and sour soup and won ton are not so great, a little bland, I had to add vinegar to the Hot and sour to make it tangier but did not make it memorable.
author: Kevin D.

description: Love this place. Super fresh dumplings and unexpectedly good selection of beer! Run by a nice husband/wife team.
author: Alex M.

description: Great dimsum, nice atmosphere, lots of sunlight (if it is daytime & sunny). They pay attention to all the details.
author: David W.

description: Awesome little spot.  Great dim sum.  Got seated right away at the window for good people watching.
author: Max G.

description: This place is a nice surprise and pretty impressive.  I do agree with some of the other yelpers, there are a few kinks the restaurant needs to work out but other than that and most important the food is great!  The dim sum is a definite must.  I'm also happy you can order it for dinner because sometimes you just have a craving for it!  The dim sum is fresh and the items aren't too large or too small.  I also appreciated the owner being present and making sure everyone was enjoying their dinner and having a good time.  The wait staff is friendly,there is good energy in the restaurant and best of all, affordable prices.  It's a great new local spot to have dinner with friends or a date.  This a wonderful addition to the neighborhood and I can't wait to go back and try some of their other dishes!  My favorite part... all the spicy entrees on the menu.  Yum!
author: Marita S.

description: Awful service I had to get my own menu bcuz the waiter was too busy flirting with a customer! It's a dimsum spot so the food should be relatively quick not so much it took 30 minutes and counting still waiting and the place isn't even full! Wtf??? Never again overpriced Asian food
author: melissa e.

description: Delicious! I highly recommend the shrimp and cilantro dumplings! I live nearby, so I do see good business everyday and returning customers. Nice little spot :-)
author: Jacquie L.

description: My new favorite dim sum and Chinese restaurant.  Cute ambience, nice neighborhood away from the craziness of the Castro and quality authentic fresh and Clean!  Check it out!
author: Michael R.

description: First time there, I ordered shrimp dumplings, which were ok, and cold vegetable noodles, which they accidentally put pork on. Completely flavorless and overpriced. My friend reported that his vegetable bun was excellent, but the vegetarian treasure box was dinky and awful. Inconsistent and sloppy service. Won't be returning.
author: Seghel Y.

description: Love the food.  Love that we have dim sum in the Castro.  Please, please, please turn down the lights for dinner.  Way too bright in there.  Until you do, it's lunch only for me.
author: Brian S.

description: I came here to eat tonight with some friends.  We arrived at 6:20pm, the restaurant was relatively empty.  We ordered appetizers around 6:25pm.  7:15pm Nothing came.  People that arrived after us and ordered way after us started getting their food before us.  I mentioned to the owner that i'm very sorry to complain, but people that ordered after us are getting their food before us!  He said it was because we ordered the shrimp chicken shu mai which takes 15 minutes to steam.  It was a lie because we ordered it at 6:25pm. I know the time because i received a text from a friend at 6:30pm, but it was right after we ordered the appetizers.  They simply forgot to put the order in and then tried to lie about it.  This ordeal caused an argument at my table.  My friend got upset at me for saying something even though i was polite about it.  When the appetizer finally came it was after our dinner was ordered although dinner was ordered 15 mins after the appetizer.  After the shitty service, my friend and i got into an argument about how much to tip.  Our bill was 58 dollars and i felt that 63 was more than enough.  My friend wanted to give a normal tip bc he works in the tipping industry, i disagreed (i am one who normally always leaves 25% tip minimum, i've been a waiter before also).  We got into an argument about it.  Ughhhh.  Fuck this place and their shitty service!!!!!!!!
author: Brandon P.

description: Everything here is delicious!  I'm not sure I'd come here just for dim sum because their dim sum menu is pretty small but all the dim sum I tried were quite tasty.  What I'm really craving however is Mama Ji's bean curd (veggie is good but I recommend getting the meaty one ;)), their eggplant is off the chain as is their fiery fried fish - love that szechuan spicy chili oil.  It's not the biggest place so it can get busy and you may have to flag someone down but the staff are warm, friendly and attentive and the owners are very nice.  Decent beer & wine and nice tea selection.
author: Suzanne V.

description:
Unlike other reviewers, I'm not a fan of the dim sum here- but this is still one of the best Chinese restaurants in SF. The menu is homey but sophisticated Chinese comfort food and there's a well-considered beer list.

I love the fried turnip cake, the country ribs, and they do a great job with vegetables- especially green beans. My quibble with the dim sum is that like so many restaurants, it's ordinary- the product seems to come from a vendor (Kingdom of Dumpling?) and is completely outshone by the in-house production.

High heat levels. If there are three red peppers next to an item on the menu, they mean it. Service can be flaky but always cheerful.
author: Rocco P.

description: Food is delicious and service always great! Fried pumpkin is amazing, as is the fried eggplant. The potstickers are my favorite and we always need to order a second helping. Love this place
author: Amy S.

description:
I came here the 7th week they were open and the service and kitchen were already completely up to snuff. The Szechuan style food here is done perfectly and they won't coddle you with dulled down spice if you happen to be a gwai lo. Unfortunately I can't even remember what I ordered at this point, but I do remember one of the dishes had star of anise in it which wasn't listed on the menu. I can't stand the licorice like taste of star of anise so that was disappointing, but the rest of the meal more than made up for that though. 

The two owners, a husband and wife, were very friendly, attentive and personable. They told us that they had no experience in the restaurant business, but from the yelp reviews it seems like they're gonna be a big success.
author: Alex P.

description:
Had dinner here recently and everything about the food and service was excellent.  Fresh ingredients and lots of flavor made it a great meal.  We had just a couple of dim sum items and two mains.  All were excellent.

The restaurant is clean and comfortable.  And although every table was filled the noise level was very comfortable for talking.

I would love to give Mama Ji's 5-stars but having been burned by other restaurants in the Castro food-wasteland I will wait to upgrade this review after a few more visits.

Right now I know we will return.
author: Roger C.

description: Fabulous food - she knows what she's doing, and makes various dishes from different regions of China. Service was super friendly - the husband is a real nice guy, the wait staff were sweet & friendly. Mama Ji herself is funning around checking in on each table. The Triple C Chicken was an unexpected treat, the dim sum were yummy (the pork shu mai were my least favorite, but everything else shined), and the custard-filled buns for dessert were unbelievable!
author: judah m.

description: Great Chinese food and even better beer.  I'm not sure which to compliment more.  They have an amazing selection of draft Belgian beers that makes their dishes even more delicious.  Awesome place.
author: Bill K.

description: This is most likely the best Chinese food I have ever eaten ! I have had a lot of Chinese food. Everything is delicious and made well.
author: Shane W.

description: My new favorite place in the castro. Casual and fun. Mamma Ji is great, super nice, and helpful. Great beer + wine selection. Food was awesome. Especially try the smaller appetizer portions. The duck fried pumpkin special was outstanding. If you're looking for ordering advice, it seems like many of the spicy dishes are made with similar sauces, so try not to order too many of them or you'll be getting very similar flavors.
author: Garen C.

description: Would not recomend. The restaurant is often very busy, no clue why. Prices seemed mostly okay though some items seemed a little overpriced in my opinion. But it really wasn't worth anything since the food was just not good. The service was okay. First I was assisted by someone who did not speak English fluently. I guess this was the waitresses assistant. The actual waitress was friendly and mostly available. The manager was visible and checked on the order. But the restaurant looks dirty, old, and out of date and just did not appeal to me. There are many tables crammed side by side in a small space. Meanwhile there is an oversized bar/service area that really has no purpose. The kitchen is behind what looks like a dirty shower curtain. The bathroom was also dirty, small, and looked like someone's apartment bathroom from 1970. There is outdoor seating but there are no heaters.
author: L. A.

description:
Have been to MaMa Ji's twice.  First time on opening day and again this last weekend.  I'm so glad I gave it another chance!  

Top notch, authentic dim sum, just down the street... I couldn't be happier!   The owner was also super nice and accommodating to our stroller space issue, and personally carried a table out to the side walk for us.   How nice is that?!!  

It was the perfect weekend dim sum fare under the sun!  We'll definitely be back!!
author: Jessica C.

description: I live in the Sunset and grew up eating dim sum regularly...Mama Ji's got it down. Tastes very fresh and way less oily than most dim sum joints. Didn't try everything but definitely want to go back for more. Pea Sprout w/shrimp dumplings were super tasty, tofu/shrimp - hot, tasty and NOT fried, shanghai buns - right amount of juice and flavor...and their vegetable buns were delicious - the filling is just how I like it - tofu, rice noodles, etc...only thing I would change is more filling and less dough but not easy to find good vegetable buns here in the city. Wasn't a huge fan of the bean paste noodles - noodles are good (maybe fresh) but sauce isn't my style.
author: Aeon G.

description: I was a little disappointed in MaMa Ji's. After reading the high yelp reviews, I figured it would be great. The food was good but the service made the experience awful. When we walked in, no one greeted us or offered to seat us. We literally stood there for 5 minutes and just decided to sit down. About 15 mins in, a waitress came over to take our order. There is a large coffee menu on the table. I asked for a latte(which is on the menu) and she said, "Oh, I don't want to make that. I don't know how.". Um, ok... I'll have a water then. Then we ordered various dim sum and she was on her way. The plates started coming but unfortunately every plate the waiter brought was not ours. When we would say it wasn't ours, he would just place in on another table, which of course was not their food either. I saw some dim sum end up at 5 different tables. This went on for the entire meal and it took about 2 hours to complete our order. English was definitely not their strong suit, which is fine, but the lack of organization is dismal! Trying to get a bill was close to impossible and we aren't exactly sure if we paid for what we actually got.
author: Rosie G.

description: Delicious Dim Sum and Belgian Beers
author: Allison R.

description:
Not your typical Chinese restaurant. It didn't have terrible customer experience or semi-grungy decor! Super cute family-run place! It's very obvious that the owners really care about providing a good customer experience.

However, the food was lacking.. We came for dinner and was really hoping for a good Szechuan experience in the Castro. We ordered:

 - Green tea - excellent!
 - Pea sprouts with garlic - decent
 - House cold noodles - a little lacking in sesame/ peanut paste
 - FIsh fillet in chili oil - extremely spicy, which was good, but unfortunately was too sour

This place is no Z & Y :(
Will return to try the dim sum!
author: Jenny K.

description: The food was absolutely mouthwatering. The dimsum that Mama Ji's offers is probably the best I have had in the city thus far, and their wings are to die for. Make sure to get there somewhat early since it is a popular place or else you'll have to wait for a good while. But definitely worth the wait! I'm definitely going to eat at Mama Ji's again soon and often!
author: Lauren P.

description: Great Dim Sum and friendly service.. what more can you ask for!  Depth of flavors were on point.
author: A A.

description: Not a very good place to go! We walked in 2of us there were 5 tables with 2 people the rest of the place was empty. Saw a friend and asked if we could be seated next to them NO! that is for 4 people only!!!! Ok we sat at a table for 2 ready to order then a different person you need to move! She didn't ask I was told... They needed that table for 8 people coming move sit in  the middle of the room I was told. I felt if it was going to be this difficult to find a seat I don't think I want to spend my hard eared money in a place from the very beginning  not feeling welcome.  I don't care about how the food is  good(?) or bad I will never give my money to this undeserved and unwelcoming  place I and I will let people I know and meet know how the service is here.
author: Hazzi C.

description: We've been waiting for a great Chinese place to open near us and now we got two in one. Dim Sum is great, really any time of day and the Sichuan is...spicy. And very good. While an odd combination, there are some great Belgian beers in bottle and on tap. For after dinner there's Ritual coffee and small pastries available.
author: Omer T.

description: Looooove this place. Used to live in Beijing and this is the closest I've found in my area (mission/castro) to those flavors. Great spiciness, great dumplings, brown rice, and very friendly staff. Eat here!! :)
author: Scott B.

description: Yum! Mama Ji's never disappoints. Owners are super friendly and accommodating. The food is delicious - particular favorite is the wonton soup with extra noodles. I'd like to see a few more non-spicy options on dinner menu (more for kids than me) but besides that all fantastic.
author: Lecia K.

description: I have to update my previous review which I gave MaMa Ji's 4 1/2 stars.  On my 3rd visit, it was for lunch (Dim Sum).  I found the service chaotic, the server had no idea what was in the dish, no specials or changes on the menu from the 1st time we were there. If MaMa Ji's doesn't constantly change and reinvent itself, diners like myself will simply go elsewhere.
author: David P.

description: I just don't get the 4-5 star ratings. I had Kung Pao Chicken with white rice. It's rated as "medium hot", but it's one of the hottest dishes I've had. In addition to crushed dried Szechuan chilis there were TONS of fresh hot peppers (I think jalapeño, but I'm not sure). It also looked like the cook used Chili Oil. Regardless, there was a pool of red oil at the bottom. Too much. They used cashew instead of peanut. And it's low-quality chicken (thigh probably; certainly not breast). All I tasted was heat. The service was good, tho; there was only one waitress but she did a good job. BTW, for visitors: rice is $2 EXTRA! This boggles my mind. Made the lunch rather expensive for what it was.
author: Lake Y.

description: A little bit off the beaten track but easy to get to and in a nice neighbourhood. Great experience and delicious. It's a nice touch to be able to choose from a menu instead of the old cart thing. I don't get to enjoy dim sum often enough but I really liked their choices and preparation. Definitely recommended!
author: Uli B.

description:
Quick update, now that Mama Ji's has had a few weeks beyond their soft opening. They've smoothed out the service and salt issues, and seems like it's already habit-forming for a lot of people in the neighborhood, including us. Hard to walk by and not be tempted...

The atmosphere is relaxed and friendly and the food is SUPURB. The owners take care of customers without being overly solicitous. 

I honestly wouldn't go anywhere else in the city for Chinese food. And when it comes to dim sum, they've aced out Yank Sing: Better quality, better selection (you can order from the menu instead of waiting for a cart to come around) and bargain pricing.
author: Paula T.

description: Meh, I've tried a few times, and I want to like it cause it's local, but I'm done.  What they miss in flavor they make up for in hot peppers.  I like some heat on my food, but there has to be some flavor with it.  Over all it feels pretty haphazard and thrown together.  Much better food in Chinatown or Richmond.
author: Ruth F.

description:
This is the closest restaurant to me and every time I walk by it seems pretty darn busy.  I went in one day since everyone else was doing it and the menu did not seem super vegetarian friendly.  They made me veggie chow mein with tofu which was really good but really greasy, but that is to be expected of chow mein so I guess I can't complain.  The service was pretty good, a little slow to take my order but they were busy so it was understandable.  The beer was pretty expensive unless you wanted Blue Moon, which I didn't so I paid $9 for some delicious blond ale.

I am going in between 3 and 4 stars, but going with 4 in hopes that next time I am there I magically find an awesome veggie dish or take the time to ask what is veggie.  Couldn't really tell if cold noodles involved meat or not and I was not in the mood to ask.
author: Jonathan T.

description: Somewhat pricey, but good quality, very tasty, and excellent service.
author: Jason R.

description:
Craving dimsum and Ive been meaning to try this spot... All the food was excellent, but 3 stars because i literally had 4 servers the entire time. Pretty annoying. It was a nonstop cycle of servers coming to my table asking me the same things repeatedly. I initially ordered only shanghai dumplings and clearly explained id start with that and order more food in a little while. Even when i had to explain it to 3 others, that still wasnt good enough for them. It was almost like they kept sending servers over to pressure me into ordering more food, before i ever received the dumplings.  The employees need to communicate with each other better,assign tables and sections to their servers,  and not be in such a hurry to get people out of there. Otherwise, everything was delicious. IF i return, Ill be sure to tell them i want only ONE  server(preferably the brunette girl), and ill be ordering at my own pace. 
mama ji needs to relax.
author: Jordan s.

description: I am pickie to eat out when I am travel. When we went for dinner, the place was crowded and busy, but our waiter was amazing and took great care of us. He was overseeing a large section of tables, but he never forgot about us, even though we were only 2 people.The food was Ok here but server was very attentive. A little pricey compare to LA.
author: David G.

description: Food was delicious. It was super busy and yet the service was great! Definitely will be returning to experiment new dishes. Mama Ji's is a must!
author: Nikki W.

description: The food is probably 3/4 stars but the service - OMG bad! - so bad that I am not sure how they stay in business..  Not only are a couple of the waitstaff grumpy and rude - the owner is the WORST.  She scolds, is rude, impatient when THEY make mistakes.  HORRIBLE.  Unless you want to be insulted for no reason what so ever, do not even bother checking this place out.  They also don't care, so I suspect nothing will change unless people actually stop going.
author: Sim M.

description: Menu is very basic but delicious. I dare say the chili bean paste noodle is the best I've ever had of this kind. The owner is a nice guy. They haven't opened for a long time but from the queue waiting tonight it seems they are doing pretty well already.
author: Shirley W.

description: We live up the street and LOVE Mama Ji's. I only hesitate to write this review because I'm afraid it might become so popular, we won't be able to get in. The dim sum is delicious--although the selection is not as varied as you might get downtown, the food is yummy and portions generous.  I like the sticky rice, and the shanghai dumplings.  I've also had the wonton soup, which is good, but the broth is a little bland.  For dinner, I've had the Mapo tofu, which is delicious, with just the right degree of heat.
author: Christine H.

description: Really nice shrimp and chicken dumblings. No waiting time if you go around 7. not the greatest atmosphere for a special night out but prices and taste are great.
author: Chris S.

description: a very loveable restaurant...in the castro, Belgium beers on tap, cute tea cup set, clean white décor.   dim sum may not be the best ever but i will be eating it here from now on.   my faves were the shrimp shumai, shanghai dumplings and chili sauce noodles.   I'd pass on the veg steamed buns and spare ribs, both which lacks pizazz.  we ordered way too much for 2 people - i wish they kindly requested that we review our order because it was so excessive for 2!
author: Wakako U.

description: Food was awesome!  Service was terrible.  Communication was horrible.  I'd love to go back and eat the food but the service makes it difficult to go back unfortunately.
author: Monica H.

description: The best chinese food I have ever had. Accidentally found this place when we were looking for a quick bit of food and boy am I glad.  You have to get the Chongqing chicken and wings (go figure). Looking forward to going back.
author: Ike W.

description: so delicious and yummy! and the owners of MaMa Ji's are so adorable and nice
author: L. Y.

description: Enjoyable little spot tucked in the Castro neighborhood.  I was genuinely welcomed and offered a table right away.  Explaining that I was just dropping in for a glass of wine and an appetizer while I waited for my daughter to get off work didn't bother the young lady at all.  She promptly showed me the wine list and explained some of the dumplings and other dim sum items of which there were quite a few listed on the menu. I was very pleased with the atmosphere and attitude of everyone there - I was asked to come back with my family - I definitely will!  Truly gracious Staff.
author: R B.

description: very excited about this new addition to the hood. not the absolute best dim sum in the city, but damn good. sticky rice in lotus leaf and siu mai are top notch. my one grievance is that everything is VERY salty, and i love salt. tone that down and it's 5 stars!
author: Erica W.

description: OMG first time there and it was great! Good beer selection (it goes really well with Sichuan). Had the onion cake, boiled beef in fiery sauce, and crispy eggplant. With custard bun for dessert. Service was excellent as was the food. And the price was really reasonable - our bill was about $20 less than I thought it would be. Good value.
author: Playa S.

description:
ok this place was dim sum an can say over the top with amazing food for the 3 times I ate there before, This time with the new name and new menu and may i say was chopped in half! why! its a bigger kitchen, more staff and the place is huge inside . I was shocked that we had like 10 things to choose from after having like a 2 sided page before she merged with mama jis. Maybe its transition and getting the place on track. The food served hot and fresh but something was different  somehow ,someway and I honestly can not peg it yet but after we left I had the runs and blotted for 2 days . Normally i would say maybe something i ate earlier in the day but i only had oats like always , so the thing i think is the ingredients have been change from what it was before on some of the items we had, im only guessing,  I will of course go back and say it was a fluke and change the review.  I hope no MSG and now that its part of a CHAIN please do not mess with her old food style and ways it was amazing and over the top. again my review is not to be hurtful but honest and I want them to know that sometimes change is great but some things need to stay the same and not change stuff just to save money ... Please stay to her OLD food recipes!!!

Randy /Scorpio 
aka 
Randy Moore
author: Randy M.

description: They have great service and great dim sum! We will come back! This is the best Chinese restaurant ever!!!!!!
author: Lorena K.

description: Amazing place - great dim sum with Belgian beers to complement. Menu isn't too overbearing like many other places, so you get a great, homemade feel and taste. Highly recommended and the owners are great and offer helpful tips. This place is a must.
author: Andrew H.

description: I have to say this is one of my favorite chinese restaurants in the city and I am happier to go pick up food to go from here than have delivery at home. They get three stars because the last two times I have gone here I have had service issues. The first time was a to go order where the worker after running my card gave me the receipt which showed an extra item that I didn't order. To save time I told him not to recharge the card, and the extra chicken dish was amazing..but still not really good service. The next incident was in the restaurant. My date and I sat down and promptly order, three tables around us were seated and order shortly after us. I think they forgot to put in our order as the three tables around us order the same dishes and were eating and almost done before we finally asked where our food was. Again the food here is AMAZING...just have low expectations with the service.
author: David C.

description: I used to love this place. Despite the fact that it is a tad expensive (par for the course for the area) and the service is sparse, it was pretty tasty in the past and as recently as a few months ago, it was a place I would have considered bringing my Asian, dim sum loving parents when they visited from out of town. However, today we ate here and I have to say the food is no longer good or authentic. It is bland, the texture is off, the dumplings are weirdly chewy as though they were left out, the lotus rice (usually my favorite) was dry. Dishes I usually salivate just looking at were completely unappetizing to me and I was left disappointed with an uncomfortable stomach. Maybe it was an off-day, maybe they changed their chef, but I'm not going to risk the prices to come back. I can't bring my parents here in the future, sad to say. :( I'll be trekking out to the Sunset for my next dim sum run.
author: Christine S.

description: Overpriced dim sum. We ordered shanghai dumplings and they brought a side of  ginger. The ginger is meant to be soaked with vinegar to use as dipping sauce. Instead the waitress accidentally added soy sauce. No big deal only she took it away and never brought back it back! Also, they didn't even have hot mustard!
author: Jenny J.

description: This place is fantastic -- really tasty food and an extensive beer list (including Chimay on tap).  We ordered the vegetarian bean curd, pea shoots, and the shrimp-stuffed eggplant.  Each dish was delicious -- the pea shoots were a knock out (tasted like sugar snap peas).  Service was warm and friendly -- we even got to meet Mr. and Mrs. Mama Ji!  Even with all the great Chinese food options in the city, we will definitely be back.
author: M B.

description: Finally, an authentic Chinese place in the neighborhood! Great service, kind owners, and awesome spicy food. If you want the real deal (hint: beef broccoli and orange chicken are NOT the real deal), come here. My favorite was the fried pumpkin with salted duck egg. Yummy.
author: Caroline T.

description: Seriously good dimsum comes to the Castro. We've been here three times and can't wait to come back again. Favorites are sweet rice with shrimp, sausage, and egg in lotus leaf; turnip cake; and steamed BBQ bun. Authentic and value!
author: Ken S.

description: A fantastic selection of Belgian beers, with a very knowledgeable bartender (who I believe was the owner). Pork buns were light and fluffy and the house special spare ribs were fall off the bone tender. The dim sum overall was very impressive given that this used to be a coffee house. The Chongqing chicken was super spicy and perfectly crispy. I will definitely be coming back.
author: Sebastian A.

description:
I was a big fan of the Dim Sum at Mama Ji's before the remodel and, so, was really anxious to get back to try the new Sichuan dinner menu after returning to SF from a month long vacation. We went last Saturday evening around 7:00 and were surprised to find the place pretty crowded. One of the owners ("The White Guy") greeted us as we sat down and took time to explain each item on the dinner menu. NOTE: This is REALLY helpful as it is often so really understand what some Chinese dishes are! My husband and I don't eat red meat so we stuck to the vegetarian and chicken and fish/seafood dishes. The Hot & Sour Soup--vegetarian--was fabulous and a great way to begin. It's really hard to find a good, vegetarian version of this dish here. We continued with the Ma-Po Tofu, the Chongqing Chicken and one of the fish dishes (can't remember what it was called but it was amazing). The Tofu dish was delicious--large cubes of silky tofu perfectly cooked in a spicy, delicious sauce. I'd never had Chongquing chicken before but I'm a big fan now. It's deep fried and, then, cooked in the wok with lots of Sichuan peppers. Yum. The Castro has really been lacking in decent, let alone really good, Chinese food. I really think that Mama Ji's is going to make up for that

That said, they really were very busy on Saturday night and the place filled up just after we sat down. But, while there were some service issues--and this is to be expected in a new restaurant--the owner went out of his way to apologize for any lapses in service and even offered us complimentary wine and dessert (a very generous gesture). So, I'm going to be going back again and again for the great food. All new restaurants need a bit of time to get their momentum going. The really good food makes Mama Ji's stand out. Service issues can be fixed! Give it a try--you won't be disappointed!
author: Barry W.

description: This place is an impressive addition to Castro places to eat.  You don't have to like hot but if you do you'll really love some of the choices, this place offers some really impressive "home style" dishes that are a refreshing change from other Chinese places. A couple of the most impressive dishes were not hot at all, the chicken won ton soup was full of fresh cabbage in a decent broth and hand-crafted won tons with tons of greens in them - biting into the dumplings was a delight.  The rib main course was also rich in a home cooked style sauce that was a pleasant change from the over-corn starched sauces of other places. Other mains that were impressive were the Chicken with Tofu in a red sauce laden with spices but not too overwhelming.  Beer selection is heavy on craft monk-brewed Belgium ales that go well with the robust flavors. Desserts included a steam dumpling egg custard bun, where the pillow of fluffy white dough encased a tasty real egg custard, and such good value with three puffy balls arriving for a very reasonable price. Good luck to this excellent addition to our somewhat otherwise mediocre food choices in the Castro. Can't wait to try the Dim Sum.
author: Bill e.
